Reviews.Title: “Great Time”
Reviews.Author: Rory000
Reviews.Content: We had very positive family vacation. Staff was friendly and helpful. Room was great and the pools, water park and private island were also great. Only suggestions would be to provide some authentic PR music in main lobby ( versus the very nice 2 men singing Bon Jovi cover tunes ); maybe work on the AC temps as its deep freeze and perhaps a bit fairer pricing on the beers on the island. These are minor suggestions for an overall positive stay. We will return.

Reviews.Title: “The only beach is off site, and the water is filled with weeds.”
Reviews.Author: Justanothertraveler7
Reviews.Content: Because I met many very friendly (although typically not well trained) employees at at El Conquistador (ElCon) I feel bad about sharing my experience. I still feel compelled to do so in order to prevent others from wasting vacation dollars without at least understanding what they are getting into. First of all, El Conquistador DOES NOT HAVE A BEACH ATTACHED TO THE PROPERTY. You know how a cruise ship works, where you wait in a line to board a boat which takes you to a shore beach (and then wait again when you need to board to go back), with your time at the beach limited by the hours that the transport boat operates? This is the situation at ElCon, as the only beach is a 15 minute ferry ride out of the marina (3 pm is the last ferry to the beach, and last ferry back is at 5:30pm). You take a tram to this ferry ride, by the way (if they are working, otherwise it is a 30 minute bus ride around the property). Had I known this, I would NEVER have stayed there. Imagine what a pain this is. You spend a lot of money and fly hours and hours and the one thing you really want, a turquoise Caribbean beach a few steps away, is not only far but is also controlled and limited by access and time. Worse then finding out that there is no beach without travel, you finally get there and all of the water, except for a few tiny spots suitable for standing (not big enough for swimming) is FILLED WITH SEAWEED (I don't know what you call it - eel grass? Basically it is long ribbony dark embedded weeds that to me is pretty gross and being a little skittish I wonder what could be hiding in there). It's everywhere - almost no one was in the water. Even in the few clear areas where you could stand, floating sea weed is in the water and keeps brushing by your legs. People basically just sat in their chairs in the hot sun (there are only a few umbrellas) and drank the $10 a pop teeny tiny pina coladas or expensive beers. You could rent a jet ski or kayak, but if I fell over the weeds it would have made me pretty unhappy so I declined. Then there was the beach sand. What a mess! It is filled with dried up seaweed, chunks of broken coral, a water bottle top here and there, etc. Note: There was no big storm right before I was there. There is so much seaweed growing everywhere that this has to be a constant problem. They could at least use a machine to clean the beach, since that is all there is to enjoy on this little island off the resort's coast (and it is the resort's only beach). I would also WEED THE WATER. A big swath of it, so people have somewhere relatively clear to swim. Maybe that isn't possible, but it's a thought. My favorite thing to do on beach vacations is swim, but I went once to the beach at ElCon and never went back. I stood in the water for a minute or two and then got out. Now back to the resort. If you are still game for a visit, DO NOT stay in the rooms closest to the marina on the 2nd tram level. The "funiculars", or trams, broke down frequently, and at one point both (there are only two) were down and I had no way to get back to my room (I therefore arrived at a business dinner dressed for the beach). I didn't have time for the back up bus ride, which when adding the wait for everyone ahead of me to go in the huge line, would have taken way more than the 30 minute drive promised. When the trams are running, the walk through the VAST property, to the tram, plus the wait, then the walk to the rooms, including the FOUR STAIRCASES up to the third floor (at $10 a pop for a drink, you can't provide an elevator???), then down a long hallway, and then back again, takes about 40 minutes minimum if all goes well. So when you go to the main building for anything (pools, restaurants, casino, shops - it's all there), don't forget anything back at your room!! Basically, get a room in the main building if you want to stay at ElCon. A friend who stayed there was quite happy with his proximity (he did say that his room smelled moldy). Our inconvenient room down the tram ride was quite spacious, tastefully decorated, and had a nice, though distant, view of the water. The many white, waterproof surfaces on the modern furniture were dirty, but I guess I could have spent a little time wiping them (I just wasn't inclined). The staff...With few exceptions, I found the people there to be genuinely friendly and fun. It seems that for the most part management had a good eye for hiring nice people. Unfortunately, management then failed to properly train or empower them. When things go wrong, the employees are not empowered to do anything to compensate or make the guests happy. When both trams were broken and forty frustrated guests stood in the hot air waiting for the people locked in the stuck tram to be released, all of the employees were like, "Oh well...". One gentleman listened sympathetically, then did nothing. No follow up. People shut out of their rooms with business dinners to attend were offered no amenities. A man at the front desk told us that a manager would be contacting impacted guests to discuss the situation. No one ever called. This is a management problem, not an individual employee problem, as it is systemic to this place in every part of the resort. I went to one of the top floor, expensive restaurants and the hostess was munching on her dinner as we discussed table availability. Literally sitting and eating it as I walked up. I sat with an empty pina colada for thirty minutes while a table of employees ate next to me at the marina bar restaurant. Every server was more interested in chatting with their fellow employees and bringing them food and drinks then asking me if I wanted another. I'm happy for their camaraderie, but I've just never seen anything like that before. There are many instances where you might be in an elevator or the tram, or standing in line somewhere, and the employees around you are laughing and chatting loudly in Spanish to one another and having a grand old time as if you aren't there. I'm not sure how to describe what is off about this, but it seems as if they are the ones on vacation and the guests are the ones stuck in a constant quest to figure out all of the many obstacles that go with this property. One thing I will say is that they seem very happy working there, and they all seem to enjoy each other's company. By itself, that is a positive, and I'm sure it says something good about how management treats employees. Still, I think the staff would be even happier working at a place where the guests were taken better care of, because that leads to better reviews, repeat customers, a full hotel, and job security. In addition to the four staircases we climbed in the heat every time we needed to go to our room, the giant escalator to all of the nice restaurants on the top floor was broken the entire week we were there. I have never in my life seen an escalator broken for so long. Am I wrong or can the down escalator be put in reverse so at least the uphill climb is assisted? Is it that difficult to find someone to repair an escalator? If you look around the resort, there are MANY places needing paint, a broken tile replaced, carpet changed (like the ripped carpet at THE FRONT DESK?!), etc. It looks like a bit of a recession thing, but it's all simple and quick fix stuff. What a shame as the resort is really beautiful and it's all cosmetic. Again, it seems to be a management issue. In fact, I never once saw any senior looking manager milling about anywhere. I guess I could have missed him or her, but surely he or she is missing a lot of what is going on. The best things about this resort...The view is spectacular, really. You are up on a cliff looking over magnificent water (too far away to see the weeds). I heard the golf course is good, although with the ONE HOUR DRIVE FROM THE AIRPORT and the other issues, I'm afraid to say that the El Conquistador is a big no in my opinion. There are just too many other resorts in gorgeous, sunny places with perfect, clear beaches which are attached to the property. These places often have beautiful golf courses, and many of them do not require a one hour drive from the airport. Out of those options I would choose a place where the property is in good repair and the staff is well trained. After that, I'd be OK with paying $10 for that pina colada.

Reviews.Title: “Not bad, but not Five Star in my opinion.”
Reviews.Author: AKmama3
Reviews.Content: Husband and I visited the resort for a business trip, so most expenses were paid for by the company. We did, however, choose before our trip to extend our stay a few days after the business part was finished, so those days were on us. The resort was beautiful and the view was specatular. Our room was just ok, it was in a very noisy location and we could hear busses and rolling luggage almost constantly during the night. The tub didnt drain well at all and we were ankle deep in water everytime we showered. We did inform housekeeping. My two biggest complaints about the resort are (1) Most of the staff we encountered during our six days were rude and unhelpful. It was as if we were wasting their time. We arent high maintence people by any means, so when we asked for directions or assistance it was basic and minimal. The response and treatment from the staff was terrible, especially at the front desk and at the casino (which is a joke). Ive been treated better by the staff at my local Quik Lube during an oil change. (2) I absolutely expected paying high meal prices and looked forward to it! I love food! We were at a Five Star resort after all and I assumed the food would measure up to the resorts rating as well. I was sadly disappointed. We had probably the worst sandwiches ever at the cafe next to the Ice Cream Shop. Dried out meat, too much bread and flavorless. Subway would have been better. For the price, I would have expected it to have at least looked like they put a little effort into it. The Striphouse was awesome! The steaks were done to perfection, juicy and of great quality. The service was outstanding and the atmosphere was one of a kind. A gem! Blossoms was terrible! Tasted like what a run-of-the-mill Asian buffet would taste like. The Stingray was very nice. We sat outside on a lovely warm night and dined on perfectly steamed clams and seared scallops. Very nice evening out. My complaint with the food is that if your going to charge me as much for a sandwich and fries as you are for steak and seafood (etc.), then it had ALL better be top notch! The food was pretty much a crap shoot! My husband and I actually cut our trip short and spent our last two days in Old San Juan. The hotel we stayed at was very cozy and the staff was so nice and accomodating. It was soo much fun! I wouldnt go back to El Conquistador.

Reviews.Title: “Nice property, but has a lot of areas for improvement....”
Reviews.Author: LikesAGoodValue007
Reviews.Content: We just returned from our six night stay at the El Conquistador in Fajardo during the week of April 1, 2012. To start off, the property itself was very impressive. Check-In We were greeted by a bellman that loaded our luggage onto a cart and whisked us to the check in at the main lobby. Check-in was smooth and we were given the option of several rooms, and opted for one near the main lobby. Good choice, as for the most part evenings were quiet without any disruptions to our sleep. The person who checked us in was helpful and took the time to answer our questions regarding the property. Room The room itself was pretty spacious and the bathroom was huge. The carpets were worn, but the bed linens and mattresses seemed to be in good shape and were good quality. The bathroom was large, but it had a mildew smell to them and mildew stains in the shower grout. We fixed that by buying a bottle of bathroom cleaner with bleach and spraying it down the first few days we were there. Rooms were cleaned daily and the done at a satisfactory level. Pools There are a number of pools on the property and they are very nice. The problem is getting a chair(s) at the pool. The hotel seems like it allows anybody onto the property, and it appears that it does not have any controls over who can use the pools/facilities. If the hotel does have a policy for restricting the pool use to guests staying at the hotel, and/or their guests, it does not appear to enforce them. You can park your car in the parking lot, unload your car and head to the pool without showing proof that you are a guest.We observed cars that would pull into the parking lot. People would unload their vehicle with coolers and plastic bags with their personal items, and walk onto the hotel property without showing proof that they were staying at the hotel. There would be groups of these cooler people at the pool that would ambush chairs as soon as other guests picked up their towels and left. Before you know it, you had a large group with their own base camp that seemed to take over certain areas of the pool. There are better controls at public pools where you have to show ID or proof of residence or pay a small fee to use the facilities. If you donâ€™t mind knowing that anybody can just walk off the street and use the facilities without paying for them or being a guest of the hotel, then I guess youâ€™ll be OK with this.This was similar to the water park. There didnâ€™t appear to be anybody enforcing whether you had a bracelet indicating that you paid for your water park visit. There seemed to be a number of people enjoying the water park with no wristbands. Hereto, you just walk from the pool, take a tram (where nobody checks your hotel guest card) and walk right into the water park. There is no gate, nobody checking whether youâ€™re a guest. Just walk right in and use the facilities. Again, there appeared to be little if any control as to who can use the facilities. We realized that after we paid and received our wristbands and were at the water park for an hour or so. The place where you paid for your wristband was located inside the park, and we had to search to find it.The only time we were asked to show proof that we were guests was when we charged food/services to our room, or when we boarded the ferry that took us to Palomino Island, the resortâ€™s private island beach. When we would validate our parking ticket, the valets would ask if youâ€™re a guest of the hotel or a visitor. So they seemed pretty aware and accepting that visitors come to the hotel and use the facilities. By the way, they have a â€œno coolerâ€� or outside food policy for Palimino Island. That is strictly enforced. We saw several people in line who had coolers were told that they could not bring them aboard the ferry. Even when you enter resort at the front gate, we were not required to show proof that we were guests of the hotel. Restaurants Restaurants are pricey and the food is average. Our first morning we ate breakfast at the one of the â€œcasual restaurantsâ€� and selected the buffet. It was pretty straight forward something along the line of what I got as a complimentary breakfast at another hotel, except here you could have an omelet made for you. When I got the bill, it was close to $90 with tax and tip. That seemed a bit pricey for a breakfast buffet. $24 for adults and $12 for children.We ate at several other restaurants, and again the food was average, the service was slow and the prices were pretty steep for what you got in return. We ate lunches at the pool, and wound up going off property for dinner most evenings. Conclusion I do recommend the hotel with the caveats listed above. We booked this last minute, and it seemed like a logical choice since it is a Waldorf Astoria owned property. We spent a few nights at their flagship hotel in NYC and were very happy. However, if you have another vacation spot in the Caribbean, you may want to consider it.

Reviews.Title: “Had a Blast”
Reviews.Author: steveatl1
Reviews.Content: I went on a family trip with my brother, his wife, and two kids (ages 9 and 11) this April. Pros: 1. stunningly beautiful views 2. easy one hour ride from San Juan 3. water park was a blast (3 slides, pools, pool "river") 4. Palomino Island is a private beach via 15 min ferry ride - quiet, plenty of chairs, activities for rental, bar and restaurant, umbrellas for rent, great for adults and kids. 5. staff was always friendly 6. rooms have quiet AC and are comfortable - great bathrooms, changing areas, balcony (Las Brisas wing) 7. Pools have towels and plenty of chairs/places in sun and shade 8. Outdoor cafe by lobby is the best restaurant - good pizza and more reasonably priced. 9. Plenty of activities offsite via the concierge 10. casino is small but $5 blackjack is fun 11. Starbucks onsite but expect lines in the morning Cons: 1. Skip the main restaurants - expect $40+ entrees and the food is good but not great. 2. Shops for snacks/food - everything twice the cost you'd pay at home. In fact, all of the restaurants and food items (ice cream, burgers, pizza, you name it - double the cost). 3. You need to rent a car to get off the island to hit local restaurants which we didn't do. 4. Main breakfast buffet is pretty good but $28 with tip per person for adults. 5. To get to the beach, you have to ride the funicular down to the marina, then catch the ferry which runs every 30 min - timing can be tricky, and if one of the funiculars are broken, you can wait in line. Not a bad thing, just be aware of this. 6. Everyone, I mean everyone, is from Massachusetts or Connecticut. I found that odd. 7. Service is slow (bars/restaurants) and they are pretty casual about having one person floating around with a tray by the pools. Tips: 1. rent a car and get the off property for a day - probably cheaper to do the rainforest excursion that way, or others. 2. Bring some wine/booze/snacks to your room (pack some for the trip) 3. Pack long pants as it can be breezy and cool there at night. 4. expect to spend $100 a day extra on top of what you've already paid (unless you are doing inclusive package) 5. If you are staying in separate rooms, make sure you are not separated by the funicular ride - this would be frustrating and can waste time. 6. A light breakfast at Starbucks is 1/3 the cost of the breakfast buffet. But doing the breakffast buffet allows you to skip lunch which can be convenient. 7. The outdoor casual restaurant down at the marina is not very good.

Reviews.Title: “week in Puerto Rico”
Reviews.Author: dmrubnitz
Reviews.Content: The El Conquistador was very nice. Pool was great, service excellent and food was delicious. Very neat water park on site. Downsides were a beach that took an elevator ride, gondola ride and 30 minute boat ride to get to. The view was awesome though. Beach was on a private Island that had a resturant and bar along with stuff to do. However you had to rent floats and umbreallas. We had a great time though and thoroughly enjoyed our stay. El Younque rain forest hike was very good as well.

Reviews.Title: “Huge, beautiful, but overpriced”
Reviews.Author: NYCtraveler062
Reviews.Content: I thought the resort was very large with tons of stuff to do. The grounds and hotel and it's areas were very clean and well kept and all the staff that I met were extremely friendly and helpful. All the food is overpriced and everything has a price on it. They strive to have you use your room card for purchases which I feel keeps most people from keeping track of what they are spending. All in all, I had a pleasent stay, but would most likely not stay here again with family.

Reviews.Title: “Flaming bag of dog crap”
Reviews.Author: Chris O
Reviews.Content: This place was awful, believe the one star reviews. My experience was like many of the others I have read about. The hotel tried to charge me $200 more per night than what I had originally booked it at, my room was dirty, the staff was rude, the food was terrible and expensive and the service sucked. Fortunately the have decent wireless and I was able to book a much nicer (and cheaper) hotel elsewhere. Beware!

Reviews.Title: “Nice, huge property!”
Reviews.Author: Snickersmama
Reviews.Content: We just got back from a trip to the El Conquistador with a large group for a "rewards trip". I was initially very nervous about getting a room literally right next to the elevator/lobby/drive up area, thinking it may be loud. But I think the walls must be concrete because we hardly heard anything, which was a nice surprise. While I agree with some other reviews that the property could use some updating here or there, it was obvious the rooms had already had some updating (minus the shower, but that was ok), plus it was such a nice, expansive property, it was easy to look past that. The views towards Palomino Island are just fabulous. We really didn't eat at the restaurants since our food was provided typically buffet style for a large group, but I'm sure it's a similar taste throughout the property, and everything we had was good. Did have a cheeseburger at the island restaurant one day when we wanted to hang out at the beach, and that was pretty good! Pricey, but it's what you would expect at a typical resort like this, so no shock there. While we did not come here this time with family like we normally would, I would not hesitate to come back as I think everyone would have fun, especially the kids. There was a waterpark to keep them occupied, plus various activities out at Palomino island like miniature golf, soccer, horseback riding, snorkeling, volleyball, etc etc. I also did not realize until the last evening that a little market area was not too far from the property, so next time I would probably venture off over there to check out the local restaurants too. We also golfed one day at the resort, and the course was beautiful (but very hilly!). The rental clubs were very nice too, which was great. Pack bottled water in your suitcase, since they are $2.50 each if you buy them at the resort. Overall, we really enjoyed this place, and will definitely look at coming back in the future to spend more time here with our family members. Also, the employees were all very friendly and helpful!

Reviews.Title: “Good from afar but far from good”
Reviews.Author: samjacobson
Reviews.Content: I arrived at 4:30 on a Thursday after having travelled since 7am to get here to be told the rooms were not ready The front desk staff was rather obvious The room when we finally got it was tired and not in good condition. The barroom walls were stained and needed a total renovation The bed was ok but the carpet was worn Overall too much of a hassle to get to a very mediocre place at best This is not doing anything for the Waldorf Astoria Brand

Reviews.Title: “DONT' Waste Your MONEY”
Reviews.Author: Traci B
Reviews.Content: The hotel is run down, definately NOT what you would expect from a Woldorf hotel. Hotel staff is rude. Rooms where unclean and you had to call routinely for towels. Don't waste your money!

Reviews.Title: “Ivan Gines made the trip!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: samparks42
Reviews.Content: Great week and the following staff were exceptional; Ivan Gines went above and beyond to entertain the kids. Wilma found the kids coconuts and was gracious. Freddie at the Ballyhoo was also fantastic. Great time at Palamino Island and the watermark.

Reviews.Title: “Great 'Classic' resort. Good for families.”
Reviews.Author: PatientX
Reviews.Content: If you saw.read the review titled "Five star name, three star hotel"...it might not be too far off. I'll tone that down just a tad though and say "5 star name, 3.8 star hotel, 6 star restaurant prices") Our family (myself, my wife and our 12 yr old daughter and 8 yr old son) just arrived home yesterday from 6 days at the El Conquistador. We had a wonderful time and overall I would recommend the hotel and I would stay there again. We had rented a car in San Juan (Enterprise) and drove the 50 minutes out to Fajardo. Highways are well marked; however, once you are off the main road use the GPS since there are few to no signs with road names. Back to the hotel...my only complaint is that the resort food is WAY (again, WAY) expensive. We had 2 meals at Cafe Caribe (dinner the night we arrived, and breakfast the next morning) but never ate on property again. Dinner (for what was basically cafeteria food) for the 4 of us was $100. Breakfast was $65. I'm sorry, but thats robbery. From then on we jumped in the car and drove a couple of minutes to a local Panaderia and each had eggs, toast, bacon and coffee/juice for $3.50/each. Breakfast pastries at the same place were 75 cents. We had lunch at stands or took sandwiches back to the hotel. The best meals we had were in Luqillo at the Kiosks. Terruno (I think #20) was the best, although Congas was just as good. We had dinner the last night at Metropol (Cuban) in Fajardo. The food was awesome and reasonable. I had the Fiesta Cubana platter $14 which sampled 7 or so of the favorite dishes. We were actually recommended to go to Boricuba, but found it dark, lonely and the parking lot overgrown like it had been derelict for years. Weird that the Concierge had recommended it as 'one of my favorites'. We had booked a garden room, but found that we had a beautiful view of El Yunque and also of the ocean out towards Luqillo over the golf course. Bonus. It was nice to have a patio/balcony with chairs which was a fav morning and late evening spot. There are so many different wings and levels to the hotel that its wise to look at the buildings and ask to be in a certain wing. We were in the Las Vistas wing which has direct access to the pools, spa and golf/tennis and is near the lobby. The trade-off is that we had a few minute walk to the funicular which takes you down to the marina for the boat to the island/beach. If you want to the close to the marina, ask for the Las Brisas or Las Olas, but of course then you will be walking to the pool or lobby. (although Las Olas has its own pool) Overall our room was clean and comfortable, and large. Other reviews said 'paper thin walls', which was not our experience. Our walls were concrete, but I think that review was the Las Brisas wing. We had 2 queen size beds, a reading chair with ottoman, desk with chair, TV console with drawers, and night stand with iPod dock. There was also a counter with coffee maker and small refridgerator. The closet is large and in the bathroom, which has a separate commode area. We rented a movie from the DVD machine near the Business Center one night ($5.45 rental). For some reason the TV then wouldnt go back to the regular TV channels and was stuck on AV2, but a call to guest services produced a 'technician' in about 10 minutes and he had it working in 2 minutes. The pool complex was wonderful. If you have kids the two pools in front of Las Vistas are the better ones. The upper pool (nearest the casino) gets more adult traffic as it has the swim-up bar and restaurant. A small inconvenience is that the only towel shack is at the upper pool, so one of us had to trek up and down the stairs for towels. We visited the beach on Palomino Island on 2 diff days. It is beautiful and the water was clear and warm. You can play mini-golf, sandbag toss, soccer, volleyball and basketball for free. Snorkel equip, tubes, jet skis etc are for rent. (we didnt and I dont know how much they were. Well, I think snorkels were $9). Horseback riding is $69 per person!! I'm sorry, but does that come with a steak dinner? I dont care if it is on a private island... The island also has a couple of gift shops where you can buy trinkets, sunscreen ($12/can), hats ($22), t-shirts, masks/snorkel ($22), and other sundry. Of course expect 'resort' pricing. We bought a few things the day before we left and on check-out I saw that the charge had shown up twice, so double-check your bill before you sign it. Self-park was easy. Drive in, push the button, get the ticket and park. Before you return to your car visit the parking counter and get your ticket 'validated' (aka. charged to your room). You have 20 minutes then to get to the car and put it in the machine on your way out of the parking lot. Lets see....what else? Starbucks is a busy place in the mornings, per usual anywhere. The little market next door is a ripoff. The other store closer to the lobby is slightly more reasonable. Wifi...worked great in the room, lobby and Starbucks. Nowhere else. Note: ATT and T-Mobile/Sprint are in-network in PR. Verizon is roaming, so pay up or turn it off and leave it in the room safe. Back to food for a sec...You can find a gillion places serving breakfast (desayunos) etc by going down to the entrance and make a left (Cabezas) and quick right (Avenida Conquistador). When you get to the 2 speed bumps turn left (still Ave Conquistador) and you'll see the Panaderia a couple of blocks down on your left. Otherwise, if you go past the Panaderia there is a Burger King another block down. BTW...for those daring enought to read this book I just wrote, order the PR Entertainment Book a week before you leave. For the $25 you will find restaurant coupons, rental car coupons etc. I used the Enterprise Double-Upgrade coupon and got a midsize, and we used about 3 other ones. The book paid for itself about 3 times over.

Reviews.Title: “Family Vacation”
Reviews.Author: PaulDBoston
Reviews.Content: I am writing this review on the 6th day of our 7 day stay. We were given a 2 bed room in the Marina, 2nd floor, ocean view. Overall we could not be any happier with the room location- it is in the heart of the action and quieter than being up above in the main resort. Travel to and from the main resort is a bit of a walk, but I have not found any difficulty as the two funicular cars are well timed so that the wait is no more than 5 minutes. Staying with the family including kids ages 6 and 9, I like the marina because it is near the Ballyhoo restaurant,which is one of the less expensive choices where most of the action is. It is also great for the kids to be at water level, so we can walk the marina and see the bots, easy access to the water park and there is a cafe take out breakfast, the ferry to the Palomino Island, shops, etc. There is really no reason for us to go up to the main resort except to check out different restaurants, pools, etc. My rating of this resort is broken down into three categories: good, bad and ugly as follows: Good: the location of this resort is truly unique; the views from the upper resort are like nowhere I have ever been, and from the marina at sea level it is outstanding as well. Overall, the property is older but well maintained, and efforts have been made to provide updates in key areas. The staff are generally helpful (see below for more on this). There is a lot going on at this resort, more than ample to fill a week for the family without becoming bored. Bad: When you travel to a resort, you know it will be expensive, with that said the prices of food and drinks at all restaurants are ridiculously high. My Wife believes this is necessary to fund the huge overhead of this property including the ferry to the island,and operating the island itself. I would strongly recommend family travelers rent a car at the airport, so that you can make a huge Wallmart run to stock up on necessities and be able to get out of the resort on occasion. Aside from prices, I have found some of the staff to be helpful, and others that could not be bothered. One example of this was my first experience with the concierge- upon check in I needed to quickly find a place to get the kids some lunch as we had been traveling since 5 AM, and by 3 PM they were really hungry. Overwhelmed with the many restaurant choices, I approached the concierge to ask for advice about a good place to eat, preferably something that would not take too long. The individual at the desk threw a binder of menus at me and said here you go. I asked several questions, and received little to no guidance; I felt that my request for help was inconveniencing this person as she was constantly checking her text messages. We ended up at the restaurant at the main pool and the service was horrible, it took about an hour and a half for a basic lunch. Fortunately, this was the most extreme example of bad service to date and since then things have improved. The Ugly: I was surprised to find an active water leak in the ceiling of the closet in our room, and active mold growth indicating this leak was not new. Called the operator to report the issue, and was met with the attitude that this was not a big deal. I explained the heath risks of mold to the individual, and was then transferred to a supervisor who said she would refer the concern to housekeeping for further review. When we returned to the room that evening, the mold had been removed but the leak continues several days later, causing us to leave this area free and clear of all personal items- not what you would expect at a 5 star resort. Summary: huge resort, very unique and special location. Very expensive; you will continuously pay every step of the way. WiFi does exist, but the bandwidth is so narrow that it is effectively not possible to get anything done- the speeds are slightly better than dial up. Some people here are very helpful, but overall the customer service attitude seems to be from ambivalence to please don't bother me, I am checking my text messages. I am giving 4 stars overall, but I think 3.5 is more accurate.

Reviews.Title: “Five Star Name Three Star Hotel”
Reviews.Author: MelDC
Reviews.Content: My family and I spent 6 nights at El Conquistador over spring break . I had read many reviews prior to our visit on TA and most of them were spot on. We arrived early Monday afternoon and check in was a breeze. ROOM We had booked a room in the Las Olas section of the hotel. We chose to stay in Las Olas because the rooms are a bit more spacious than other parts of the hotel and this section also has its own pool which is nice if you have little ones and you want to avoid crowds. The room we were originally assigned was on the 3rd floor of Las Olas. We had a stroller for my son so the bellman suggested that we request a lower room in that section as there are no elevators in that part of the hotel. The front desk staff quickly obliged our request and we were taken on our way. The room had a king size bed and a â€œdayâ€� bed which my daughter slept on. The room on the first floor of Las Olas had an obstructed view and the funicular stop was right off the balcony, which was extremely noisy. We requested a room change for the next day which we were granted. Carrying the stroller up the flights of stairs was a pain but worth it in the long run. The website says that the room has a mini fridge and neither room that we stayed in had one; also of note no minibar. Walls in the hotel are paper thin and hallways are noisy so if you are a light sleeper you may want earplugs. The air conditioning sounds like a 747 taking off each time it comes on. If you have a baby know that the hotel provides (for a fee) pack and plays as opposed to cribs. It had almost no padding on the bottom so it feels like your baby is sleeping on a board. Maid service was a bit frustrating. Most days we left our room around 9am and returned at 4 to a room that had not been serviced. FOOD My husband and I often comment that on vacation our worst and most expensive meals are the ones we had at the hotel. We ate at the hotel our entire stay. The prices are in line with every place we have been. The food is OKâ€¦nothing great nothing horrible. I would say avoid Blossoms if you can. It was strange because some meals seemed to take far too long and others were rushed, no consistency but exactly what I expected. If you want a quiet meal do not eat on the â€œpatioâ€� of the Italian restaurant. There is a piano in the area and every parent seems to think it is darling when their snowflake pounds away on the thingâ€¦its not cute or endearing, it is annoying and I say this as someone with two children. One of the most frustrating aspects of the trip was the Starbucks; the line was well over a half hour long each day. This was not due to the number of people, as my Starbucks has a line out the door every day and I am always out in no more than 10 minutes, it is just the â€œisland timeâ€� attitude. GROUNDS For the most part the hotel grounds are very nice. Here and there you see wear and tear. We did not find the funicular as annoying as other reviewers. By staying in the Las Olas section you can actually walk down to the Marina level, so you only need the funicular when going up to the main hotel. The week we were there the hotel was full and most of the time we did not feel any crowding. My husband golfed and said the course was well maintained. We were not as impressed with Palomino as other reviewers. It was a bit of a pain to take the boat over with a 5 month old, get there and have to set up your spot. Once you are there you kind of have to make a day of it since the getting there is at a minimum 30-45 minutes by the time you board the boat and ride over (not to mention the waiting in line). We did the waterpark one day, which my 6 year old loved. I do think the charge for it was a bit much considering it only had 3 slides; one days admission should be included as part of the resort fee. The hotel had a scavenger hunt game set up for kids while we were there. The kids had to collect bands from different locations at the hotel. Each location had a fact about Puerto Rico or something unique to see. My daughter loved the game and it was a great way to see and learn about the entire resort. Overall, if this was a Hilton I would say the trip was a success. By putting the name Waldorf Astoria on the hotel, I expect more as far as the staff anticipating my needs. I would expect a first rate experience and things like room and beach service, neither of which were available. We found most of the people on staff to be very nice and accommodating of our requests but some of the things should have been standard given they we were supposedly staying at a high end hotel.

Reviews.Title: “I feel El Conned!”
Reviews.Author: Allwitty
Reviews.Content: My review in three words: not so much I'm writing this review from the confines of the thin walls in my Las Brisas room. I don't even know where to begin. This hotel is an utter disappointment. It's so dreadful it's inspired my first tripadvior.com review. I absolutely regret making the decision to stay here. Three more words: Dirty, dirty, dirty There are dirty carpets all over the second floor of Las Brisas and the lobby. Coincidentally, these are the only two carpeted areas I've been in. We entered our room and found hairs in the sink, and on the floor, and on the bed, and in the tub... I had to stop looking. Walls are cracked, water damaged, and rooms are appointed with dingy furniture. Forgetful Food Fail Get the service straight first, worry about the crust later! They never put my daughter's steak order in at dinner tonight. So my son, my husband and I were all served our meals while my wide eyed daughter wondered where her dinner was. 20 minutes after our dinners show up, hers finally makes an appearance. No apology from the server, nada. This happened while we sat next to some sort of manager meeting where they discussed improvements that could be made to the pizza crusts served at the retaurant. Erm... Why not focus on service first guys? Then focus on minutia later. It's surprising that this is a Waldorf. I should check the spelling on the signage here. Maybe I'm at a Waldorph-Asstoria and not an authentic Waldorf-Astoria. If this is not a knock-off Waldorf-Astoria there are Walsorfs and Astors doing 360's in their graves right now. More negatives: This place needs a serious update. The funicular is more like the scaryicular. The ride is rickety and rusty. I don't mind waiting for it as long as it's safe! I mentioned the dirty part already right? The bathroom/closet combination does not work for me at all. You have to walk through the bathroom to get to the closet. Most architects will say you don't want to have to go through a wet area to get to a dry area. This place looks cheap, feels cheap, with a not-so-cheap price tag. To be fair some positives There are a lot of amenities. From Starbucks to a shoe store this place is loaded with amenities. Fortunately the Starbucks and retail shops are not as ramshackle as the rest of the hotel. The pools are nice. But, that reminds me of another negative. $70 for a family of 4 to ride on three watersides and a lazy river makes me feel so used, especially after shelling out a fair share of cash for a dismal dorm of a room. Oh! I just thought of another positive! The view from my ocean front room is nice. Will I return? Just one word for this one, NO! I cannot believe that this is a $500 per night room. I feel like I've been el Conned by the el Conquistador.

Reviews.Title: “We were pleasantly surprised!”
Reviews.Author: JeanineClifton
Reviews.Content: Our room had a garden view and we overlooked the golf course and the mountains. Our hotel room was modern, clean and very spacious. We ate in the casual restaurants and thought that the food was good and wasn't over priced. Our 18 and 19 year old sons loved the beach, the pools and room service. I was impressed that every staff member we met along the way greeted us. When there was a broken pipe in our section, they left us a voice mail letting us know what was going on and completed the repair quickly. We enjoyed taking the ferry to the private island. The beach was beautiful and clean with plenty of chairs. They also offered on the beach free activities: volley ball, basketball, horse shoes and mini-golf. For an additional fee you could rent a jet ski, kayak, floating mat, snorkel gear or go parasailing. We all had a wonderful time and I would definitely go again.

Reviews.Title: “No adult pool... or anything else”
Reviews.Author: AmyRed713
Reviews.Content: This is a "family-friendly" resort, unless you are considering feeding your family. In that case, it's quite expensive for food/drinks, much less other resort activities. The rooms were average, at best. I will say the staff was very courteous and we enjoyed most of the food. Strip House was delicious, and was where we dined more frequently, partly due to the absence of children. There are no adult-only areas, which was probably the biggest disappointment. Palomino Island was quite nice, however it somewhat cumbersome to get over there. On our first night there, we took a taxi into town and bought food, liquor, and beer for our lunches & snacks, which saved a lot of cash and no one at the resort seemed to care. Near the resort, there is a small fishing village and park (an easy 10-15 minute leisurely walk). We walked there to eat at some local places, as the resort didn't provide much of a cultural experience in the way of food, or anything else. We also did a bioluminescent bay kayak tour (not resort-sponsored) that departed from the pier in the village. Even walking there at night, we felt pretty safe. Were it not for our first few days we spent in Old San Juan (at another hotel -the Gallery Inn... so cool), our trip to Puerto Rico would have felt very ordinary.

Reviews.Title: “Impressed, even at full capacity”
Reviews.Author: Nickknick
Reviews.Content: We stayed over Easter break. We arrived around dinner time and didn't have to wait to check in. We were even upgraded to an ocean view room in the marina. I didn't expect that given the full capacity. The staff was always prompt and friendly. Since we rented a car, we only ate at the bar restaurant in the marina. Standard food at resort prices...but it was fast. We stocked up on breakfast and lunch items at Ralph's food warehouse in fajardo. We wished we could have had more time allotted on our vacation for palomino island. That was our favorite part of this resort. Great snorkeling, plenty of towels and chairs. The island is why we will return and spend more time here. Wifi worked great for usin our room. We had yaucona coffee every morning on our balcony.

Reviews.Title: “Family vacation”
Reviews.Author: Chris Z
Reviews.Content: Ive stayed here three times twice for work and recently with my family. The reviews I've read are mixed and for the most part accurate there are very good points to this hotel and some bad ones. THE GOOD The view is incredible and our room at the marina was clean and comfortable. The waterpark is a lot of fun for the kids (ages 11 and 13) and for me as well. The main pool up top is a typical big resort pool with swim up bar and a nice water volleyball pool. There are plenty of lounge chairs at both and friendly staff. The beach is a 30minute trip each way counting wait time but is a nice beach with plenty of trees for shade and decent snorkeling just off the beach. We scuba dived and the staff was friendly and competent. They have an ice cream shop at the main resort that was great for the kids and plenty of little tourist shops that cover anything you forget and make it easy to get gifts. The workout facility in the spa is top notch bit ironically the only place the staff isn't friendly. Overall the staff is solid to good. THE NOT SO GOOD The restaurants are way over priced even for a resort. My wife and the kids and i split two entrees and had two appetizers my wife and I had two beers each and the bill was $260 enough said. The vehicular which connects the main resort to the water park/ marina etc.,. breaks way too often. On two of my three trips it's been down and it's a major hassle. They charge to use the water park, there is a $38 per day resort fee and on checkout there where things on my bill that were not mine. At the beach it costs $15 per person for mask and fins and the worker left it closed for 45 minutes with an " out to lunch" sign. RECOMMENDATIONS Rent a car from enterprise and park it for free in their lot (otherwise its another $20 per day to park) and go to one of five or six restaurants within 5 minutes that are pretty good and while not cheap cost $90 to $125 for dinner for four with two people getting a couple drinks each. Get a room in the marina that way you are near the waterpark and transport to the beach. Buy a case of beer/ water and soft drinks on your way there or be prepared to pay another $50 a day for incidentals. This trip costs me a thousand per day with airfare so I wasn't trying to be cheap but I also saw no need to spend another $200 per day on dinner/ beer and soft drinks. My family loved the trip and we will go back so it was worth it. Note if your a Hilton honors member you get free upgrades ( thanks Patricia at the front desk we loved our room) as well as free access to the spa's workout room and expediated check in.

Reviews.Title: “Expensive and Old”
Reviews.Author: kijoda
Reviews.Content: The hotel was supposed to be a perfect getaway and it turned out to be the opulence of 80's old style hotel rooms, impossibly horrible food and worst of all expensive. My first night at the hotel they put us in the oldest part of the hotel unrenovated and built in the 60's. With my children I was frustrated by the service and was told by the person who checked me in that they were filled above capacity and I get what I get basically. I threatened to leave the hotel and call my credit card company to dispute the charges as it was the room was not what I paid for and they changed me to an 80's style room. That was better but OMG the bathroom was sooo outdated. I had so many problem rooms keys didnt work, $70+ for every meal including breakfast. And every 1 out of 3 hotel workers were rude. I finally got a car to bring down the costs for food and I also felt isolated by the location since I could not walk anywhere near the hotel and found this was the best way to really enjoy PR without spending another $1500 to eat which is what I would of spent for me and my 2 9 year olds. The service is soo subpar, no waiter service or bar service by all the pools and they use some kind of trolley to get up and down the mass resort which breaks down every 24hrs while packing 20 pp in a trolley at time a time like sardines. The only good part of the hotel is that it is in a beautiful location, it has lots of little shops, wifi all over the property, and a variety of restaurants (since there is no way to get around by a car) to help ease the tension of feeling as if you are on a deserted island. They also have a beautiful island called Palomino where you can take advantage of the water sports and beach (no beach on the main property major bummer!) the only problem you have to take a ferry that only runs from 9-5:30p missed that boat and you are literally stranded on a desert island. Unfortunately the beach is not that big so you really have to find a place to stretch out. But it was better than nothing. Also some but not all the staff were nice but that doesnt make up for my feeling absolutely swindled by this resort and the price I paid for a supposedly 4 star hotel. Its about a 21/2 star hotel with really bad service, food and hotel rooms are horrible.

Reviews.Title: “Masquerading as a Waldorf”
Reviews.Author: gllove_12
Reviews.Content: When you think of a Waldorf property you expect the best of the best, high quality food, service and ammenities. This hotel lacks all three. The hotel used to be Wyndham and that is what it should be, or even better a Hilton. Rent a car in San Juan and drive to the resort, when you get to Fajardo you have no clue that the resort even exists as you drive through a neighborhood. Once you are at the hotel property you feel safe and shelterd from the outside world of Fajardo. We stayed in a 2 bedroom at the Las Casitas which are more like apartments adjacent to the main hotel which is a 5 minute walk. We spent most of our time at the El Conquistador which is the central hub for all activities. The hotel needs a major facelift and updates. The main pool looks like it is still from the 1960's, the cabana's are an embarassement and very outdated. If you are going to associate the Waldorf name to the hotel then it needs to be Waldorf quality which the main pool is not. The Las Casitas main pool is newer and looks over a cliff and has a negative edge pool which is exclusive for only people staying at Las Casitas. The main lobby of the hotel is not bad, the best things about it are a Starbucks Coffee shop (slow service) and the ice cream shop for the kids. The Caribe restaurant is horrible, not owned by the hotel, poor food, poor service and very expensive. The Strip House upstairs was the best restaurant we ate at and this is what you would expect from a Waldorf property, only if everything else would emulate the Strip House at the resort. It is a long walk to the tram to take you down the hilll to the water park and the boat to Palomino Island. There is no beach on the hotel site, you need to take the boat to Palomino Island, actually it was a relaxed environment, the beach was nice, water good. You need to pay for everything once you are there, snorkel equipment, horseback riding, jet skiing, etc...it adds up. The waterpark has 3 slides and a lazy river. I was very upset when I had to pay to use the waterpark for my family of 5. It was almost a $100, eventhough I am a hotel guest paying over $600 for a two bedroom casita, I though it was very tacky. I have stayed at the Waldorf in Maui (Grand Wailea) and they do not charge for the slides and niether does Atlantis. The tram broke down on several occassions and we had to wait to get back to the top of the resort which was very annoying. The capacity on the two cars is limited compared to the size of the hotel, I suggested that they build some stairs to the top, I would walk them everytime. When I checked out, there was a 14% resort fee charged per day, I was shocked and upset and told the manager the most I have ever paid at a resort was $25, this is highway robbery. I do not like being taken advantage of especially when they charge you to use the water park and nickel and dime you for everything else. The best deal at the resort is the Starbucks. A few more things, the pizza at the restaurant by the pool is horrible, it tasted like frozen pizza you buy at the store. They really need to improve the food quality for what they charge if the hotel is going to be called a Waldorf property. Something that stood out, when you go to a high end resort in the tropics you expect tropical fruits, etc...so I want to order a bananc smoothine and I asked if they use real bananas for the drink and they said not we use a syrup mix, that was a big turn off right there. The resort is good for kids, a lot of activities and entertainment for them, but don't expect a Waldorf experience. I will not go back I would rather go to the Grand Wailea again, much better food, service and ammenities.

Reviews.Title: “Great location with views of mountain and sea”
Reviews.Author: Bullies65
Reviews.Content: This hotel is lovely - only negative is you have to pay for the water park which is unexpected. The Infinity pool in the park is lovely and the kids had a ball on the slides and lazy river. The funicular to the ferry which takes you down to the marina has lovely views and the ferry to palomino island (the only beach) is regular. I would have preferred a beach I could walk too but otherwise loved the place. Also was very reasonably priced

Reviews.Title: “When a Waldorf is not a Waldorf”
Reviews.Author: aremk
Reviews.Content: I really want to give this property 3 or 4 stars, but I just cant. There are too many things wrong with it, and if it wasn't marketed as a Walford maybe I could. There are some positives: - the property is really nice. Great views, nice public areas. - nice pools. plenty of pool towels (i hate resorts that make you feel like a crook when it comes to asking for pool towels). - water park is very nice -- clean and fun. - the restuarants are great -- yes, expensive but no more so than NYC prices. Good burgers by the pool (Virgin Burger). Great Steaks at the Strip House and Great Fish and Wine at Stingrays. The service at all the places was very good. Now, the downsides: - the interior is a dump -- putting it mildly. We had a leak from the ceiling. I tried calling for repair, but our room phone didnt work. A quick call on my cell and the leak was fixed but a mess was left behind. I thought, no biggie -- we'll call housekeeping --- but the problem was our room phone still didnt work....followed by our patio door being stuck on the open position...etc, etc. - the furnishings were scratched, torn, stained, etc. - maid service was unreliable. Called for evening turndown service each night (once they fixed the phone) -- zero for five on that front. - the funicular + ferry to private island gets old really fast. The first day its fun. But, as soon as one funicular breaks (which happened) and one ferry doesnt show for 45 minutes (which also happened), it becomes a nightmare. Long lines without the protection of shade isnt fun. - Wifi doenst work. Even though they tell you there is no problem and that no one else complained, everyone we asked said the same thing. (They are very quick to collect the 14pct "resort" fee which includes the wifi and funiculsr/ferry service, but not so quick to provide reliability in these paid-for services) - front desk service which is indifferent and has no regards for guests. Did we have a good time? Yes. Would we return? Probably not. Its great for kids to about age 15 or so as its pretty self-contained and a lot going on. I cant imagine Waldorf keeping thier name on this property much longer unless they pour a lot of money into it. In her heyday she must have been quite a grand resort, but she's let herself go.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Hotel for Kids!!!”
Reviews.Author: lanzmo
Reviews.Content: We have been here before with our kids and it just keeps getting better!! There is so much to do for them. Our 8 year old said "Dad how many hotels have their own water park, a finicular, a private island WITH its own catamaran ferry that we can ride?" NOT MANY! They are in heaven here. Patricia checked us in and was amazing!! The property is lucky to have her!! Our room was great again as it was in the Las Brisas tower. We were in room 3432 which overlooked the Marina and water park. We also had a view on Palomino Island(the private island) and on a clear day we could see all the way to Vieques Island. This year all the nicer restaurants on property were better than last year which when staying on property and eating with our kids was a nice surprise. We had one minor issue with the Bio Bay tour that we booked through the concierge for my oldest son and I. My son had been looking forward the tour for the better part of the year....since our last trip. We booked it as soon as we got to the property and had received multiple confirmations from the concierge. On the evening that we were supposed to go we drove down to where we leave from and they initially didn't have our reservation and all of the sudden they had it but at a later time...NOT the one that was confirmed. We could not do the later time. My son was devistated to say the least. I had not seen him this upset in a long time...having looked forward to this for the better part of a year. We went back to the hotel and went to the concierge to voice our displeasure. We ended up speaking to BOTH Manny and Victor who promised they would do all they could to maybe get us on the tour the next day to which we said Great! It would make my sons day and most likely his trip! The next day he wanted me to keep going to the room to see if we got any messages. In the latter half of the day we got one and he was so excited! BUT to out avail it was only an automated apology for a fire alarm. I used to work in the hospitality industry. We all know where a lack of communication gets us BUT to say something and NOT follow through at all is rather pathetic. Maybe they thought my son being so upset and the mishap was just a joke but to us it was not. Their lack of a response says a lot about how much this issue meant to them and their professionalism as a whole. All they had to do was let us know that they could not do anything and I could have given my son an answer. We got nothing.

Reviews.Title: “Best service ever! Steve the Butler”
Reviews.Author: Lucy4521
Reviews.Content: Beautiful resort!!! Views were amazing and really good food. The best part was our butler, Steve. His attention to detail made our trip perfect. Do not go without Butler service.

Reviews.Title: “a Magical Family Resort”
Reviews.Author: Tom K
Reviews.Content: We returned to the El Con in late March after spending 5 glorious days there right after Christmas. Once again it did not disappoint. We stayed at the Marina, which is a different experience from staying in the main part of the hotel. However, once we got used to it it was great to be so close to the water park and the boat to Palomino Island. Our six year old daughter loved the water park and after dinner swims in the pool. My wife and I enjoyed relaxing at the beach on the beautiful Palomino Island. We had two terrific meals at the Strip House and Piccolo. Best of all, the service is fantastic. We were treated like celebrities throughout our stay - our daughter was treated like a princess. She even became friends with Rosie O'Donnell, who was staying at the resort. Keyla, the VIP Services Manager, is an absolute delight and will ensure that your family has a great time.

Reviews.Title: “Kids Had a Blast!”
Reviews.Author: So_worth_it_12
Reviews.Content: Perfect place for kids to never be bored! I have a 6 and 8 year old who soaked up everything the El Con had to offer: pools, waterpark, the beach, the wristband scavenger hunt, the game rooms, the bands, and so on! The trip was for them so my husband and I did not worry too much about what we wanted to do this trip. We did get to relax at the waterpark as the boys ran around and around the lazy river finding little friends to play with......also at Palamino Beach when they snorkeled and found shells. The cost for meals, drinks, and stuff is not that outragious when you compare it to other resorts such as this. The cocktails are a bit weak at the pools, however. We stayed in the Las Brisas room which was in the middle of everything so was very convenient to go either direction of the resort. The funicular (both) ran fine. The rooms were a definetly "used". The bathroom was very large so that was a bonus! I really liked the made service at night (this is in addition to them cleaning your room during the day). Always a new set of towels and garbages emptied while we were ar dinner so we had clean towels for the morning! Overall, this was a great family trip that the kids will remember forever.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful views but okay food”
Reviews.Author: MelissaHipskind
Reviews.Content: We visited this resort the first week of April. Beautiful, beautiful views. Our rooms were in the Las Brisas section overlooking the marina. Our room was very comfortable and modern. However, the air conditioner didn't work properly and we ended our stay with a very humid room. The Palomino Island was very nice. Our kids were able to snorkel and found lots of conch shells. We rented a kayak and paddled over to Palominto Island - where they filmed the last part of Pirates of the Caribbean, I'm told. That was awesome! The sand was very rough but the scenery made up for it! The food at the resort was nothing to write home about. I thought the prices were excessive (e.g. we bought 4 juice based non-alcoholic drinks - $24) but we were at a resort. The golf course was beautiful, although we did not play. They had a program for the kids that encouraged them to explore the resort for wrist bands. They enjoyed the challenge and it gave us the opportunity to explore the resort. The pools were nice and well maintained. Overall, we had a great time and made lots of family memories!

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic stay with toddlers, but very pricey!”
Reviews.Author: brianwon
Reviews.Content: We arrived a few hours before check-in due to the poor weather in PR that day. We had initially planned to spend the day in Old San Juan and then drive to the El Conquistador resort right around check-in (4). We called ahead and the folks there told us to come on by, register and partake in the amenities while we wait for the room. Thankfully, the room was ready right when we arrived! After a turbulent flight with 3 and 5 yr olds, there was nothing better than entering our own private room then off to the pools! We had acquired a Las Brisas Ocean View room, as this was the most recommended by other travelers here on tripadvisor, and let me tell you, it did not disappoint! Our room was close to everything! The funicular was one floor down and the casino/restaurants/front desk was all on premises. The main pool was here too! Palomino Island - is a beautiful island, private and only accessible via ferry. The lines for the ferry can be very long, especially after 11a, but if you're on one of the late ferries, your day at the beach won't be as good. Try to get out on the 10a ferry. That way you can find a set of chairs under palm trees. The umbrellas are $11/ea, but you do get them the entire day. The cabanas are $20, but you can only squeeze two chairs underneath, and there's no breeze. The shaded spots under the trees are definitely the way to go. If you want water sports, you'll have to arrive early and reserve. Jet skis and 3 man kayaks seemed to have long lists. El Coqui Water park - fantastic time with the kids! The zero entry pool and baby slide is perfect for those kids who arenâ€™t tall enough to play on the bigger slides or go to the deep end (3'6"). Only gripes I have with this place are that they charge hotel guests - something I thought they didnâ€™t do, and it appears that they let non-hotel guests enter. The place got really crowded and rowdy. It was so rowdy and inappropriate for toddlers, that by 2pm we left. Camp Coqui - My kids loved the night camp while mom and dad went out and enjoyed a quiet dinner at the strip house. Even though we're back home, my kids still plead to go back to Camp Coqui. Now for the not-so-nice stuff. They charge for EVERYTHING. Fridge? $20/night. Valet? $20/day. Water Park? $80 for a family of four. The prices for food and drinks are also very expensive. $17 for a bowl of cereal via room service, or $7 if you want to eat it in the restaurant downstairs. They give you these charge cards and if you're not careful you'll easily ring up thousands of dollars in charges like we did over our 5 day stay. Everything from overpriced sun block, to a $400 dinner at Stingray, to $500 in drinks for 2 for 5 days!! Obviously, we splurged. So my tips to have a great time at El Conquistador are to do the following: - Splurge on the Las Brisas room - Purchase your own alcohol at one of the various shops on the way to the resort - While renting a car may sound cheaper than paying for the bus transfer, after everything it really isnâ€™t. If you wish to explore the area, take cabs. - Eat at La Estacion. It's a stones throw from the entry gate. IT opens at 5, and you'll need a reservation if youâ€™re not there early enough. The ribs are fantastic, as is the whole red snapper - Take a cab to the bioluminescent bay; it's the same bay you can see from your window if youâ€™re staying on the north side of Las Brisas. There are a bunch of waterfront places to grab snacks and beer. - The water park is good, but Palomino Island is better and free - Bring water-shoes for Palomino Island. The coral/rocks are sharp and abundant. - Buy your supplies at Walgreens on RT 3 rather than packing it or buying it on the resort - water, milk, sun block, booze, snacks, etc - DO NOT FLY AMERICAN AIRLINES, or Delta. They both charge you for checked bags! AA's staff were rude and the seats were uncomfortable. And some things we were worried about after reading some of the reviews here which didn't pan out are: - The funicular isn't really that bad. The express side takes you up and down in a couple minutes. It's also air-conditioned. - The local town is pretty run down and not easy to get around if you don't have a car or have a taxi waiting for you - While PR is a US territory, the further you get away from the larger cities, the less english people tend to speak. In conclusion, we had a great time! But we would probably not be going back again. The 1hour drive from San Juan, coupled with cost of everything didn't seem worth it. If we are to go back to PR again, it'll be for the port on our way to a cruise. For the price we paid for everything on this vacation, we could've easily had a suite on a 7 night Caribbean cruise!

Reviews.Title: “destination wedding”
Reviews.Author: c t
Reviews.Content: I just watched a video of a family wedding I attended on nov 12 2011.We had a group of 90 people!! Some stayed at the casitas and some regular rooms. It was so much fun!! The most beautiful backdrop for a wedding ever! And a beautiful bride!!! The area for the ceremony was so pretty my sister bought paintings and gave them as gifts.The food,room,lighting music and cake all great! There was a wedding planner Yahira Hernandez who made sure everything went well.This is a nice place to have a destination wedding no passports needed!! Also rehersal dinner at the italian restaurant the night before {for all guests} was delicious. Palomino island was a bonus.

Reviews.Title: “Not a Five Star, but good”
Reviews.Author: Randy C
Reviews.Content: We arrived late for this time zone, we checked in and ate at the Steak House. Wonderful meal, wonderful drinks,and resturant staff fantastic, lot of fun and good service. We were here for a convention, so the review is a bit skewed since we did not have ample time to lounge around. The rooms well to say the least old!, but liveable. The staff not the best at working around our schedule. We called for room clean up and hours later had to call again, this was in the morning around 10:00 a.m. I sent a shirt out to be laundered on Monday A.M. for Tuesday night, we had to keep calling to ensure we would get the shirt back. Had we not kept calling, I probalbly would still not have the shirt. Golf course good, but a bit on the high side, The Casino looked like fun, but we did not have to use it. The private island was good as we had a private party with the group one night. The Font desk staff, did not want to check us out, unless we went back to our room to get the keys we left on the desk to check out, of course this would mean we would miss our transportation to the airport. If we go back to Puerto Rico, I will be checking on other accomodations. Who knows maybe this is the best they have to offer.

Reviews.Title: “Downhill”
Reviews.Author: rvbolorin
Reviews.Content: I have stayed at El Conquistador about 8 times in the last 15 years. In the last 2-3 occasions the experiences have been average at most. I booked just 2 nights,prior to a honeymoon trip. Resort is beautiful, the private island Palomino is also beautiful, restaurants are expensive but good food. The problem is that there are so many people and they are not ready. Getting a table for breakfast was more than 1 hour wait. After breakfast, getting the funicular and the boat to Palomino was another 1 hour wait. This happened every single day. Who wants to spend "vacation" time waiting? This is not Disney. We are locals and I don' t think we will come back.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful setting, nice rooms, very friendly staff, average food...”
Reviews.Author: Tedkid
Reviews.Content: This was my second visit to the El Conquistador Resort. The rooms are nice with an incredible view. My room was clean and well maintained. The resort has an older feel that is not really nostalgic and 'almost' dated. The bathroom was spacious with a separate dressing / closet area. The shower / tub is a step-down affair with good water pressure (the tub is tiny) and plenty of hot water. Wifi was free but seemed slow. The property is in very good condition. Everywhere I walked I was greeted by the staff with a friendly hello. The most disappointing part of the resort was the food. The only restaurants I ate at was the outdoor restaurant next to the lobby and the Caribe Cafe. Both are average with a limited, expensive menu. There is a steak house onsite but looks very expensive. I was attending a business meeting and the catered meals were 'above average' for large meal hotel catering.

Reviews.Title: “A Waldorf Astoria resort (Not)”
Reviews.Author: highmain
Reviews.Content: You see those signs around everywhere - but it's hard to see the luxury you would expect from the Waldorf Astoria. Just came back from a four day stay at El Conquistador, and this is not any more than a three star hotel at 5 star prices. Stayed in Las Brisas before (which was new 5 years ago -when we went before), but it's not new now. Carpet desparately needs to be replaced, and definitely get a room on the 3rd floor or above. Everything else is partway below ground and smells musty - even if you have a balcony with a partial ocean view. The bathrooms need recaulking and a good cleaning. The beds were ok and housekeeping did the best they could to keep up. We got the meal plan which included breakfast and dinner - couldn't tell if it was a good deal or not - but it worked ok for us. Palomino Island was great, however it was somewhat of a pain that the ferries stop taking people ove to the island at 3:00. Don't go to the waterpark if you have kids over 11 or so - we went for a couple of hours at the end of the day and my kids (ages 11, 14 and 15) were bored. Ate at the steakhouse - The Strip House - the food was excellent there, however it is decorated so distastefully that one might dismiss this restaurant as a choice. The Italian restaurant was great, good food, and good service, and Blossoms was just average - nothing spectacular. Would not go there again..

Reviews.Title: “A great family experience”
Reviews.Author: Josh B
Reviews.Content: We spent 5 nights here, with an 8 year old and a 5 year old. It was great. First off, like all the other reviews note, the property location and views are fantastic. Perched on a the cliff, one can see Vieques, a string of other islands and water water everywhere. Let's start with the rooms. They were spacious, clean and well-tended. The "turn down" service was a nice touch. The bathrooms and walk-in closet were good. (We wish the door to the closet was off of the room and not the bathroom, but that's a minor point.) We had a room overlooking the water and that was spectacular. (The balcony railing was high enough that we didn't worry about the kids.) We were relatively close to the funicular (see below), and that meant we could hear the cars coming up and down. That wasn't ideal, but it actually didn't disturb us. I could see it bothering a light sleeper, though. I won't repeat what lots have writen, but there is no beach there, one has to take the ferry to a private island. And to get to the ferry, we had to take the funicular down the hill. If you are in a rush, it's not ideal. If the journey is part of the experience, then it's fun. We went to/from the island on 3 different days and loved the boat and the ride (just 15 mins). Ferry runs allegedly every hour, but it seems to go more frequently. Both of the funiculars worked the entire time (except one morning one was out of service). The longest wait we ever had was 5 minutes. The island (Palomina) is great. Basically its own beach resort. Hundreds of chairs. (never a problem). Horseback riding (both kids did it and loved it.). Kakays and snorkeling rentals. Water is very warm and very shallow. Soccer field. Basketball court. Several bars. Low-key outdoor food spot (surprisingly not shockingly overpriced -- kids burger and hotdog around $6. Adult sandwiches and salads between $10-14. Drinks weren't crazy.) Mini-golf. Horseshoes. Basically, you could go to the island at 9 am and be there until 5 and have LOTS to do. Back at the resport, there are several pools. Nothing fancy or special. Three hottubs, all good. Poolside bars, never waited for a drink. There are a number of restaurants on site. We ate at the hibatchi one, the fish one by the marina and the italian one. They were more expensive than the norm, for sure, but definitely not unreasonably crazy overpriced. We never did the buffet or big breakfast, we just got oatmeal or a breakfast sandwich from Stabucks. Food was fine, nothing special. ALWAYS kids options, which was very nice. And the wait staff were pleasant and we always could get a seat. The casino was small -- there are 1cent slot machines which was funny. There are 2 arcades for the kids. There were lots of shops, and stores at multiple levels. Ultimately one never had to leave the premises. BUT WE DID. And, frankly, the best part of our visit were the off-site trips we took. First, we went to the Rain Forest (El Yunque). It happened to be pouring when we went, but it was still fun. We had rented a car, so we drove ourselves and did it solo (didn't go through the hotel or tour). It couldn't have been easier. The drive to the Rain Forest is 25 minutes from the hotel. We stopped at the visitors center and got maps and saw a little movie, all worth it. The driving through the forest is windy, but very easy. Don't picture a difficult drive, rather just a slower windy drive. We stopped along the way for pictures. We did a 2 hour hike to Britton Tower in the rain, which was not particularly challenging but great for the kids. BUT YOU MUST STOP AND EAT AT THE LOCAL DIVE JOINT AT THE 7km mark. It looks sketchy, but the food was divine and authentic and local! No joke, best meal we had. Even the kids thought it was great. One night we did the 8:30 pm kayak trip of the bio luminescent bay. We did not do the hotel tour, but instead had the concierge arrange it through "Kayak Rentals". These tours leave about 10 minutes from the hotel, so VERY EASY to get there (our car; but could easily have cabbed or they will pick you up). It cost $45 per person and lasted 2 hours. It was amazing. Truly. It was pitch black,except for the water, which lit up the entire time. Our guides knew enough to educate us, but it was more about the unique experience. Again, our young kids loved it and wanted to return the next night. We ate dinner down by the water at EL RACAR, another local joint that was excellent. (The following night we ate at a local joint called Popeyes -- think sailor, not fried chicken -- which wasn't as good and the service was terrible.) Both of these are authentic, local food. Outdoor seating only. A handful of tables. Definitely not fancy. But good grub and a great alternative from the hotel. We highly recommend this property and the activities. In many ways, it was the perfect mix of "active vacation" plus "beach resort" plus local touch.

Reviews.Title: “Waldorf Astoria? Really?!”
Reviews.Author: TravelHound_12
Reviews.Content: This hotel has been around for ages and looks like it. It's a beautiful piece of property, and the grounds are lovely. But the hotel itself is in dire need of renovation and upgrading! I had visited El Conquistador years ago for dinner (while staying at the Westin Rio Mar, which I would recommend well over this place!), and the property interested me enough to want to come back. So, when I heard that the hotel had been bought by Waldorf Astoria, I thought it was the perfect time to stay at El Conquistador. Well, let me tell you...it's no Waldorf Astoria! If the parent company has put a dime into the hotel, it doesn't show. The furniture in the lobby looks like mismatched pieces from your grandmother's attic; the hotel annexes, which were added on in the 50s and 60s, are straight out of "Mad Men" and, at the very least, need to be re-stuccoed to cover the wear and tear of the past fifty years; the guest rooms, while quite spacious, are in desperate need of redecorating. Basically, it looks as if the Waldorf merely added a little paint and some new carpeting and called it a day. The hotel needs a $20 million makeover for sure! And let's not forget the service...or lack there of. Forget having anyone come around to bring you a drink at the pool. Ha! There was no pool or beach service at all. And towels were almost impossible to find. At a Waldorf, I would have expected towels laid out on every chair and servers circulating with drink orders. Isn't that how resorts make their money? And speaking of beach chairs, the chaises at the beach were abominable! Old, uncomfortable plastic mesh chairs, many of which were broken. Oh, I could go on. The only thing that was consistent with the Waldorf name was the cost, especially for the food (which was truly mediocre and exhorbitantly overpriced).
