The drink service on the beach was also nice. We were suprised to see bunnies on the beach - they were very cute and one napped under my chair the entire time! Activites - Biobay is a close walk. Do NOT book through the hotel. For some reason, they charge a lot more. You can walk down to the marina and book directly with the kayak companies for $20-$30 cheaper. The bay does get crowded and its hard to navigate in the dark, so you are constantly bumping into other kayaks on the way in and out of the bay - but its well worth the trip. Coolest thing I've seen. I would also take a trip to the rainforest. We explored and hiked on our own rather than taking a tour. Pool - the pool was nice, but very crowded. There are two pools, but in the afternoon - they sometiems close one for private functions. Therefore, everyone is stuffed at one pool and chairs were hard to find. Word of caution - we rented a car at the airport and returned it at the resort. The resort rental guy said the car was missing a jack out of the trunk and tried to charge us for it. There was never a jack in the trunk, but the airport rental guy said it was there - after much negoitation, they decided not to charge us for it. Not sure if this is a one-time thing or a way for the rental car companies to make additional revenue. Service - I would say the service is mediocre for what most people pay to stay the resort. I am accustomed to very friendly staff going out of their way to serve you - however, we often had to wait to get served at many places. Overall, it was a beautiful resort - but too expensive for what you get. I would definitely go back to Puerto Rico, but stay somewhere else. I would, however, recommend to friends looking for a high-end, nice resort.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful setting with so-so service”
Reviews.Author: holiday_routine
Reviews.Content: My family and I went to this resort for Thanksgiving break 2009 because I had a gazillion Hilton Honors points and the kids wanted to go someplace warm. This hotel falls under the Hilton chain. I started to make the reservation online but had questions about water park and golf packages so I called the hotel directly. Despite the computer telling me the resort was available,the reservations agent was telling me they had no openings. To prove my point, while I was on the phone with the agent, I completed my reservation online and then gave him the confirmation number. He was less than graceful in acknowledging that his system obviously was not showing him all availability. And no he couldn't help me with an early check-in, no I could not get a water park discount with Hilton Honors points, no I couldn't get an upgraded room, despite being a HHonors VIP. When I called Hilton Honors to let them know what happened, I got all kind of follow-up calls to apologize for the foregoing and got my questions answered, got the early checkin, etc. It turns out that we got two water park admissions with our package, but no one could tell me that ahead of time. The ocean view was magnificent and the hotel has a superb setting with a terrific golf course, although the course starter was borderline incompetent. We wanted to hit some balls and aside from the lady behind the cash register in the pro shop couldn't find anyone to get a bucket of balls from and had to walk around looking for someone. The starter didn't enforce starting times and instead just went to the driving range and started a mad rush by announcing that someone had to tee off. The hotel food was good but very expensive. We found wonderful food at wonderful prices in some of the nearby restaurants just off the hotel grounds. The hotel has several pools but apparently only offers poolside service by the lower pool with the private cabanas. We were by the pool for many hours and no one came by for drink orders, though they were scurrying around taking orders at the lower pool. The cleanliness of the pool area had a lot to be desired. There were numerous limes laying around on the pool deck in varying stages of decomposition as if some had been there for days. Some of the fountains by the pool looked very pretty from a distance with red flower petals on the surface, but when you got close you could see decomposing petals all over the bottom all brown and decaying like it had not been cleaned for some time. We thought the people were nice, the location beautiful, but this resort has a lot of unrealized potential. They need to reduce their food prices and improve the cleanliness of the pool area if they want to really achieve a four star rating. Parking was very expensive, but I guess most of the high rollers there don't mind. The parking is also a separate business from the hotel and we had to go through a separate check out with them after checking out from the hotel. I can't see this hotel being rated any higher than 3 stars because of the lack of pool service and poor cleanliness.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Place, Nicely Renovated, Great New Waterpark, but EXPENSIVE for the level of service provided”
Reviews.Author: D0ct0r_L
Reviews.Content: We returned to visit the El Conquistador (last there in 1995), this time with kids. The grandeur of the place is beautifully maintained, and the rooms are newly renovated - modern and sleek, but the bustling crowds of the 90's missing. The front desk staff upgraded us to Las Brisas section when we arrived because the section of the hotel that we booked (Las Olas) was not being opened due to low occupancy. While the hallways in Las Brisas were a little "worn", the rooms were nicely decorated, with comfy beds and feather pillows, large bathrooms, and fantastic ocean views. The restaurants serve mostly fantastic food, but were very expensive ($30+ entrees). The service was usually good, but horrible one night when festival was going on in downtown San Juan, and they once tried to subsitute Tilapia for Sea Bass thinking we wouldn't now the difference? Overall, I felt the service definitely was not as good as it was when we visited 15 years ago. There is a 14% nightly "resort tax" supposedly for the ferry to Palomino Island and the funicular, etc. But that in combo with other taxes, 18% gratuity for all meals given we had party of 6, daily cost for Water Park and expensive food made the trip overall expensive ($1250 per night for two rooms and 3 adults, 3 kids eating 2 meals per day). The grounds at the hotel and the views are gorgeous. Palomino Island seemed a little "junked up" with old lounge chairs piled in visible areas, etc, and you had to find staff to get you a drink, but kids loved snorkeling and kayaking (had to pay for that, too.) and the views and water were picture perfect.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice grounds, service is average, very expensive”
Reviews.Author: BarbiBooS
Reviews.Content: We stayed in December 2009 with our 9 and 13 year old daughters Beach- There is no beach on the grounds. You must take the ferry to the private island, which is gorgeous. The ferry only traveled on the hour when we were there, which did get a bit tiresome. There is some nice snorkeling of the tip of the island Water Park- Has only 3 slides, but they are nice, and infinity pool, a zero depth pool. I would not pay $80 out of pocket for a family of 4 for this. Ours was included in a package Rooms-were not fantastic,but reasonably sized with nice big bathrooms, very celan, beds were comfortable Grounds were really pretty, well maintained Restaurants-very expensive. Chicken nuggets for the kids, a hamburger and a plate of chicken with 2 waters, a beer and a lemonade was $75. We figured we would go to the nice restaurants (which were quite good) and get real food with wine for $150. There are some decent restaurants not too far if you have a car Service-was good in restaurants, otherwise forget it Location is great-go to the phospohrescent bay, you will not regret it. Our whole family loved it. There is not a lot of shopping near here. The rain forest is also less than a half hour away

Reviews.Title: “Great vacation for all ages”
Reviews.Author: notfrequentflier
Reviews.Content: We recently booked a two bedroom villa in the Las Casitas part of this resort. We have two older children, 18 and 21, and one toddler, 2 years old. We needed someplace that gave us flexibility for the older kids, but enough freedom to keep the little one busy and safe. The resort is about 45 minutes from the airport. We rented a minivan from Enterprise (which is not on site at the airport, which was a little inconvenient). The ride was not too difficult, and we were able to use the navigation on our cell phones. We stayed from Sunday to Friday. The villa was exceptionally clean (I'm extremely picky). The maid service was attentive but unobtrusive. The decor was modern/zen with neutral colors and tile floors. The resort has enough restaurants to keep you from getting bored. The restaurants are not cheap, but the food is decent. The seafood restaurant seemed to be the best food of them all. The brick oven pizzeria was also great, but be sure to see if they are actually using the brick oven. The second time we went to get pizza, they didn't and it wasn't as good. The Japanese "hibachi" was as expected: the kids enjoy this, but the food is mediocre at best. The hamburgers and sandwiches at the restaurant on the water level near the ferry were very good; we returned there for a casual dinner our last night. The villa we rented had a good sized kitchen with full sized refrigerator. We stopped on our way and got some breakfast food for the little one, and some snacks to keep around for everyone. It was nice to have the refrigerator for juice and milk. There is a coffee machine with coffee provided. We had to ask for more coffee once we used the first packets. The villa also had two flat screen tv's, both with dvd players. The pools were clean, but not too warm. The weather was in the upper 70s/low 80s. Going to the beach is a little bit of a hassle with a young child, as you have to take the funicular down to the water level, and then take the resort ferry over to their private island. Once there, it is very nice. The beach is not so great: the sand has a lot of coral, as does the water. There is a restaurant there, and there is also a little shop to purchase any beach items you forgot. The ferry runs every thirty minutes. It was a nice change of pace for our older girls, who went to the beach several times. We did not do the water park, as the big girls weren't interested, and it seemed to be a waste of money for the little one. For kids 5-mid teens I'm sure it would be great fun. There is a casino in the main part of the resort. My husband and the older girls went every evening for something to do. The nightclub was not open while we were there, since we came midweek. Overall, it was a lovely vacation. It was perfect for our needs.

Reviews.Title: “Mixed feelings..”
Reviews.Author: mrmrsddas731
Reviews.Content: My husband and I went on our honeymoon in PR this past summer and this hotel was our first stop. Given that its part of the Waldorf Astoria collection and all, we were expecting a little more as far as service and room quality was concerned. First off, check in took about 45 mins as there was a long line at the counter but when we finally reached the counter the staff helping us was very knowledgeable. They even gave us an â€œupgradeâ€� as we were on our honeymoon. When we get to the room, we were wowed by the view but not by the room. The mini fridge in our room wasnâ€™t working and we had to wait about 2 Â½ hrs to get them to replace it by then all my ice cream had melted away into oblivion ï�Œ and the bathroom door wouldnâ€™t close completely so that was a bit of an inconvenience. But overall I was satisfied with the location of the room, and the resort itself. I loved our day trip to the island that is owned by the resort, its beautiful and you can spend pretty much all day thereâ€¦the resort itself is huge so I would definitely suggest taking the time to explore it and enjoy all the pools and the beautiful viewsâ€¦.There is definitely room for improvement at this resort as far the quality of service is concerned but I would still recommend this placeâ€¦

Reviews.Title: “Fun in the Fajardo Sun”
Reviews.Author: pfg07
Reviews.Content: My wife and I went to the El Conquistador for a six day vacation in January 2010. Overall, the trip met our expectations and we were quite satisified. Highlights of our trip: 1. Palomino beach: It was nice being able to relax on this beautiful island. The water was obviously warm and great for swimming. It was disappointing that we paid a resort fee though (almost $50 per day) and then had to rent things like kayaks on the island. Also, the food is expensive on the island - if you can, would bring your own food. 2. View from the hotel: We had a view of where the Atlantic meets the Carribean - truly spectacular with wonderful sunrises. 3. Kayaking Puerto Rico: Would recommend their tours to anyone. We need the Biobay which was the highlight of our trip but also did the rainforest tour - these guys are professional, educational and really nice. You need to do a tour with them if you are in Puerto Rico. 4. Hotel staff: From the bellstaff to the servers - everyone was really friendly. Things to look out for: 1. Check your bill. I had an extra $700.00 of charges on my bill from other folks. The staff fixed this fast for me - but had I not looked, I would have paid much more than I was supposed to. 2. Hotel restaurants: Pretty good (actually Blossoms is really good) but expensive. If you can go off resorts to eat, I would do so. Not because the food is bad (because it is not) but you can probably get more value for your money off the resort. Overall - a very good trip. My wife and I were concerned with some of the reviews - but overall, it was a great trip and we will come back to the resort.

Reviews.Title: “love this resort!”
Reviews.Author: elikar718
Reviews.Content: what not to love? nice rooms, nice resort, good food, private island....

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel, but they refuse to take care of the horses on their property”
Reviews.Author: bjbolton01
Reviews.Content: I throroughly enjoyed my stay until I saw the condition of the horses on their beach island. Many were without water, all of them were standing in their own manure up to their ankles that had not been cleaned in quite some time. Some were in need of medical attention, all of them could not move out of the heat and flies. The stables consist of a shack that is falling down with boards, nails, and garbage lying all around. It is not a safe environment for the horses, nor for the breeding of foals, nor for clients to visit. It was a horrible site for such a high-class hotel. The worst part is that there is no reason why the horses should be forced to live in such awful conditions. They are work horses, and should be treated with dignity as they are forced to help bring money into the hotel. They should be entitled to a nice barn to live in, with clean water to drink, a place to get out of the flies and heat, just as the visitors should enjoy happy steeds to ride, and a pleasant place to visit. I understand the horses do not belong to the hotel and the hotel wishes to ignore all requests to help the horses. However, that is no reason why El Conquistador should not put up appropriate stalls in a barn, a pasture for turnout at night, and enforce the proper care of the horses by the owner and caretakers. The hotel promotes the rides on the beach, and should not be encouraging rides on horses that are not fit to ride due to their dehabilitated state. If the hotel does not want to put up a proper facility for the horses, then I suggest that they get rid of them, tear down the dilapitated building for safety reasons and discontinue the horse rides altogether. I will be returning to lovely Puerto Rico at the end of March with my husband, however I will be spending my vacation dollars elsewhere this year. I refuse to promote a hotel that wishes to absolve themselves of all responsibility for the horses on their very own property.

Reviews.Title: “Not Impressive”
Reviews.Author: cdp73
Reviews.Content: It felt like a ghost town... go here if you want overpriced drinks, average poolside food and cold/lukewarm bath water. The private beach is nice, but it's a pain to catch the ferry which only leaves every hour.

Reviews.Title: “Stunning setting and fabulous setting outweigh disadvantages”
Reviews.Author: AnitaBrett
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a fantastic four day/five night vacation at the El Conquistador. I was very leery about going because of the mixed reviews here, but we went with the proper expectations and were thrilled with the results. There are lots of things you can do to ensure a great stay. But first, let me share with you, the good, the not so good, and the downright ugly. The good: - The "water park" is absolutely wonderful. There is a surcharge for it, and personally I'd budget for at least a half day pass every day. It is set right next to the ocean so it feels like being at the beach from a scenery standpoint. The park itself is immaculate, uncrowded, and has plenty of chairs and tubes. The water slides are a lot of fun. There's an easy one, a moderate one, and a scary one. My two boys (ages 11 and 14) loved the scary one the best. The lazy river is beautiful and relaxing. My only beef is that the chairs could be a tad more comfy, but otherwise I LOVED this area of the resort and could spend tons of time there. - The room. We had 3418 and 3419. I thought the rooms were great! We had a breathtaking, almost 180 degree vista of the ocean. The little patio is plenty roomy to sit out and have a drink. There is a TON of clothing storage compared to other hotel rooms I've stayed in. The bathrooms are very spacious. The bathtubs double as showers, but are cleverly sunken into the floor so that when you shower very little water gets spread around. They give you an awesome blowdryer that works FAST. There's a fridge and a makeup area - - just a very well laid out room. The finishes are a notch down from the marble and stuff you'd see at say a Ritz, but frankly, I think they were a lot more friendly for the cleaners to care for and practical. Our room was very clean. - The room rate. We asked for the triple AAA rate which was a significant discount, and no one ever asked us for our triple AAA card . . .so it seems to me that anyone could get this discount. - ice cream parlor/Starbucks - There is an ice cream parlor with Nestles ice cream and a Starbucks in the hotel - - both of which seemed very popular, and we really enjoyed them. - The staff. The staff was uniformly warm, friendly, and helpful with one exception (pool bartender at main pools). - The lap pool. The hotel has three main pools, and one of these is a full sized, beautiful lap pool with lanes. If you like to swim, you can easily get a lane in the morning, and it is beautiful watching the sun rise while you swim. I loved this pool! - The fitness center. I've seen a lot better/bigger/more luxurious fitness centers - - but I enjoyed running there anyway because the Lifefitness equipment was well maintained and state of the art. It probably could stand to be more air conditioned and bigger - - but the views are beautiful, and I still enjoyed working out there. - The golf. We didn't golf this trip, but we were sorry we didn't bring our clubs. The golf course looks breathtakingly beautiful. Probably hard too, but beautiful. The not-so-good: The island beach. As you've probably ascertained, you take a ferry to a private island if you want to go to the beach. The ferry ride is great - - about 15 minutes on a gorgeous catamaran with tons of seating. The island also has TONS of seating and palapas. The beach is pretty, and there is a good restaurant for food. But, the beach is also seated on a dead reef. The snorkeling is non existent as far as we could see. You can book a snorkeling excursion, but snorkeling right off the beach is awful. You definitely NEED water shoes as the bottom of the ocean has tons of dead coral. There aren't big waves at the beach so if you rent boogie boards, they are pretty much useless. The water is very warm and clean for swimming, but my boys were bored pretty quickly. You really had to rent expensive stuff in order to keep them occupied, and personally I'd prefer to hang out at the stunning water park. The computer system at the hotel is terrible. Whenever you go to buy something or get a new key or check in - - anything of that nature - - it seems to take an inordinate amount of time and a zillion key strokes. The drink prices are very high. Frankly, this was the only part of the pricing that I thought was out of line with other resorts. If you want a water or a Coke, you are going to spend too much money. Definitely recommend stocking up on water/Coke outside the hotel if you can. The food prices are high, but I think they are in line with food prices at other resorts. The ugly: The game room for the kids is a huge rip off. They give you one try for $0.50 on games where many locations give multiple tries. The room smelled strongly of vomit. It was just unappealing and a waste of money. DINING: We ate one night at the hotel and three nights outside: Strip House - Same pricing as any high end city steak house. Food was great - - especially do not miss their french fries which are giant spiced steak fries and very yummy. L'Estacion - Directions: Drive to bottom of El Conquistador driveway. Make a right. L'Estacion is no more than a half mile down the road on your left. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. Good food reasonably priced. Recommend the pinchas (skewers of meat) and the whole grilled fish (FABULOUS and accompanied by fried plantains that were yummy). Also, I really enjoyed the drinks here - - margarita and an awesome mojiito. The Blue Iguana - This is part of the Farajado Inn. It's kinda tricky to find. Drive down the driveway and make a left. Go straight until you reach Route 195 (right after you pass a big Burger King). Make a left onto 195 at the light. Now, keep your eyes peeled for a sign that reads HOTEL with an arrow pointed to the left. You want to take that left hand turn. It's one of the first lefts you can take. It takes you up a big hill to the Inn. The Blue Iguana has authentic Mexican food, and we really enjoyed it. Highlights were the salsa (order chips and salsa to get it) - - it is delicious! And the carnitas are outstanding!! Everything was quite good except the guacamole . . . The third place we tried was a tapas bar called Tasca Olelelolai. This was my least favorite restaurant in terms of the food, but there were definitely highlights - -like the paella! There were lots of fried items, so kids enjoyed it. Do not get the shrimp tempura. I should have asked more questions about the menu. The atmosphere was lovely though so worth a shot. It is very easy to pass this restaurants/get lost so I suggest asking the concierge for landmarks. The most visible sign faces the other direction from the hotel, and the restaurant is way up high in the building so if you aren't looking up, you'll cruise right by it. The sangria is yummy, but could use more alcohol. Other tips: Rent a car. If you go through Budget you will save enough money to pay for the convenient valet parking. Renting a car means you can buy drinks off property AND eat some dinners off property at a huge savings. The drive from the airport is long and confusing. GPS doesn't work well, but it did get us from the airport to the hotel. We brought our portable one from home. It took a good hour as there's quite a bit of traffic. If you have questions, please feel free to ask. All in all, I loved my vacation - - and won $170 at the blackjack table to boot :). The weather is just perfect balmy, breezy, comfortable, just perfect.

Reviews.Title: “Incredible views !!!!!!!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: MiamiBoriqua
Reviews.Content: The place was amazing, the people were wonderful, if i didn't work for a living i would go there at least 2 or 3 times a year

Reviews.Title: “Nice Place”
Reviews.Author: ShawnnellW
Reviews.Content: The place was beautiful. We had some issues with the room key and it was resolved. The service on Palimino Island was OK and could have been because we went in December. Of course everything at the resort was more expensive.

Reviews.Title: “worst hotel stay of my life”
Reviews.Author: zod28
Reviews.Content: stayed at the las casitas with friends. they charged us $50 per room per day for "maid service." we stayed in the casitas so we cooked; that meant we needed to pay to have them take out our garbage and replace the toilet paper. They also had a service for delivering food. The food came from a local gas station quick-mart (i know because I checked the receipt) and didn't include half the food we ordered or was just wrong. when we complained, the response was that the person I was complaining to wasn't the one that got the food! when it was time to leave we called for a bell hop to bring our bags to check out....never came...called again...never came...called a cab. when we looked over our bill we saw bogus charges from the water park. they said they'd take those off...never did...calling them a 3rd time on that...bottom line, just save your money and go elsewhere unless you just love feeling like an uninvited guest.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice. Not for everyone, but a great stay”
Reviews.Author: vballm22
Reviews.Content: I believe the Conquistador is a great hotel... for SOME people. I'd like to give a 5 star review but I have stayed at some really nice hotels and resorts. The Conquistador is unique and some people will love it and others will not. I'll attempt to break down for you my experience and hopefully it will help you make your decision. The first thing to note is that the hotel is not in San Juan. Fajardo is about 45 minutes away (excluding traffic) and on the eastern Shore of P.R. This is good and bad. It is good if you like to get away from it all. It is bad if you crave nightlife, which San Juan can provide. For me, I like to get away from it all so I enjoyed the remote location. Another major thing to note is that this hotel is not for people who are cheap. It is a remote location and yes, they will nickel and dime you a bit. More like dime and quarter you :) But I can forgive them for this since the room was reasonably priced compared to San Juan hotels and because it isn't close to anything. The hotel lobby is immense and immaculate. Checkin was a breeze (arrived after 11 PM) and service was excellent. The room itself was perfect. The king sized bed was extremely comfortable. The room was clean and had one of the largest bathrooms I've had in a normal room at a resort. Iphone docking station in the radio and flat-screen tv were a nice, modern touch. The location of your room is key as the resort is so large. If you have kids and plan on hitting the water park, ask for a room closer to that area. If you plan to head offsite or spend most of your time at the casino and restaurants, stick with the rooms closest to the main building. I visited the resort's private island on the first full day there. Talk to the front desk to find out what times the ferry runs. It could add some wait time to your trip out to Palomino. The snorkeling is just ok at Palomino although I can't say that I ventured too far around the island. They have a full range of water activities to do there but everything costs money (some resorts, the hobie cats and snorkel gear are free to borrow). Definitely a nice way to kill a day if you sunbathing is your thing. There are plenty of chairs and you don't need to bring towels as they give them to you there. The pool is very nice and since the hotel was dead when I was there, getting chairs. I only ate at the breakfast buffet (excellent), Starbucks, and Blossoms (pretty good teppanyaki, actually). Expect to pay 20-40% more. Something you must do if you stay at this hotel is visit Culebra. It is a very short taxi ride to the ferry and a 40 dollar cab ride to the airport where flights are just 35 dollars each way (15 minute flight versus a 2 hour ferry). Culebra had some of the best beaches I've seen and much better snorkeling than Palomino. Taxis on the island are SUPER cheap. If you like to fish, check with Captain Marcos at 787fishing@gmail.com. He put me on the first tarpon of my life (30 pounds). he launches from Puerto Chico which is pretty close to the resort. Checkout was smooth and the hotel didn't charge me anything unexpected. Parking is not cheap. Valet is 20 a day and self-park is 15. In and out privileges. Below are a few pros and cons: Pros Incredible views Very well maintained Private caribbean island with access to any/all water activities. Romantic Reasonable rates. Cons Far - Factor transportation into the price of your room when you compare Resort fee - I don't believe every hotel in P.R. charges this fee. You should factor this into your cost, as well. Enormous - Getting around takes some time Resort Food is pricey (25 bucks for the breakfast buffet, for example) and local food options are almost non-existant and are only reachable by car. No direct beach access. Must go to the private island for beach. * Also, while Las Casitas is technically listed in tripadvisor as a separate(and higher rated) hotel to book, it is actually 1, 2, and 3 bedroom condo units available for rent that are essentially on the same resort property. * I didn't hit the water park, but everything I heard about it was good

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful resort..rent a car to explore outside of the resort ! Gorgeous.”
Reviews.Author: ConnGal
Reviews.Content: We stayed here arriving noon on Tuesday, 11/24 left 5 am on Sat 11/28-A short time but we made the most of it---My husband & I had a nonstop flight from Newark NJ. We arrived in San Juan at noon hopped on the hotel shuttle bus and took the 50-60 minute trip to the resort. When we arrived, the staff checked us in and the process took under 5 minutes. We had a garden view room which looked over the tennis courts and golf course and in the distance the rain forest and the Atlantic Ocean. Beautiful view. We had a king size bed in our room. The rooms are European, cosmopolitan in design. Comfortable and CLEAN. The rooms have a hairdryer, and mini fridge. Good size room. We also had a nice terrace. At night we fell asleep to the sound of the coqui frogs chirping. We ate breakfast in Las Brisas. Good food, expensive though. The pools were very clean and we took the funicular to the marina to board the boat for the 7-10 minute ride to Palomino Island. Here are some recommendations so far in this review: 1-Study a map of Puerto Rico (roads etc). This is an island with good roads and signage, don't be afraid to drive it and get off of the resort (it's not Jamaica or Dominican or even Mexico). I would recommend renting a car at the airport and driving to the resort. There are some tricky turns, but if you are up for it give it a try. Otherwise, take the resort transportation and pay attention to the turns and the roads. We rented a car from Enterprise right in the resort, reserved before the trip. We DID NOT pay for parking since we parked in the Enterprise lot. Ask though. Use the car to drive off the resort into Fajardo, we gor breakfast in the morning from a VERY nice bakery, scrambled eggs, coffe and fresh squeezed OJ for 2 people UNDER $20 for the whole check. We went to the grocery store (nicer than the one here at home!) and got beer to stock the fridge and OJ and snacks. Grande or Amigos are good stores. Then we drove into downtown Fajardo, very quaint, we were there Friday after Thanksgiving in the morning. Everyone was so nice we shopped and took in the architecture. Got some nice sports t shirts for my nephews. On Thanksgiving day we ate at La Estacion right near the entrance to the resort. EXCELLENT food and the whole dinner (because it was special holiday fare) came to $25 pp. I was stuffed. One night we drove to old San Juan. I had made reservations at Marmalade (check out the review on TripAdvisor) UNBELIEVABLE the meal and the service and the food. Conde Nast lists this restaurant among the BEST and they are right. I could go on and on about the trip, BOTTOM LINE: Be prepared to pay resort prices--this is not all- inclusive, they have to make a profit SOMEWHERE so it's the food and drink, expect that. If you are used to being waited upon like at all-inclusive resorts in the poverty stricken islands, get over it here, the service is excellent but they don't always have their hands our for a tip after bringing you a drink, like at other resorts or on cruises. This is not some backwards place this is an American territory. This resort will appeal to folks who like to stay on a resort and don't mind paying the prices for that...however Fajardo is a great place to explore, if you are of that nature. This isn't a place where you can't eat certain things or can't drink the water..like I said, this is a clean place not a backwards territory. I would highly recommend renting a car though to take in the island and the local fare. People are so nice, local people. I'd be happy to be a resource to someone who has a question, I'm no big expert. I can't make sweeping judgements about those who have posted disenchanting things about this place, but I don't know how some have arrived at their conclusions. Like I said, this isn't an all-inclusive resort. I asked for a room that was a higher floor and quiet. Also, word to the wise; if you are nice to people they will be nice to you, treat others as you'd like to be treated. I'm a talker and like to get to know others, I have a hard time treating others like servants. This isn't the DR or Jamaica. The employees here take pride in their jobs and are for the most part very warm and personable. Talk to a bar tender, they are a MAsS of information about PR. Have a great time, I wish I were there now! For me and my husband, we are used to traveling and live outside of Philadelphia and New York City..I was SO pleased by our short vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Pay for more than you get...”
Reviews.Author: KamloopsBCPeter
Reviews.Content: Having had holidays in Maui, Fiji, Montreal and Sun Peaks Resort I'm no stranger to paying for my pleasures but El Conquistador sets a new standard for me. By charging $5.50 for a Medalla beer that cost 80 cents just outside the fence, this resort is doing business as if my money means nothing. Cabs are very expensive. and walking to a grocery store or restaurant is out of the question, as the hotel is situated on a coastal bluff behind the golf course. The golf course is a very effective buffer from the surrounding neighborhood, and it virtually imprisons a guest, leaving them no option but to pay inflated prices for average food/beverages. The staff are courteous and helpful although not all are bilingual. My Spanish is poor on every level and it would have been helpful to be more fluent. The main hotel is past it's prime. It's also clear the entire hotel was built with less than qualified craftsmen. For example, the floor in our suite was covered in a fairly nice carpet, but the concrete floor itself was far from level. One had to tread with care as the hollows and ridges created a tripping hazard for ladies in heels. The main entry door to the suite recently had a weather strip installed to prevent dust/geckos and such from coming in. Good thing too, the door wasn't installed particularly well. It wasn't plumb or square. This was representative of the entire resort although the more recent construction appeared to be of a better quality. The over-spray from our tub/shower flooded the lavatory every time someone had a shower. Again, this was a hazard as the floor became quite slick two or three times a day. The scuba from this resort is OK, but pretty expensive given the limited options. The water-park is actually REALLY GOOD! I could potentially spend a week just hanging around there. Palomino Island was OK, although the snorkeling was best on the opposite side of the island and it was a bit challenging to get to. The coral is suffering from too many nutrients, but it's not dead. There's a good variety of tropical fish/turtles etc. but the local scuba operator will get you to better sites. We did a snorkel/sail thing to some small islands to the north of the resort. They anchored quite a way from the reef to protect the coral. Although the visibility was poor because of all the recent rain, by swimming 20 minutes toward the break over the reef I found some very nice coral heads and lots of fish. Pay attention to your bills in the restaurants. Blossoms added a 15% gratuity and a blank space for an added tip; Pretty expensive if you don't catch it. Checkout was fairly straight forward, but again I suggest you review your bill the night before to ensure things like parking are treated appropriately. Some changes were needed on our bill. The golf course appeared to be pretty good for a tropical track. The rates were a little enthusiastic. A twilight rate (after 3:30 PM) of $150.00 plus $55.00 for rental clubs before taxes and supplies left me a bit cold when I figured I'd likely finish in the dark, if at all. There are better values in Puerto Rico. Spend a little time and I'm sure you will find an excellent resort with far more reasonable prices and far better quality.

Reviews.Title: “Great family trip, everyone wants to go back again.”
Reviews.Author: Westsox
Reviews.Content: This resort does not have the luxury associated with the Waldorf Astoria but it's pretty good for a Hilton. The property itself is beautiful with great views. We spend thanksgiving week at the resort and my entire family had a great time. My children ages 18, 15, and 10 all had a great time at the waterpark and on the island. We had two rooms in La Marina with the waterpark package. Our room was located on the end of the building overlooking the waterpark and away from the Funicular, which resulted in extensive walking when going to the main building for breakfast or dinner but was a great location for waterpark use and also to access the boat to Palamino island. Resort staff was extremely attentive and always pleasant. The daily breakfast buffet in Las Brisas was excellent and was included in our room rate. Prices at the resort are a bit high but with the waterpark package, breakfast and airport transfers were included. On two evenings we ate dinner at restaurants outside the resort. We also booked a bio bay trip with Kayaking Puerto Rico and were very impressed with the trip and our guides. My wife, who does not like water where she cannot see the bottom even had a great time once we got the trip started. Be sure to book the trip yourself as the price through the hotel is almost twice the rate if you book it on your own. You can walk from the resort to the park where the trip originates. It is about a 10 minute walk. Everyone in the family wants to visit the resort again next year.

Reviews.Title: “This place has it all!”
Reviews.Author: BookishBeachGirl
Reviews.Content: We just finished attending a conference at this resort. Our conference had 1000 attendees. This resort was able to provide an amazing array of services that made the conference very memorable. Every event came off without a hitch. When not in meetings and at special events the hotel has a dizzying amount of things to do. Many people enjoyed the water park. The pools were very nice and unlike many other resorts I have stayed at they have enough pool chairs so that you don't have to get into a fist fight to get a chair. I also liked that you could swim at anytime, night or day. We spent some time in the casino and dancing in the club. We were surprised to find affordable items in the resort gift shops. Our room had a spectacular view. Our room was newly renovated. The bed and bedding were really comfy. My only disappointment was the fact that the only beach has to be reached by ferry. I only went to the beach once. I am not a pool person, I like the beach, so I stayed indoors and went home without a tan. All of the staff were really professional and friendly. This place really does have something for everyone. What a great choice for a conference.

Reviews.Title: “STUDY PLAN AND CONQUER”
Reviews.Author: nomoreyankees
Reviews.Content: After reading the reviews We thought something was fishy, the difference between guest expectations and stays were incredible so here's the accurate rundown.Our trip was scheduled from November 4th-12.After reading the reviews i called on the first to cancel and switch to a resort i had stayed before(,I study and am in the hospitality business) so i feel well versed in the sense of instant gratification which is a very common denominator when traveling.From the beginning i explained my concerns to reservations and was convinced after many questions and well responded answers to give it a try and let others be proved wrong,Well we arrive to find an almost empty magnificent grand resort on a Wednesday to an instant upgrade with chocolate covered strawberries.They hooked me from there, remember this is Pert Rico its 4 hours from Philadelphia so for all i know i could have been in Harrisburg by car.Heres the deal this is too long Rent car do not eat in the restaurants except for breakfast and total convenience ,they are awful and the upper tier of food and beverage need work alot of it its that bad and that's the truth.Okay so we had a package called fall escape it included Buffet breakfast everyday ,no transportation and a gardenview room (which was upgraded at no charge to full ocean view) We arrive to an empty hotel and are told our room is not available til 4 Well my mother who i treated to on this vacation needs to eat(cup of frozen bag in the box broccoli soup ,2 microwaved cheeseburger and 2 iced teas PLEASE SIT DOWN 57.00 DOLLARS THE WORST Okay back check in to room nothing special not spotless but that was expected the view was to dye for they hooked me again were back on track..II wish i had this before i left i would need no others Ill stay on track now Palomino Island is magnificent the boat ride fun and clean the pool are and pools perfect nightlife except casino does not exist that's the negatives oh and did i say don't eat their food i don't mind expensive and good but this place is over the top we have you trapped here's the worst i can send you and ha ha you ll pay for it bad.. STACY-hostess La Brisas breakfast buffet amazing person great info and like cheers knows your name Dianne-manager of pool grill and Las brisas converted main lander a delight Reuben-Head Bellman hes a gentleman and on top of things Manual- head of property operations always moving started at the bottom and worked up for a reason, hes great Angelista(Killed her name its not right0 waitress and cocktail server at the main pool your the bomb and the hotel should know she has all the info for all traveler and is a delight Jaimee(pronounced Heimee) Casino dealer and owner of en estacion restaurant my favorite9kidding about owning) RENT CAR parking from enterprise is free they don't offer that info unless you ask it must be from enterprise My list of do not miss restaurants remember i was there 8 days and i conquered: En estacion,Passion,Kings seafood,Calyzzo ccaffe and a tappas restaurant on the hill called taques ohelio its wrong but the concierge has the menus too all restaurant and use the concierge they are great Enjoy and for once don't be stubborn and take advise I conquered Oh and one other thing i didnt want ot miss him Jose the casino dealer cif you dont like what you do leave its a big island and you rub off on all us travelors that you dont like

Reviews.Title: “Good but be aware...”
Reviews.Author: lldirect
Reviews.Content: This resort is a perfect example of "thinning" of the brand. It does not have the luxury associated with the Waldorf Astoria but it's pretty good for a Hilton. The property itself is beautiful with great views. But you need to know what you're getting. The hotel is huge with several separate buildings, two of which were closed when we were there. We were first put in the Marina building which requires a funicula to get to from the main areas. That didn't bother us much until it turned out we could hear it rumbling like distant thunder all night long. We switched to the Las Brisas building (which a friendly bellman had told us was his favorite) and were offered a room with a better, more open view (for which we paid an additional $19). As others have pointed out, certain basics like cleanliness are not in top form. In our first room, our bathroom had coffee stains in the sink, and the counters hadn't been cleaned. In the second, my daughter found stains on her sheet. The decor is a little tired, with linoleum instead of marble for the floors. Again, as others notes, the food in the restaurants we ate in was expensive and mediocre at best (although drinks were very good). Based on tripadvisor advice we got a car so we were able to drive to San Juan and Loquillo to eat. It was a schlep, but well worth it. Primarily, we were there for the Golden Door spa and we over-indulged in treatments that were uniformly fabulous. Unlike other's experience, we found the service everywhere in the hotel including the spa to be friendly and helpful. I'd made our appts. by phone from NY and Grace in the spa voluntarily offered a 15% discount. By the time we'd had our full complement of massages and treatments, we were too blissed out to care much about anything else and decided we'd happily come again. Since we'd left the kids at home, we didn't need to avail ourselves of the many pools and water park, but we did note that this would be an excellent place for a family, especially if you wanted to stay in a casita with kitchen facilities. All in all, if you look for comfort more than luxury, friendliness over efficiency, you won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “fabulous”
Reviews.Author: bellamia53
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from three days at this resort. I had read all previous reviews and I had low expectations . THEY WERE WRONG! All the staff were very nice. Our room was beautiful and clean. Well designed and very tastefully decorated. The grounds were beautiful maintained , tropical plants and flowers everywhere. Sculptures and art work in all areas. The pool was gorgeous. The tropical island of Palamino was a paradise. Boat ride was fun. The views from the hotel were amazing. One side is the Atlantic Ocean the otherside is the Carribean Sea. Yes there were some paper cups around from sloppy people. Well they could clean up after themselves. People are slops and arrogant to think they cannot throw a cup away... Only complaint was the lack of variety of food and incrediable expensive. But it certainly did not stop us from having a fabulous time.We travel alot and I would definetly recommend this place

Reviews.Title: “NICE AND DIRTY”
Reviews.Author: weasel18
Reviews.Content: This is a beautiful hotel. The staff does not cater to guests. The casino was dirty and I had to ask the manager, who was busy talking to his friends on the phone, to have somebody clean the area around the slot machines. the staff at palomino island was uncaring and the island was not well kept. the staff complains about business being slow but they don't move an inch to welcome gests. I would not spend money to stay here again unless theydo something about the staff.

Reviews.Title: “AMAZING!”
Reviews.Author: NK0514
Reviews.Content: We just got back from El Conquistador - my husband and I went with our two year old daughter. All I can say is that we had a great time! We booked on travelocity and upon checking in we received an upgrade from the room we intially requested so that was great. We were in the Las Brisas section of the resort which was close to everything and we had a great view of the ocean! The resort is very big and has beautiful grounds with great views of the ocean. I also love that its located on a cliff. We went to the water park which our daughter loved (I actually don't know who had more fun - my husband or my daughter). We also went to Palomino Island which was very nice and relaxing. We rented a car and did a half day self-guided tour of the El Yunque rainforest - it was 15 minutes away from the resort and I believe a must-do if you are in this area of Puerto Rico - it was beautiful! The food/drinks at the resort were a little expensinve but we did some grocery shopping (since we had a rental car) so that helped us save on breakfasts and snacks. One night we also ate outside the resort at a restaurant recommended by the concierge and loved the food. We ate at the Bella Vista Cafe alot and also at the Stingray Cafe both of which we liked. The only thing is that the nightlife is almost non-existant but that was fine by us since we were travelling with our young daughter.

Reviews.Title: “Fancy, enormous, overpriced resort”
Reviews.Author: nedtraveler
Reviews.Content: Spectacular, expansive resort, mostly perched high on a cliff above the coast, near the northeast corner of Puerto Rico, an hour from San Juan. Walking fast, it took 15 min. from our room (at the far end of the marina, near sea level) to the impressive conference center at the opposite end of the hotel atop the cliff (the distance might be unacceptable for the elderly or young children). This involves stairs (or elevator), a funicular ride up the cliff, a long walk, and another elevator, just to reach the "ground" floor of the hotel. We were part of a large meeting occupying 2/3rds of the rooms and most of the conference space. Rooms were listed (negotiated conference rate) at "only" $174. But adding resort charge, portage fee, housekeeping fee, etc., it was $215 a night. Self-parking (which we didn't use) is expensive, although a car rented from Enterprise (at either the resort or the airport), parks free. No beach is on the premises, but 100-acre Palomino Island offshore, owned by the resort, is 10 min. by catamaran; it is surrounded by beaches (some "cloth optional"), with hiking trails, activities, and a casual restaurant. The catamaran runs every hour (it says every half-hour, but it was deemed "off-season" when we stayed). Many shops and activities are on the hotel site: golf course, casino, water park, and several large pools. The El Con literature lists nearly 30 separate eating establishments, including room services and some fancy places in the ritzy Casitas condos, which may not be open to people from the regular resort. Options range from Starbucks (with a morning queue avoiding costly sit-down venues), an ice cream place, and "David's Cookies", to trendy and extremely expensive restaurants; several were closed (for breakfast, or just plain closed), but you have many choices if you have a hefty balance on your credit card. We dined at Stingray late one night (they close at 10 pm). It has a pleasant outdoor ambience near the yachts; service was adequate and the food good, but not worth the extreme expense. The cheapest wine was $12 per glass; bottles averaged around $100. Appetizers cost what an entree would at an equivalent mainland restaurant. With no affordable place for a simple meal, we took most lunches and dinners off-site, which requires a long walk from the marina (to a few modest restaurants), at a minimum, and generally a car (it is a mile to the hotel's entrance gate and at least a mile beyond to several restaurants). Breakfast options include a full buffet, which normally costs $25 (plus tax and tip), but reduced for our meeting to "only" $19 (plus tax and tip). The omlets were good, the fruit fresh and ripe, and the orange juice good (though not fresh-squeezed on site)...one felt one had to eat a huge breakfast just to "get your money's worth." Our room was on the 3rd floor above the sea, which was 100 feet beyond our balcony. Our room was better than a standard hotel room, with an unusually large bathroom, more than ample closets, a small safe, a mini-frig, a modest flat-screen TV (and DVD player), an iPod dock, a ceiling fan, a small desk, a large couch, a comfortable bed, and an ample outdoor deck...but no coffee-maker. Wireless internet ($15 a day) had the speed of a dial-up modem (why do pricey hotels charge, when internet is free in cheap motels?). (USA Today and the NY Times were supposedly free on-line, but the Times wouldn't load throughout our stay, despite our complaint.) Slow, erratic internet is free in the lobby, where caged parrots were often intolerably loud. The whole resort is air-conditioned like a refrigerator; our room could not be set above 72 deg. The toilet was proficient: be careful your clothing isn't sucked in when you flush. The shower head provided abundant water; the tub's surface was slippery but no rubber mat provided. Outside, coqui frogs chirped at night and iguanas rested in the trees by day. The resort's ambience is luxurious and tropical, but not overly much so. What is over the top is the sheer scale of the place. Despite stunning architecture and plentiful amenities, many things were broken: our telephone and frig had to be replaced and it took a maintenance man with a screwdriver to reset our clock, which was off by 1.5 hours; but maintenance responses were quick. And someone is available 24/7 by dialing "88" to answer questions. The funicular broke down at a critical time; the lobby escalator and a critical elevator were broken much of the week. The resort offers mini- or full-size-bus transport to/from San Juan airport, taking about an hour, $75 per person round-trip (water, sodas, and rum are available). You are greeted at the resort with a brief overview, then assigned to a porter who takes you to your room (the latter is mandatory, with portage fee added to your bill...it may be a good thing: we couldn't have found our room on our own). The El Con is part of HiltonHonors. Our dinner experience one evening was disappointing. We returned from Palomino Island to find the marina Bally-hoo bar&grill empty. Returning half-an-hour later, we were told we must wait 30 min. for a table by the water...most of the restaurant was reserved for a big party (later, loud music played into the night). So we went to the fake-Italian poolside restaurant by the lobby. My wife ordered "The Caprese", supposedly made of vine-ripened tomatoes, mozzarella, and basil leaves. What came was one plastic tomato, hard bits of mozzarella, and lettuce (not basil). We sent it back. The linguine was ordinary. But the price of our dinner was extraordinary. Needing to depart on a bus tour at 7 a.m., we asked where we could get breakfast beforehand. The Cafe Caribe supposedly opens at 6:30 a.m., but it was still closed at 6:40 a.m. Between coughs into his hand, the cook explained that his cashier hadn't arrived. We escaped that flu-laden scene and had a few pricey things at Starbucks, which was open. Our last dinner, at Blossoms, was pretty good. My wife had crispy duck in orange sauce from the Chinese menu and I selected a combination of sushi and sashimi. Service was professional, not pretentious, and the food was good. But it was over $150 for two.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: kathyg95
Reviews.Content: Excellent place, great people, beautiful scenery. Everything was so amazing. We went for our honeymoon, and the place was so memorable. Romantic yet we had many activities we could choose from. Jet ski, snorkeling, horseback riding, hiking, etc.

Reviews.Title: “Best Dive Shop: La Casa Del Mar at El Conquistador -- Fajardo, Puerto Rico”
Reviews.Author: diversgalore1234
Reviews.Content: We communicated with Carlos (by phone and email -- easy to get in contact with), who owns La Casa Del Mar, the dive shop that is part of the El Conquistador hotel. BEST DIVE SHOP and CREW (Antonio, Roberto, Tyrone, and Mariela). What makes them different from other Caribbean dive shops we've used in Bonaire, Caymans, Curacao, and Cozumel? A glass of ice cold water as soon as you board the boat, great/new rental gear, a large cooler full of assorted sodas (and beer for after diving), set-up (and rinsing and storage) or our scuba gear, cut watermelon/kiwi/cantelope/pineapple, large bath towels to dry off with, a hose with fresh water to rinse off with, a bathroom on the boat, chips and mango/peach salsa. The crew was helpful, personable, deferential, funny, and very service-oriented (including to kids). Too many times we see such indifference from the DMs. Briefings were informative, and DMs did their best to point out marine life to our group. Crew was bilingual -- communicated with ease. If you want diving in the East, seek out La Casa Del Mar. Arrange dive plans early, and the owner might permit a discount: http://www.casadelmarpr.com/

Reviews.Title: “Wish the place lived up to the resort title”
Reviews.Author: AuntBec
Reviews.Content: I got to go on a conference trip with my husband, so the trip was both business and pleasure. We were lucky to have rented a car or we both would have gone berserk with the food prices at the different eateries on the property - and we aren't the "cheap" type, we like good food and don't mind paying for it, but a dried out club sandwich was $15 plus tax. That being said, you might want to go somewhere else to eat. What you don't want to do is bring food into your room. We didn't, but when we explained that we didn't want to pay the $3.12 per day for maid service because we had ants the whole time, even after they sprayed twice, they accused us of having food in our room. Not the typical response I would have expected from a five star resort. By this time we had had enough of the lackluster service, as in we don't care what you think, and said goodbye. We also chose to take the stairs as opposed to the elevator. The lights were out in the hallway between the third and fourth floors. We began asking them to change the lights the night we arrived (10/3), and they were not ever changed and we left on the 11th. It was a little scary and most certainly dangerous. I appreciate hotels leaving a card saying they won't change the sheets every day or towels, if you prefer it that way. We didn't have that card in our room, but our sheets were not changed once while we were there. How do I know? I put a little pen mark on a corner after a couple of days to see if I was wrong. I wasn't. We did get clean towels. There is no microwave, fridge, or coffee maker - unless you ask for them. You are charged $10 per person for bellman service - regardless. You are also charged a daily resort fee equal to the amount of hotel tax each day - averages about $20. So, if you do stay here, use the resort in every way possible, otherwise you really will feel burned. There is a small water park with slides, but it also costs $20 to use it, each time. The resort fee could be for the ferry that takes you to the private island where there is a beach, chairs, towels, and umbrellas - and really cool huge iguanas and roosters and rabbits and horses to ride. What you can't do is walk into the water without water shoes because the coral is really sharp and everywhere. The pools on the property are beautiful and well maintained, but only 3 1/2 feet deep in all of the pools, including the lap pool. Not such a problem, just odd. I drank a beer at the pool, $8 - we paid the same in Japan?!?!?! Did I mention you also have to pay $16 a day to self park your car and maybe get a ride in a club cart from the parking lot to the hotel - or $20 a day for a valet to park the car for you. We did have a good time, but I would never in a million years give this place a five star rating, and my husband had to talk me into the 3 - he liked the ferry ride. They have a lot of people on their payroll, but not many actually working to keep the place up. The floors in the hallways were filthy - always wear shoes, door handles on the stair way doors were almost yanked off, it just doesn't feel like a place that the people who work there give a darn about one way or the other. Waldorf-Astoria/Hilton/whatever - it's just not what it's hyped up to be. One last bit, they have a tacky little survey on your tv, if you need a laugh, check that out too.

Reviews.Title: “Nice weekend”
Reviews.Author: CharyPuertoRico
Reviews.Content: I wanted to spend sometime with my children on the weekend and get off the daily routine. The El Conquistador Golf Resort and Casino offered a pleasure place to stay with my family. The attention of the employees was excellent starting by the front desk agent (lifesaver), Shaira, who was very nice and diligent to cater to our needs as well as help with a baby crib. The resort facilities; the exciting pools, the incredible gardens and Palomino Island, was really spectacular surpasses our expectations. We had a pleasant and relaxing weekend. If you want a nice weekend I recommend this hotel in a heartbeat. Angel Gomez, Neysha, Giovanni & Elsadi Bonilla

Reviews.Title: “Top Notch establishment”
Reviews.Author: cyndylee
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the El Conquistador in Puerto Rico. It was beautiful. The views were absolutely amazing and the accomodations were fantastic. I was able to go to the private island which was superb. There are horses you can ride for a fee. You can snorkel, scuba, play beach volleyball, swim, lay in the sun, etc. The main negative thing I encountered was the expense. Overall, I would definitely go there again....anytime!

Reviews.Title: “It Could Be So Much Better”
Reviews.Author: nightskyguy
Reviews.Content: the setting is spectacular: perched on a cliff overlooking warm, inviting Caribbean waters, far from the bustle of San Juan. I'm not big on resorts, but I've stayed at a couple of posh ones in Hawaii, and I expected likewise here. boy, was I disappointed! the buildings look like they haven't been updated in a decade or more. lots of maintenance was going on during the day at inconvenient times and in inconvenient places (I'm talking jackhammers). the room was spacious but spartan in its furnishings and otherwise unremarkable. the bed was comfy, but I found no light next to the desk, vinyl-covered furniture, and a closet inconveniently tucked way into the rear of the bathroom (which had no A/C vent, BTW). there's an 11% room tax and an 11% resort fee, whatever that is. others have mentioned the $3 daily charge for housekeeping, but the hotel even added 7% tax to *that*. other reviewers have detailed the mediocre overpriced food too, though the bar down by the marina was the pleasant exception. most breakfast options don't open until 7 am, and the fitness room is only open until 8 pm. I took the free water taxi (nice) to get to the hotel's Palomino Island just offshore for a relaxing afternoon but once there I paid $14 for a smallish margarita in a plastic Dixie cup (no cash accepted there, only your room card). here's the kicker: it took 45+ minutes to check out for no apparent reason, even though the line was only 4 deep. counter staff casually came and went without actually attending to customers. I actually used my cell phone to call the front-desk manager to complain; he was unsympathetic. I'd definitely advise that you look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Just Go Prepared....”
Reviews.Author: Colorado17
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a week at the El Conquistador where my husband attended a scientific conference. As world travelers, I would have to say we've never stayed in a hotel with as many mixed reviews as this one had and as others have expressed, I had concerns before we went. Careful reading of the many detailed previous posts on Tripadvisor about this hotel enabled us to go fully prepared and to have a very good experience overall. I hope to both validate and add to the great information in these previous posts. Since we had read that the hotel restaurants were overpriced and not terrific (true) and the lack of a car would make us largely dependent on these restaurants, we rented a car at the airport. Enterprise is the only rental car agency which has it's own, free, self parking lot at this hotel and this lot is located closest of any parking to the hotel lobby. Parking spaces were never a problem and cost savings over either self or valet parking was significant. Renting a car in PR was also fairly inexpensive; we paid $160 for the full week. Since none of the hotel restaurants offer PR cuisine, having the car enabled us to venture further afield, see more of the Island and try some great recommended restaurants. We did find the Caribe Cafe which is located across from the casino a very acceptable and reasonably priced option for breakfast. Service and food were fine if not somewhat lacking in variety. Early in our stay, we found the Amigo supermarket located close to the hotel and stocked up on snacks and supplies. We had no issues bringing things along in our beach bags on the ferry to Palomino Island and no one checked. We checked into the hotel on a Saturday afternoon well before the 4:00 pm check in time with no wait and had no problem getting upgraded to an ocean front room in the Las Brisas wing which I had requested based on previous reviews. This wing is located within walking distance of the lobby (very convenient if attending a conference in the convention center), is up to date and the floor we were on (5th) was the same floor as the lobby. Las Brisas has two wings and our room (3506) was on the left, north facing side which actually overlooked marina where the kayaks leave for the bio bay. The room had a beautiful view of the ocean beyond. Since this wing did not get the direct sun of the south facing right hand side, we were even able to sit out on the deck despite the warm temperatures. The room was clean, serviced early every day (about 9-10 am)...which was great...and well maintained throughout our stay. We had no issues getting supplies or towels replenished. The only complaint I would state (as others did) was that the bed linens were the most worn I've seen in the hotel in years. Totally unacceptable for a luxury hotel. As described in other posts, the grounds are indeed beautiful. The size of our room was better than many we've stayed in. The bathroom was very large and included a terrific walk in closet with a large dresser.. We were able to store our luggage out of the way and not feel cramped for space. Water pressure was fine in the shower, the bed was comfortable and the room was quiet. We never heard other guests. Another distinct advantage of our location in Las Brisas was that wireless actually worked extremely well in this room. Although the cost for internet was the same ripoff as you'd find at other top level hotels, at least it worked. Both my husband and I were able to connect easily every day which most of the other conference participants were relegated to working in the lobby. The main hotel has two beautiful pools which I used on several days when I didn't take the ferry to Palomino Island. The ferry didn't make it's first trip to the island until 9:00 am; it would have been great if they'd run the ferries a little earlier in the day. Still, the island is magnificent. There is plenty of room to spread out, have some solitude, sit in a lounge chair under a tree, rent sailboats, kayaks, etc. As many have said, it's the best part of the resort. Two restaurants were recommended in previous reviews and we found them as good as the reviews described. La Estacion is located just outside the hotel's gates and has wonderful food and service. We both really enjoyed the mofongo, pinchos (skewers of grilled meats) barbequed ribs and especially the cheeseburgers....just great. Tasca is located a short distance away and has a wonderful view of a bay; service is equally good as is the food. We probably went to La Estacion 4 times over the course of the week (closed on Thursdays) and Tasca twice (closed on Monday and Tuesday) . Dining at these two places was both cost effective and enabled us to experience local cuisine. Over the course of the week we hiked in the El Yunque rain forest, did the bio bay kayak trip, toured the Aricebo Radio Telescope along with the spacecraft team my husband is a member of, checked out Ponce; PR's second largest city and drove at least 350 miles around the island...all interesting pursuits. As recommended by others, we reviewed our bill a couple of days before we checked out to make sure there were no erroneous charges which would have been time consuming to correct at checkout. One duplicate charge for internet service was corrected in advance and check out was quick the day we left. This resort does nickle and dime it's guests, in addition to the internet cost, daily housekeeping, a bellman's fee, and resort fees/taxes are all added to the rate which I knew based on previous posts . But staying in a nice, clean and spacious room with a great view, well located to the convention center, not depending on the hotel for meals, having free parking and making the most of the beautiful grounds, pools and Palomino Island made for a good experience overall.

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the price”
Reviews.Author: Pheros
Reviews.Content: Trapped on campus, the hotel staff uses this excuse to under-serve and ignore you while the restaurants charge you exorbitant rates for mediocre food. A general aura of apathy pervades the place. The singular exception was a security guard, who seeing us all streaming away from the campus' back entrance in search of food that wasn't an absurd price, drove out down the unlit back-road we were walking down to make sure the small restaurants a half-mile away were actually open. Although the hotel was very elaborate and ornate, and provides a beautiful view, the level of "you're-trapped-so-we-can-charge-you-what-we-like" mentality of the entire facility, especially in light of many other nearby options significantly less expensive, leads me to conclude that El Conquistador is not nearly worth the price tag. Go somewhere else: you'll still have a great view and a great time, and won't feel like you're getting ripped off constantly.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful and relaxing”
Reviews.Author: JAMFL
Reviews.Content: Gorgeous views, lots of amenities and activities, comfortable rooms, friendly staff. Food is expensive, so better to rent a car and eat at a local restaurant.

Reviews.Title: “I have never been more impressed”
Reviews.Author: WmMilzar
Reviews.Content: I have traveled A LOT for business. Conference center after conference center so they all blur together. However, the El Conquistador stands above any other I have visited. Not only for its spectacular views and conference center, but the staff. Two examples among many. A young lady who worked at the outdoor pizza restaurant, Sally, was helpful enough to assist me in remembering the little things like cheese and red peppers (and other essentials) when I became distracted due to a business matter when picking up my dinner. She could have just handed me my pizza and moved onto the next person, but didn't. She went that extra step and that made the difference between eating my pizza in my room while working and enjoying my pizza while I worked. To exemplify the most extraordinary employee I have ever met at a conference center, I wish to publicly thank Mr. Perez, the fitness center's personal trainer. I am returning to active duty military service after years of civilian life due to a change in my personal mission in life. I am due to report to officer training soon and have been worried about the little things like a proper salute and how to perform a proper about face (being prior Army service, I will not go to basic training and relearn all of that drill and ceremony and hence was worried that I may not remember it all after 16 years). Mr. Perez is a former Drill Instructor for the Army and took time to help me remember what to do. He spent hours refreshing my memory and I am now comfortable with my drill and ceremony. This may not appear to be much, however, to me it meant more then words can ever say. SFC Perez, I thank you from the bottom of my heart and the stories you shared about your service and the Army really made a difference in this soon to be officer. (Sally, I thank you from the bottom of my stomach :~) )

Reviews.Title: “Destination Wedding in Puerto Rico”
Reviews.Author: greekmiss
Reviews.Content: I had never been to Puerto Rico and I had never been to a destination wedding so wasn't sure what to expect. I will say that I loved it! Minus the beaches that I visited - which were full of coral so shoes were a must - everything was really nice. The El Conquistador hotel was wonderfully beautiful. The lobby is very pretty and they have parrots during the day. There are a number of pools of all sizes and a water park! They even have their own private island and ferry boats that take you over (the ferry goes every 1/2 hour or hour depending on the time of day). The island was nice because it was like a little adventure on it's own. The landscaping was gorgeous and the rooms were wonderful. To speak a little more on the room - they were more than wonderful! They were large, airy, roomy, the bed was amazing with great pillows and the bathroom also was very roomy. The room was also very contemporary so it was NOT out of date at all. I really enjoyed the hotel. The food that was available at the hotel was also very good. One place I would suggest - the Italian restaurant upstairs in the hotel...it is a MUST visit! The steak house has much to be desired - especially the service. All in all this was a great trip and the hotel was a big part of that. I will say that if you want to visit San Juan, you are about an hour to an hour and a half away. But totally worth the trip! Also, El Yunque rainforest is only 15 minutes away and a MUST visit! Totally worth the trip as well.

Reviews.Title: “poor value for the money”
Reviews.Author: eolusa
Reviews.Content: This is a very expensive place isolated from any shops, restaurants that are more affordable. The on-site restaurants are pricey and there are extra charges for everything including $3 each day for room cleaning. My room had ants and some jewelry was stolen from my room - be sure to use the in-room safe even if you don't usually. Response from security was "maybe you lost it", "you must not wear it very much", etc. Would not return to this place.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Accomadations”
Reviews.Author: steveyoungUsa
Reviews.Content: We used a rental car to get to the hotel from San Juan airport. Traveling through PR is an adventure, driving is treacherous, its not like home. The hotel is beautiful. The staff is wonderful. There are so many good places to eat in the hotel, very diverse cuisines. I reccomend the breakfast buffet at Las Brisas. Please take advantage of the water ferry to Palamino Island.

Reviews.Title: “We didn't want to leave!”
Reviews.Author: Lisatedj
Reviews.Content: This was an amazing hotel. We took a day and a half off to go to Vieques, and we totally wish we hadn't. This was an amazing place. We took our son, who was around 14 months old. He loved the parrots in the lobby, as well as the amazing swimming pools. The hotel had their own private island, and we took a ferry there. It was like a tropical paradise. We had a babysitter for our son, and my husband and I rented hobby cats (those little sail boats) and sailed from one tiny island to another. It was our best date ever! We felt like explorers. I laid on my stomach and watched the coral pass beneath us. Super fun! The only bad thing about it is that the food at the resort is VERY EXPENSIVE! We paid $15 dollars for a hot dog! We kept going off the resort to eat and buy food. We kept cereal and milk (in the little refrigerator) for breakfast. The food was very good, but even the cheapest restaurants were way too expensive- almost $20 a plate!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing”
Reviews.Author: relaxed628
Reviews.Content: My husband and I celebrated his 40th birthday here. Just driving up to the resport was breathtaking. The mountains, the lush landscaping, the beautiful flowers and the water. WOW! The lobby was absolutely gorgeous and every restaurant we ate in had the best service and the finest foods. My husband recently went to Hawaii and he said that Puerto Rico was more beautiful. Palamino Island was nice, but I have been to better beaches. It was very rough on our feet so pack your water shoes. I tried to buy a pair but they didn't have my size. I would give Palamino Island a B but everything else, an "A" including the Spa. Go see Claire for a wonderful massage.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Setting and Relaxed Atmosphere”
Reviews.Author: Portena-by-Marriage
Reviews.Content: My family of 4 (2 teens 16 & 13) stayed here around Labor Day for 8 nights. We had an Ocean View Room with a balcony that was spacious & modern. The bathroom was large with a sunken tub/shower, large sink, and dressing area with a chest of drawers, iron & ironing board. The toiletries were lovely. In addition, there was a cooler in the room, which did not work, but was quickly replaced. This hotel is HUGE. It took us 2 days to explore most of the premises...multiple pools, gardens, tennis, golf, private island, spa, labyrinthe, many restaurants, etc., etc. The views are absolutely beautiful. The many pools include a water polo/volleyball pool, lap pool, at least 3 jacuzzis, swim-up bar, and a water park at sea level. The hotel owns Palomino Island with a water taxi shuttles all day. The island has services (towels, beach chairs, food, shop, snorkeling, snuba, scuba, etc.). If you have your own snorkeling equipment, bring it along. There are many restaurants and shops on premises, but I suggest you rent a car (Enterprise is on-site) to be able to get off site to buy snacks, water, and explore local restaurants. The recurring theme in reviews is that the food is expensive. I concur. Bio-Bay is right next door with many vendors on site filling up their tours. If you are a mosquiot magnet, be prepared to protect yourself before kayaking through the mosquito-infested mangroves in the dark! The tennis courts are terrific and free and the pro is really good. Raquet rental is $15/hr. For the $60 we paid to play doubles, it would have been worth packing our own equipment. The staff went out of its way to be pleasant and helpful. The spa needs a bit of a facelift, but the attendants are professional, and the beauticians in the salon are quite good. There is WiFi available, but if you need to use the business center, the charges are steep. (Why do they do that?) All in all, I would definitely stay here again. It is a beautiful hotel with a relaxed atmosphere and every amenity that you'd need.

Reviews.Title: “jz”
Reviews.Author: crazelvxing
Reviews.Content: Just back from Puerto Rico and we stayed there for 5 days. Nice trip though. The hotel view was good but the food was expensive. We went outside for food. The secret way is pass throung the marina, go outside the entrance fence and the security, there is the local area for foods and sightseeing. Only 8 minutes walk. You can also rent the canoe at 6:30 pm. Much cheaper than the hotel. When we went to the Biobay, the glowing was not too bright which made me quite dispoint. Better to arrange a full moon day and go.

Reviews.Title: “Need Improvements”
Reviews.Author: sonia1004
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this Hotel for the labor day weekend . We got late so they assigned us two rooms at Las Olas Building.
