The best (fastest) wireless access is on the benches outside Davidâ€™s Ice Cream. Free wireless is available in the lobby with tolerable but not fast transfer rates, but the lobby is often rather noisy (next to the casino, music, and loud parrots caged in the lobby). Many things here generally are not thoughtfully designed, and El Conquistador seems to be much more about appearances than actual substance. If you are not planning to leave the resort (which is rather isolated), you should note that dining here is expensive â€“ and the quality is not bad but also not particularly good. (We did enjoy the salads at the cafÃ© right next to the main lobby.) Prices are about double what you would pay in the continental U.S. After a few days, I have come to feel taken advantage of by the lack of reasonable dining options. Furthermore, within the resort, the only fruit readily available and not blended into drinks is bananas and the same red and green apples from Washington State. We picked up some fresh mangoes from a roadside stand (car trip required), and they are delicious but not available at El Conquistador. Some things in our room are also poorly designed. Most notably, our shower lacks an inner curtain that goes inside of the tub, so each time we shower, we flood the floor. A sign left in our room was also noteworthy: â€œResort Attire: Resort attire ranges from beachwear and causal to elegantly casual and formal, depending on the place and the occasion. We request that shirts and cover-ups be worn over bathing suits in the lobby area. To help us maintain the resort ambiance after sunset, we suggest that gentlemen wear slacks and shirts with collars and that ladies wear fashionable skirts, dresses, or pant suits. Please feel free to look your best when enjoying our dining or entertainment facilities.â€� El Conquistador has its own island, El Palamino, which is a 10-minute (free) water taxi ride from the resort. The ride was quite pleasant. The beaches on El Palamino were nice, and many people enjoyed swimming, sunbathing, and drinking at the beach. We explored hiking trails on El Palamino, but the island is rather desolate apart from the beach. In summary, El Conquistador is preoccupied with their bottom line. If you cannot stay elsewhere, pack lots of your own food, and be prepared to go to the lobby for wireless internet access.

Reviews.Title: “Five Star Resort, Three Star Service”
Reviews.Author: nadraamara401
Reviews.Content: The El Conquistador Resort and Spa is a beautiful place, but I feel that my stay could have been more enjoyable. Many of the resort's policies are not clearly articulated, including the amount of the authorization for incidentals and the availability of the shuttle service, leading to unforeseen expenses (on top of the high cost of the stay) and undue stress. The front desk staff tended to be rude and less than helpful, and the prices in the restaurants and shops were outrageous. All in all, El Con is a case of five-star amenities/facilities coupled with three-stars service and they shouldn't expect a return visit from me.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent place to stay”
Reviews.Author: QueenDiane
Reviews.Content: This was the best place we stayed yet. Staff was very helpful and friendly. Food was great, but expensive and was the only draw back. Definately a place to stay if interested in a top notch hotel and fantastic view. Plan lots of time between going to the room and lobby or beach. The cable car takes time and only 1 elevator worked. I recommend getting a car. Fees were not bad, and we were able to travel to the local sights such as the rain forest and San Juan without being in a tour. Seeing the bio bay is a must, but make sure you wear bug spray - the mosquitos were very bad and ruined the canoe experience.

Reviews.Title: “SPECTACULAR”
Reviews.Author: lamira
Reviews.Content: Loved it..the hotel is spectacular. The amentities were great. If your looking for beach, pool, and relaxation this is the place to go. There is no need to leave the resort. Take a ferry to Palomino Island - their private beach. Go golfing or a day at the spa and a must-do was their waterpark. We really enjoyed our Memorial Day weekend at Conquistador...

Reviews.Title: “beautiful place to stay- Palmotio Island is amazing”
Reviews.Author: NYdreamerFL
Reviews.Content: Rooms were nice hotel is huge casino is fun food is good but expensive superette on site but pricey But best thing is the gorgeous island- closes at 5pm short ride over via ferry Go to the off site restaurant (2 mins away) Passions absolutely amazing food!!!! Great service! Authentic puerto rican cusine average cost!

Reviews.Title: “Not cheap, but worth it if you take advantage of everything”
Reviews.Author: JK4321
Reviews.Content: Many of the earlier reviews concerned me but, frankly, virtually all of the complaints were unfounded. Not sure whether this was due to the prior hotel management or the situation when the hotel is completely full (it was far from it in mid-May), but we had a great time. Positives: Beautiful resort, great room, courteous service, reasonably priced food (not cheap, but even the places outside the gates were not much cheaper), lots to do, great pools, accurate bill, etc. Negatives: Not a compact resort, no internet access or good mobile reception in our guest room (in the Las Olas building; perhaps others have both), waiting for the tram can get old, the snorkeling at the island isn't good, some rooms are clearly sub-standard in terms of location. (Only real negative was that one night we were kept out by two drunken men yelling in the pool area all night, and security did not shut them up despite two calls. Complained to management the next morning, and problem was solved.) Again, we were there when the resort seemed fairly empty and got a great room and a huge pool and jacuzzi essentially to ourselves, but we did notice that the resort will close various operations (or do maintenance) during those periods. None of that detracted from our visit, and I would definitely come again. When you compare the prices to some of the other luxury resorts, the prices here actually were on the lower side. All that said, I could see things getting frayed when the place is truly packed (e.g., not enough check-in desks, not enough tram capacity, not enough places to eat for breakfast, hard-to-get reservations at the other restaurants, etc.), but a lot of places could be like that during peak season. Based on this visit alone, I would visit again without hesitation, but would look to book outside of the high season. If you rent a car, there are plenty of places within 5 miles of the resort (Walmart, Walgreens, grocery stores, etc.) to stock up on food and provisions, so if you rent one of the Casitas villas, you could really save on meals. Actually, if you had a car (and you can rent one at the Enterprise operation at the resort, which isn't that bad when you consider parking is free when you rent a car), you could really save on excursions to the El Yunque rain forest, Old San Juan, etc., which we did. Walking out of the gate by the water for about 250 yards takes you to a small recreational area with a number of food stands and a couple of restaurants. Cheaper than eating at the resort, but not necessarily cheap. The kayak trips to the bioluminesence bay - absolutely worth doing - start here, and you could probably save 50% by just walking there and joining a trip and not book through the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Vacation at a Great Value”
Reviews.Author: canwegoalready
Reviews.Content: I spent April 21-25 at the ElCon and had a lovely week with three teenage girls. This was a class trip celebrating their high school graduation. We got a great rate, the Winter Escape package, for $199 a night. This came with $100 resort credit for each of the two rooms we booked, plus several other deals we could use during this stay and future stays at Waldorf Astoria Collection Resorts. Check in was quick and easy after a drive from San Juan airport during rush hour traffic took us almost two hours for what should have been a 45 minute trip. We arrived after 5pm and were the only people at the desk. It took about 10 minutes. We were escorted to our rooms in the Las Vista wing and had beautiful views of the tennis and gold courts. Both rooms were spacious and clean. I had a king and the girls shared a room with two queens right next door. The sitting area in the king room was large enough for all of us to be comfortable. The patios were perfect. The bathrooms were large and the closet was great! I did notice some wear and tear in the bathroom, there was a missing fixture in the tub and some rust where it used to be. The main thing that kept me from giving the resort a perfect score were the sheets. They were old, not dingy, just natty from seeing so many washings. It is not very luxurious getting into a comfortable bed and night, laying on natty sheets. The resort itself is beautiful. Everyone was very helpful and gracious. We rented a car and drove from San Juan. The concierge we helpful every time I visited the desk to ask for a directions, a map or suggestions on things to do. One evening the girls got a little restless and I had no desire to drive to San Juan at night, so the concierge helped us find a nice little bowling alley in a neighboring town we were got free salsa lessons and then had time to bowl! Our other excursions were easy to navigate as well, We spent a day in El Yunque, the rainforest and then spent the afternoon cooling off at Luquillo Beach. We drove up to Old San Juan and then found a nice outlet mall on the way back. Every morning while the girls slept in I explored the resort (decided not to get a spa treatment because I missed a great special the day before), and inevitably ended up at the fabulous pool. The pools are fantastic. Get up early and go before 11am and you will be rewarded with some of the most peaceful relaxing time you can imagine. Take a bottle of water with you because there's no service before then. We also spent a fabulous afternoon on Palomino Island. The ferry ride was quick and easy. I was nervous because I have horrible motion sickness and forgot to take anything before we left the room. But I sat up on the outside deck and was fine for the entire ride. It felt like no more than a 10 minute ride. On the island I found a quiet spot and didn't venture out too far because of all the rocks, shells you had to maneuver before you got to smooth sand. But the girls kayaked and tried out the jet skis. They loved it all. The next day they went to the water park and had a good time there too. The food at the resort is very expensive. Went to Wal-Mart the first night and stocked some basics in the fridge in our rooms. We ate at the cafes for breakfast (kids ate free breakfast as a part of our package) and for late night snacks. We ate fast food when we were out on excursions, made sandwiches in the rooms and we splurged at Blossoms on our last night. We all enjoyed the meal. With the two rooms we had a combined resort credit of $200 that we used to cover the expense of parking for the week (valet parked the first day, self parked the rest of the week), a few in room movies and internet usage and some of our meals/snacks. So all in all, it was not a bad deal at all. I have visited Puerto Rico several times, my brother's wife is from the island. We planned their wedding there and I have traveled and am comfortable with the eastern part of the island from north to south. I have stayed in family homes and small southern towns and in paradores in Fajardo. The El Conquistador Resort is the best, in my opinion, on this part of the island if you are looking for a relaxing vacation at a resort that is very family friendly and has something for adults, teenagers and children. The girls (all 17) made lots of friends (as did I) and the staff took very good care of them. After the first night I had no worries letting them wander around the resort on their own. I would love to come back with my family IF they continue to have specials like the Winter Escape package. I can imagine that I would not feel the same way if I had paid a higher rate for the room and did not have the extras thrown in. They just need to get new linens for the beds and update the bathtub. As it stands, we was a wonderful vacation at a great value!

Reviews.Title: “Best of Both Worlds the El Con was spectacular”
Reviews.Author: MB3448
Reviews.Content: Experience a secluded beautiful resort that has real Puerto Rican food at the Las Croabas Park just outside of the marina maybe a quarter mile away. So you can stay within the resort and experience the luxury hotel that is the El Con. I wished I had spent one more day here and one less day in San Juan. Pros Beautiful Hotel, Wonderful Pool, Exquisit Golf Course and best of all they have thier own marina and island to satisfy all of your water sport or water relaxation needs. The Casino and restraunts in the hotel are great. And real Puerto Rican food is within walking distance. And you must do the bio-luminescent kayak tour. Youve never seen anything like it, unless you have seen something like it. Which you probably havent :) Cons Over-Priced Drinks! As much as I try to make myself understand that a 12 dollar mojito is acceptable at a resort that caliber I cant take the spritz of rum they put in there. But dont let that get in the way of a once in a lifetime experience. There is always the Amigo grocery store or Las Croabas where you can score Medallas for 2.50.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful spot to stay”
Reviews.Author: JKMAN
Reviews.Content: The hotel is absolutely huge! It is built on a hill. Our room was at the lowest level so we had to take a tram down a steep incline - beautiful views when we travelled up and down on the tram! We were close to the ferry that goes over to Palomino Island - definitely go to the island. There is a beautiful beach, places to eat and drink and even a little shop. There is no beach at El Conquistador unless you take the free ferry to the island. We were also close to the water park which was a fun afternoon even without kids! Bit of a pain to get around since we had to take the tram up to the main hotel for a lot of services. They have two trams and quite often one was out of order. But, it wasn't very busy when we were there so maybe they didn't see the need to hurry and get the other tram working. Overall, a beautiful hotel. We loved our room which had an ocean view. Outside our room on the opposite side we could watch for wildlife in the lush hillside. We spotted many, many large iguanas laying in the trees. At night we could hear the Coqui, the tree frog mascot of Puerto Rico.

Reviews.Title: “Planning my return trip”
Reviews.Author: SraRose
Reviews.Content: The hotel is a 30-45 minute ride from San Juan. We were tired of the metropolitan beaches. If you don't want to risk renting a car and driving macho-boriqua-style, then San Juan or Carolina is for you. The first view of el Yunque, the rainforest, and you feel transported. Take a hike if you are in the neighborhood. We briefly strolled along the paved roads, but we had a 4 and a 1 in a stroller, so we cut it short this time. Go hiking on the nature paths. On a clear day, the views are breathtaking. We stayed 3 days this time. That was sufficient. I prefer to move around and see all parts of the island. We also visit frequently the metropolitan area, Ponce, Humacao, Mar Chiquita, Areciebo, and Cabo Rojo. All the beaches and all sides of the island are different. We first stayed at El Con several years ago for a romantic weekend. It was so-so. Now with 2 small children, (4 and 1) and the addition of the water park, we decided to try it again. The property rests on the side of a steep slope with the buildings occupying different level terraces. They have added two buildings on the lower-most levels accessible via the funicular, the same one you take on the way to the ferry to Isla de Palaminito; one barrio half-way down the funicular (ultra-quiet uncrowded pool and jacuzzi and game room) and one at the bottom for the water park patrons.We stayed in a room at the very end of the second level close to the water park. It was clean, quiet, with an ocean view, fridge, and cathedral ceilings. Huge bathroom. Very nice. All new. The walk to the far end of the building was punctuated with sitings of iguanas camoulflaged in the trees (far enough away to be safe, but close enough to spy them). If you don't want to walk, stop here and pick another place. It was quite a hike back to the main lobby, about 10 minutes of constant walking: the full length of the building, the funicular ride to take us to the midway, walking past the row of shops (with slightly desperate shop-keepers spreading thickly the charm to make a sale) then to another elevator to the main level, past more shops and restaurants, past the casino, and then finally the lobby. We knew this going in. We were at the fathest point from the lobby. But it was a pleasant stroll and I had no difficulty pushing a stroller all the way every time. You will have a wonderful view all the way from the funicular and the walk past the shops, plenty to see, like a subliminal encouragement slow your pace. Look at the bromiliads, the iguanas, the shore, Palimino. The water park was the focus of our stay and with 2 small children in tow, you do not get anywhere fast. Plus at that distance from the lobby, you don't see any check-in/check-out traffic, bellboys, luggage, vehicle traffic, or lost tourists. It feels very private. The people chat with you while waiting for the funicular or even just walking the same direction. We felt very safe. The children's pool area was just perfect for our two little ones. One half was less than 3 feet deep and had a mini slide, sprinklers, and little submerged toad stools to climb on. The pool had a beach-like walk-in for toddlers and an infinity edge. The water park is small, 3 or 4 rides, and a lazy river, one slide is tame enough for my just turned 4-year-old to go on (about 50 times!). For PR, this is great! If you want a multitude of massive rides, go to Orlando. The private beach across the bay is only accessible by catamaran - 5 minute ride every 30 minutes from 8AM to 4PM. They have increased the frequency of the catamarans to Palimino Island (their beach). There is a path that winds all around the isla and to the top of the hill where sits an itty-bitty chapel and an arch for exchaning vows. The waterfront of the hotel is a boat dock. There is no swimming allowed there. There are restaurants with waterfront seating, but beware. You are paying for the view. Rent a car and cruise into town for meals (5-7 minute drive). Pollo Tropical is fast and better quality than chain fast food. There are fast-food chains, pizza places, Chinese restaurants, and moderate sit-down places. Plenty to choose from. We have had no problem with the local Mami & Papi restaurants and the food has been delicious and fresh. And two grocery stores right at the end of the road to stock up on anything else. I was prompted to write this because I got a email that they are having a special. I'm booking another stay for September.

Reviews.Title: “Impressive...but only at first glance (a very short glance).”
Reviews.Author: rarifin
Reviews.Content: Impressive...but only at first glance. At first glance (a very short one) - everything seems as it should for a 5-star Waldorf-Asotria mediterranean golf resort. After a 45-minute hotel bus shuttle ($68 round trip fare) from the airport, you finally arrive at the main hotel gate, only to find that the bus keeps going for at least another mile of scenic golf grounds, until you finally reach the main hotel building/check in. As you roll out of the bus onto the roundabout main entrance - the view is impressive. Columns and striped awnings flank a breathtaking view of the very blue ocean framed by colonial terrace overlooking the set of main pools below, with steps leading down to a fountain and terrace bar/restaurant. On the left, the main entrance to the lobby and check in. As we approached check-in, warm staff approach us with smiles and greetings and assuring words of comfort, such as "welcome to your vacation, let us do all the work for you." Lovely! In retrospect, how ironic. I ended up having to do triple work to UNDO all their "work." But more on that later. There was one party to check in in front of me as I got in line, which made me happy. However, I waited in line for almost 20 minutes. There were 3 clerks working. Go figure. Then, the clerk who finally checked me in asked for my credit card - so I give him my Amex (which is what I used to purchase the pre-paid flight/resort package booked through the resort's site). Fine. Then there was a lot of keyboard punching, then a confused look, then more keyboard. 10 minutes later, he gives me the key card and a resort id card, which you need to use everywhere in the resort in order to charge things to your room (they don't take cash pretty much anywhere). Our room was in the Las Brisas wing (my 3-year old daughter and my husband). The room at first was tasteful and lovely. Modern, white, balcony overlooking golf grounds (we took a "garden view"). It looked very clean...at first. On closer inspection, the corners of the room appeared a bit worn and "soiled" and I caught a glimpse of a few dust bunnies and crumbs on the carpet (not very well vacuumed). An armchair's ottoman also appeared to have some stains, resembling blood - yikes. The bathroom was large, with a closet to boot - but unfortunately, I chose not to use it as it smelled like a soiled damp cloth. Also, the bathtub looked very dirty and not very well cleaned. Mildewy and black crud molded around the hardware fixtures, and again...stains resembling blood on the tub floor...yuck! I immediately called Housekeeping, put on hold for 5 minutes, then got transferred to another line, waited a minute or so, then got transferred again until I finally got to speak with someone. They listened and told me they will send housekeeping up to re-clean it. 15 minutes go by, and I call again, get transferred again, then finally reach the same person who apologized and told me she will call me back. She never did. After 40 minutes, housekeeping finally came, scrubbed (at least got the bloody stains out, but not the other mildewy crap), plonked a damp yellowing tub mat over the whole tub, and called it a day. 5-Star resort? The pools were standard, fine. The beach was nice, but very "reefy" - water stays ankle-high all around Palomino island, not a "swimming" kind of beach. Also, quite rocky so wear your crocs. The ferry ride was about 10 min, but you have to wait quite a bit for it - so you need to count in a travel time of about 30 mins to get there. There were a lot of activities there - snorkeling, scuba trips, equip rentals - all at dear prices, of course. No shovels and pails for the kids at the very least? $25 for a lame little plastic set you can get at CVS for $5. Coqui Water Park - $20 per person for what was advertised as THE water park to go to. Basically, it was 3 "slides" and some inner tubes thrown into a "river" like pool. It was fun, but you definitely don't spend an entire day there. The drinks were all tropical and fruity. Where was the wine selection? 5-Star resort boasting 20 restaurants, and no wine? One pool bartender however "dug up" a bottle somewhere and it was horrible. We ate at the resort the first night, at their outdoor terrace pizzeria. Wasn't bad, wasn't good. Thin-crust NY pizza? Not even close. Boom, $25 a pop (personal size). Caeser salad. Bland, and more bland. Breakfast buffet in the morning, nice restaurant, but nothing beyond a free buffet at a Marriott Courtyard - $25 a person. They also told me I was not allowed to sign to my room upon presenting them with my resort "ID" card, and did not know the reason why. I had to go all the way to the front desk to inquire about this. The person who helped me informed me that there were 2 credit card numbers attached to my room and they did not know which one to use, so they just decided to "block" the bill to room service. 2 credit cards? How did that happen? So I inform them to use the Amex I gave them, so she proceeded to do some key punching and assured me it was taken care of. Confused, but eager to not drag out the issue, I accepted and headed back to my family. 5-star efficient service? Highly questionable. We also tried the beach island's eatery, where we had a $20 burger (ok) and a iceberg lettuce-only greek salad and a couple beverages somehow totaling over $60. The only other place we ate at was down at the marina where I ate a stale $14 chicken wrap - bland bland bland - slapped together and was 90% wrap, and hardly anything inside. We soon began to feel claustrophobic in terms of food options. One can't just stroll out of the resort either, we were literally "stuck on campus." (That mile-long drive from the gate to the hotel buildings was probably intentional - to keep guests in so they will have to eat and pay for the resort food!) We finally left, and took a van taxi to go out of the resort for our dinners - $20 each way (for a less than 5 minute drive) for our party of three. Literally 3-5 minutes outside of the resort were restaurants, 3 of which we ended up trying. The food outside of the resort in general was - SO delicious! We ate at L'Estacion, Calizo and Pasion por el Fogon - all three were amazing! Fresh local fish and produce, amazing flavors with culinary sophistication - were they really so good, or were we just SO desperate from all the resort food? The ribs at L'Estacion, the mofongo and the fresh paella at Calizo, and the fresh grilled whole red snapper at Pasion por el Fogon - all excellent! It dawned on me that there was nothing fresh about the food at the resort. Puerto Rico has such a wealth of flavors and fresh produce and sea life - a culinary dream - I just couldn't understand why none it was included in the menus at the resort. A shame, really. It was sort of like finding yourself on this beautiful mediterranean island, but your taste buds were stuck in a TGI Fridays. 5-Star resort? On our last night, we go back to our room after a nice evening out at Pasion por el Fogon, full, tired and content. My daughter half asleep on my husband's shoulder, and all of us eager to get back to our room to put her down. What do we find? Our card keys don't work. Both of them. So I shlep back all the way to the main lobby and wait to speak to a front desk clerk. My poor husband stays by our room with my sleeping daughter. The woman who helped me this time was all confused as to why this is happening. Again, it was a credit card issue. I told her that I kept telling them to get rid of any other credit card numbers on my account and just to use my Amex - how many times do I have to repeat this information (I even called my credit card and was reassured that my account was fine and there shouldn't be any problems, etc). I didn't even recognize the other Mastercard credit card number they told me was on my account! How is it they just - without informing the guest first - BLOCK the guest from entering their own room - with all their possessions in it - and yet cannot even explain to the guest why?!! Infuriating! I also started to worry - if they can't even keep their account info straight, am I looking at a near future of time-consuming sorting out of issues regarding billing, etc and other errors? 5-star? Meanwhile, my daughter so needs to sleep! Finally, after what seemed like an eternity and an embarrassing "scene" - I was assured that my keys will work. Which they didn't. Can you believe this? Somehow or other, because i was just so beyond infuriated, my husband got someone to let us in, and guess what? Our in-room safe couldn not be opened (with our passports and cash and cards inside). Another bout of sorting out with the front desk and waiting time for some guy to come up and open it for us. And it doesn't even stop there. Our guaranteed wake-up call for 5:30am - didn't happen. Thank God I somehow woke up just in the nick of time. You would think after all this trouble they would at least ensure that we get at least a wake-up call. Unbelievable. So, to sum it all up, this resort should be rated as 3-star at the most. The decision one makes between a 4-star or a 5-star is crucial in regards to the little details, such as service, cleanliness, food. It's these very things that make one decide to go one star up. If you don't get what that one extra star promises you - why go there? Why not just stay at the 4-star? Or the 3-star, in this case? Puerto Rico is beautiful, and we would definitely go back there - but definitely never ever would we step foot in this place again. I have no problems with mediocre food - at a 3-star hotel. I have no problems with even less than desirable service - at a 3-star hotel. I would be perfectly understanding with the wear and tear and a dust bunny or two - at a 3-star hotel. BUT NOT at a hotel that boasts 5-stars. Next time, we would stay closer to Old San Juan, at a resort with a couple pools and easy access to LEAVE "campus" and enjoy the local culture and local culinary delights. We paid way too much for this place - worth less than half the money.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced with worn rooms and marginal bed”
Reviews.Author: traveler99Georgia
Reviews.Content: We were disapointed in the El Conquistador. The tile floors in the hallways were dirty. There was gum on the floor of the elavator to our room that was not removed the 3 days we were at the hotel. Tile in our room was worm. The bottem sheet on our bed was a flat and not a fitted sheet and would not stay on the bed. Mattress pad was a twin on a king bed and we were exposed to the less then confortable mattress. This was unsanitary at best and as a result we had three poor nights sleep. Our calls to houskeeping to have the situation corrected were ignored. There is no beach and the water was unswimable. A bumpy 10 minute boat ride to their Island if we wanted a beach. The hotel was overpriced and not worth the 1 hour bus ride to and from the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Better than expected”
Reviews.Author: vbw
Reviews.Content: Many families, no "adults only" pool, private island is great except for all the coral so it's not very convenient for swimming, horrible Japanese restaurant, good steak house, good cafe on the island, noisy tram outside our window (but we got used to it), definitely get the oceanview rooms that are not directly overlooking the pool because they sometimes have corporate events and you'll listen to the staff breakdown the tables during the late hours.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful but way overpriced”
Reviews.Author: NyCarribeanLover
Reviews.Content: We arrived in the afternoon and was immediately taken to our room- no waiting. The bathroom was huge and just redone. Then walked to the balcony....we were overlooking the sewerage treatment plant (Garden view) and what a smell.... Complained to the bell hop and after a phone call we were upgraded to a room on the marina. The bathroom had a distinct musty smell and there was no way I would walk barefoot in the room. The cost for food was outrageous!! Breakfast for 3 - $57. Concessions around the resort were very confusing....some didn't take the room charge, some took only cash, the next day the same concession might take mastercard. guess it depended on who was minding the store. The only great thing about the El Conquistador was Palamino Island. That was fantastic...the ferry ride took only about 7 minutes and seemed to run everey 10 or 15 minutes. The water was crystal clear and no big waves... The funicular broke down one day and another day only one was running...that was an inconvenience...having a room on the marina...you were either stuck there or waited for the funicular. They also offered a bus, which we took once. That was worse than waiting around for the funicular. We took a not so scenic to of Fajhado...got stuck behind cars and people and had to wait until they were ready to move...totally ignored the buses horn. The drive from the botton of the resort to the main entrance took about 20 to 30 minutes.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Location...but not really up to par”
Reviews.Author: WithWifeandDaughter
Reviews.Content: I booked the Celebrating 40 package and actually stayed during my 40th birthday. Had I not booked this package, many of the included items were not worth purchasing/including at a la carte prices. First, I really tried to enjoy the resort in spite of some negative reviews. The views were amazing since the resort was perched on a hillside and I stayed at the Marina (bottom of the funicular & where you catch the ferry to Palomino Island). My room 1324, was well appointed and everything seemed fine, except I noticed a damp, musty smell on my bed that never went away and was a distraction when sleeping. The staff did do a good job cleaning the room however. Second, my best friend and his family surprised me and showed up to help celebrate my birthday...that was one of the most special moments. They stayed in the Las Olas part of the resort which was near our room. However, this part of the resort needs a tremendous make-over. The carpet was noticeably worn down (how is this a luxury resort?) and there is no elevator here. Luggage and strollers cannot easily be negotiated up these narrow steps. My friend and his wife are both medical doctors and have traveled to many luxury resorts and I felt embarrassed they had to stay there. They were in Room 2344. The only saving grace was their area had it's own swimming pool and we were able to use it pretty much to ourselves, unlike the main pool area which is crowded. The ferry was efficient and Palomino Island was a pleasure to be on...unlike another reviewer, I liked the lack of waves so my toddler daughter can play in the ocean. The food was...uninspired. The only restaurant I felt was good, was Stingray, which had pretty high prices. I knew the food would expensive, but I had hoped there would be some decent taste to the dishes at the other restaurants. Last night we went to Ritchie's Cafe in Rio Grande (about a 20 minute drive) and the food was delicious, reasonably priced, and the view was spectacular. We had a party of 5 adults, 2 kids, 2 toddlers and a baby for this dinner and the bill came to be just under $300 (incl gratuities). This is the only time I did not feel ripped off from eating. I highly recommend this restaurant because the waiters did a fantastic job of taking care of us. At the end of the dinner, the waiter offered to have my little daughter's utensils and dish cleaned (we bring our own because it's plastic). Now that is service! Previous reviewers may describe this resort as being in disrepair, but I think that is too harsh. Professionally, I know about capital improvements and building maintenance, so I can see when things have not been properly maintained. I personally witnessed staff cleaning, dusting and making repairs, however, these are things I noticed: 1. Elevators seemed always to be out of service. Most elevator banks on the resort was in pairs and there were many instances 1 of the pair of elevators would be out of service and remain that way for a day or two. With so many people, crowds and wait times are unacceptable for a luxury resort. Where I work, elevator technicians would respond the same day and would never be out of service more than a day. I don't remember if I read a previous post about the resort fee, but my friend just checked out and was hit with a $47.50/day resort fee. I am positive I was not told this on check-in and it was not on my reservation confirmation. I check out tomorrow and will see if I am charged this also. I enjoyed my trip because I celebrated a milestone in my life with people I love. But if a good friend asks if I would recommend this resort, I would sadly HAVE to say, "NO".

Reviews.Title: “Great views, service lacking”
Reviews.Author: mandyskisin
Reviews.Content: Stayed at El Con for five days. The hotel facility itself is great. There is an island that is available only to guests of El Con. There are ferries that run back and forth from about 9am to 5pm. I spent one day over on the island. There is one restaurant with so-so food. Lots of water activities or just lying on the beach. Ate at Blossoms (Japanese) and the Italian place. Food was good at both places. No complaints. The hotel rooms are nice and clean. My biggest complaint was with the lack of internet access in the rooms and how the hotel staff handled this issue. The resort is supposed to have high speed internet access in the rooms (for a fee of $14.95 for 24 hours). The first three days the internet did not work in the room so I had to go to the Business Center. The issue, though, was the lack of response from the staff. First, they tried to say that I was the only having a problem (implying that it was my computer). I was there with a conference of 200 people so was able to ask others if they had problems with access in the rooms. All of them said yes, regardless of where they were staying within the hotel. Then, at our request, we asked if we could try the access in other rooms. They finally agreed so my husband spent two hours running around rooms with my laptop, looking for access. Nothing. Then one staff person recommended that I come to the lobby to use the "free" access. First, I had already tried that and the signal was not working in the lobby either. Second, I work late at night so was not thrilled with the idea of setting up laptop, mouse, and working papers in the lobby at midnight. It was a big mess for those first few days, and an unnecessary aggravation. We were finally told by a staff person that the internet access has been an ongoing issue for awhile and that the hotel is in the process of changing internet providers/tech support. I just wish that the first time I went to the front desk to ask about this issue, I had been told "Yes, it is a known problem and we have someone coming to fix it." The staff seemed to not care that internet access was not available, so for this reason, I would not recommend this hotel. There are many nice places to stay on the island, and I definitely plan on coming back again. I will just not stay here. So if you want a nice hotel with a great pool and lots of beach but do not care at all about having dependable internet service, then this is a fine place to stay. If you must have internet service, then I would look for a review that indicates reliable service.

Reviews.Title: “Not what I would expect a Waldorf Astoria Collection to be like.”
Reviews.Author: Hoshy
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a week stay at the â€œWorld-Class Luxury Resortâ€�, which by all means is not. Took over 30 minutes to check-in and from what people have said this is pretty standard. The rooms by all means are not what you see on the internet, chairs are covered with stains, chips in the floor tile. Sheets and bedding were worn and ragged. As you walked through the corridors they were covered with stains. No power washing here. The food by all means is way overpriced and terrible. The Casino has no craps tables and is very small. I kept wondering how families of 5 could afford this place. The place was crawling with kids. So if youâ€™re looking for a quite romantic placeâ€¦choose somewhere else. I did manage to sneak away to the Golden Door Spa, which happens to be the only clean place on the property. I have traveled to many third world countries which had better cleanliness than this place.

Reviews.Title: “great if things run smoothly but when things break down..watch out”
Reviews.Author: ilasik
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the El Conquistador years ago and remember being annoyed at having to wait for the ferry to go to the beach for over 30 min (got there at 9:55am, did not make it onto 10am ferry since it was full, had to stick around till 10:30am). I decided to give it another try because of the new waterpark that I knew the kids would love. Here is the lowdown: PROS: The waterpark is indeed a ton of fun that the kids (ranging from ages 4 to 11) loved the views are gorgeous the food in restaurants for dinner is very good albeit expensive our rooms in the Las Olas section happened to be the only two with direct access to the pool (rooms 2231 and 2230) - which was great as you could just run down from the balcony, my husband could fix drinks in the room and bring them down for a pre-dinner cocktail hour the water at Palomino is wonderful and clear CONS: I was thinking to myself how people complain about the cable car for nothing for the first 3 days when everything was running smoothly. when one cable car broke down for 1 1/2 days it was quite annoying standing there waiting for the one car running filled with people. The ferry to Palomino can be a 45 min ordeal (it is NOT 8 minutes!) You have to watch every charge on the bill - we were overcharged, double charged, etc multiple times. And yes, a hot dog should not cost $10. A chicken sandwich for $12 had a chicken patty that was half the size of the bun - my husband made them remake it. Overall, had a lot of fun but would not go back.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing! Anyone who doesnt like this place is NUTS!!!!”
Reviews.Author: simstar969
Reviews.Content: My 2 girlfriends and I just returned from our fabulous vacation on Friday, April 17th. We went for 5 days. We're in our late 20's, and we wanted a more relaxed vacation therefor passing up the San Juan hotels. Well, this is what we got!!! Ive stayed at some pretty amazing places before- and I am a exceedingly picky. Especially when we were told this is one of the most expensive places to stay in PR. It was worth every penny, and exceeded my expectations. It was clean, and HUGE!!!! The property was pristine, the scenery was beautiful. The beach was perfect. For the most part, the food was good. The only COMPLAINTS, which were minor were the following: The so-called "italian" place.... was horrible. But then again, coming from NY, we KNOW what italian food should be. The sauce was bright RED, and had no flavor. bleh. Otherwise- the service was excellent. There was no local flavor-type restaurants in the hotel. I mean, they have a wide selection, but nothing "Puerto Rican" in style..... The front desk service, and Concierge could have been nicer. Some were helpful, and nice, but more often then not, we encountered women who were, well, they couldnt be bothered with us. The first room we were given was definitely for someone who had a medical disability. The shower was level with the rest of the bathroom- and after the 3 of us showered, there was water flooding to the toilet bowl. We complained, and were given a new room asap. Much nicer. They should really pay more attention to their clientele. The spa- the hot tub in the women's locker room area was tepid at best. On the colder side. LEAVING THE RESORT/EXCURSIONS: We did drive to San Juan/Old San Juan/Condado a few nights, just to see what the nightife was like when we didnt feel like hanging out at the pool bar, or the other bar by the restaurants upstairs. It was about 45 mins away. Not a bad drive. We were thankful we rented a car so we can sightsee. I highly recommend renting a car if you are going to stay at the Conquistador. I found Enterprise to be cheaper than most of the places. We went to the rainforest one day when it was overcast in the morning, it was so beautiful. We were supposed to do the Biobay kayaking tour at night, but I messed up the scheduling- and we ended up missing it! oops! Next time we definitely want to go the outer island- Vieques and/or Culebra. They look amazing.... oh well. Theres a million reasons to return to PR, and especially to El Con. WHO THIS RESORT IS GOOD FOR: Its a great place for families with children- because its so huge, and they have a waterpark. We were actually concerned we would be inundated with children running around us- but honestly, its so spacious, we really didnt have a problem. PLUS there is a pool at the 2nd level on the way down to the Marina, which is usually empty! It would also be a great place for couples- its soooo romantic. PRICES: Ive read many of reviews complaining about the prices of food and drinks. I guess they were pricey. I think being from Long Island, and NYC, were more used to higher prices. For us, they were more normal than anything. Like 12-15 bucks for a cocktail kind of thing. Resort prices basically. SPA: We received massages one day as well. I got the Golden Door massage, 80 mins. It was THE BEST massage Ive ever had. And I use spas as much as I can. We also took a yoga class. No complaints about that either. The gym was great aswell. Fairly up-to-date machines. Within the last 5 years altleast. It was empty when I went, so it was good. They give you towels. There is also a juice bar, which makes great fruit-smoothies. All in all, we/I would go back in a heartbeat! I didnt want to leave!!! I loved it!

Reviews.Title: “Loved the view; hated the snorkeling; the rest was okay.”
Reviews.Author: BethanyBeach
Reviews.Content: This is a very long report, but I wanted to include as much as I could think of. I know that I use this site all the time to get people's opinions and ideas - so here goes: Stayed for four nights, April 2-5. HOTEL SHUTTLE SERVICE TO AND FROM AIRPORT: Must sign up for this ahead of time. $68 per person round trip (taxis are at least as expensive, so this isnâ€™t a bad deal). Someone was waiting at the luggage pickup area with an El Con sign. You must collect your luggage and then walk with your luggage about a block to the shuttle bus. We only had two bags plus two carry ons, but if you had more luggage, you would probably want to get a porter. At the shuttle stop, they check off your name, tag your luggage, and for us, within about 15 minutes we left. The ride is about 45-60 minutes depending on traffic conditions. Upon arrival, you are instructed to go inside and check-in and then come back and retrieve your luggage (in our case, a person from the bell staff took us to our room.) CHECK-IN: We arrived on a Thursday and the line was very short. However, we were in the first seats on the bus, so we were pretty much the first to make it inside to check in. ROOMS: I had originally booked a room in the Las Olas area. I wanted this area because it is between the top level and the marina level and I figured that it would be better to be in between going to the beach and going to the rental car, etc. However, I didnâ€™t want a connecting room as they all too often create a noise problem. I was told that all the Las Olas rooms were connecting and she recommended the Las Brias section. Well, I didnâ€™t even know where that was, so for a moment, I just didnâ€™t know what to do. She said that they were recently renovated rooms and that I would still have an ocean view with a balcony with chairs and a table. She also said they were much nicer rooms. So, I agreed. I AM SO GLAD THAT I AGREED TO THAT CHANGE, and hereâ€™s my opinion why: The Las Olas rooms are actually just about down to the marina level â€“ you can walk up and down to that level via stairs, if you want to. The Las Brias rooms are pretty much in the main building â€“ just a short walk to the lobby, restaurants, pools, funicular, and most importantly to our rental car. It was so much better to me to be where we could easily get to things. HOWEVER, just as importantly, was the balcony situation. We really like to spend time sitting out on a balcony. The views from the Las Brias building on the ocean side, were just amazing â€“ and we were on the second floor, not the top floor. Plus we like as much privacy as can be possible given the fact that you are surrounded by rooms. The balconies in this area had solid walls completely to the top and out to the front on both sides. I could clearly see the balconies in the Las Olas section, and they were not completely private. They had walls that were completely to the top in the back and then ended up about half way up in the front. I would not have liked that. Worse yet were the balconies on the marina level. I think these are the expensive rooms, but these balconies only had railings around each balcony. You might as well be sitting with the people next to you, because they are only a few feet away and in full view. Our room was large and kept clean. I called about the refrigerator not being cold at all, and when someone didnâ€™t come in 30 minutes, I received a call asking if someone had been there and when I said â€œnoâ€� someone arrived within 5 minutes. Plus I received another call asking if the situation was resolved to my satisfaction. It turns out these arenâ€™t really refrigerators so to speak, but electric coolers. However, as the time went on, for some reason it seemed to get much colder. Perhaps it had just been turned on before we arrived. There was no coffee maker in our room. I knew this up front and brought a hot pot and luckily my husband likes instant coffee so that is what he does. RENTAL CAR: There is an Enterprise station in the lobby. It costs about $20 more a day to rent there rather than off site, but then you have to get off site, etc. I reserved a medium size car ahead of time and paid $44 a day for all costs. Also, if you rent a car from them, you can park in their parking spaces for free. If you bring in your car or another rental car, you will pay $15 a day minimum for parking. And all the parking is pretty much in the same area. It is about a 4-5 minute walk from the lot to the lobby. DRIVING IN THE AREA: If you havenâ€™t been to Puerto Rico, just be aware that we noticed two very definite things about driving habits there â€“ stop (pare) signs are pretty much ignored â€“ most people didnâ€™t even slow down. Many people do not drive in their own lane and make turns from the wrong lane. Getting around the area is easy, however. Enterprise gives you a very detailed map. We used the car to go to Walmart and the grocery stores for food, case of water, beer, etc. The Walmart, KMart, food stores and many restaurants are just 10 minutes from El Con. FOOD: We didnâ€™t purchase the food plan. We knew up front that the food is very expensive. We did decide one morning to go to the breakfast buffet and that was a mistake. It really was a poor buffet â€“ fruit choices limited, etc. It just certainly wasnâ€™t anything that I would go back to twice. I realized later that the casual restaurant in the Las Brias area (across from the casino) served a sit down breakfast for a fairly reasonable price. We did get a cheeseburger/fries from that restaurant one night and it was about $16. It was a large cheeseburger and quite good. I know that most people that post have a fit about the price of the food â€“ but this isnâ€™t a Holiday Inn. Most places to which I have traveled charge a lot for food â€“ Atlantis, comes to mind. I think a beer was about $6 and a larger bottle of water was $4. That is one reason we rented a car, so we could stock up and avoid paying the exhorbitant food prices. We figured that with the cost of the car rental, we saved about $75 additional by shopping and eating at other places. FUNICULAR: The funicular takes you from the main level to the marina level. They just keep going up and down, so the wait is never long. I thought it was kind of a neat thing and I went down to the marina level 2-3 times just to walk around. Two days that we were there, the funicular wasn't stopping at the Las Olas section - made me even happier that I wasn't there - that would have been a major inconvenience. PALOMINO ISLAND: El Conâ€™s private island is reached by boat. They had one boat operating while we were there. It left every 30 minutes and the ride is about 10 minutes. The boats are large. The island has LOTS of seating and is a beautiful setting. We went to snorkel, and it was the worst snorkeling experience we have ever had. Actually, we couldnâ€™t even snorkel as the water level never went above 2â€� unless you probably walked out several 100 yards. It was ridiculous. We gave up and left. I saw people in the roped off swimming area standing way out and the water was only up to their knees. So, we never went back. They have a towel station as soon as you get off the boat. POOLS: If you like pools, then you should like El Con. Las Brias is next to two large pool areas. We had no trouble finding a lounge in the shade in the one pool. The other pool might have been for adults, saw no kids there, but all lounges were in the sun except for the shaded section that was roped off, for some reason. We could see the Las Olas pool from our balcony, and I never saw more than 3-4 people in it. So, you could always go to that pool area if you want something not as crowded and don't care about a pool bar. We had a small soft sided cooler that we used to take water/beer when we went to the pools. GOLF/TENNIS: We didnâ€™t do either, but the course and courts looked very well maintained. CASINO: Didnâ€™t go in, but walked by it every time we went to the car. Nice enough size for this resort. FITNESS: I didnâ€™t go the spa area â€“ costs each day just to get in and I never pay for massages, etc., that I regularly get at home. I do exercise, however. There is a SMALL free fitness area in the Las Brias section on the walkway to the funicular. It is pretty pathetic, but I just wanted to use free weights â€“ and they had plenty and a small area for me to work out in. They had maybe about 10 cardio machines but they were all in use while I was there and I noticed that 2-3 people were waiting. No one wanted to pay $25 a day to use equipment â€“ I wouldnâ€™t either. SERVICE: I found everyone that I came in contact with to be very friendly and helpful. The front desk people didnâ€™t seem quite as friendly, but then again, they often have to put up with a lot of â€œcrapâ€� all day long. Overall, I thought El Con was a beautiful setting and a lot of fun to explore. If you do your research before your trip, you can find lots of excursions to do on your own. We had a snorkeling day sail set that was cancelled the day before our trip due to the illness of the captain. That was our only disappointment and we didnâ€™t bother trying to find a substitute because I wasnâ€™t prepared and didnâ€™t want to get stuck on a boat with 40 other people. The only decent snorkeling is definitely via boat, from what I gather. If you are looking to get a way on a romantic adult getaway, this probably isnâ€™t your place unless you plan carefully so you arenâ€™t there during possible school breaks. We didnâ€™t care about whether kids were there or not, but I could tell as it closer to Easter week, that kids were coming in by the droves. I can see how one could feel completely surrounded and overrun by noise and kids. However, if you have kids, they will probably love it. If you have any other questions, you may PM me.

Reviews.Title: “Beware of Blossoms”
Reviews.Author: Gillett9
Reviews.Content: We ate at Blossoms for Chinese food it was the worst chinese food we have every eaten. When you check in make sure your room is not near a service elevator unless you want to wake up every morning at 7:30 a.m. from the yelling of the employee's. We waited 50 minutes to check into the resort with only 4 people in front of us. Not a Five Star Resort

Reviews.Title: “Not even a 4-star hotel”
Reviews.Author: c48gold
Reviews.Content: Before going to the El Conquistador , I asked a friend about his recent stay there and his comment was, " nice, but I wouldn't go back". Now I know what he means. The check-in line that took 20 minutes was a preview of the week - lines for breakfast, wait for the boat to Palamino Island (40 minutes because only 1 was running) and the worst was the funicular which wasn't working properly for 2 days to the Las Olas section of the hotel where we were staying. This meant that we had to walk down 4 flights of steps to get to the Marina area, and take the express funicular up to the main level or conversely, take the express to the Marina and walk up 4 flights to get to our room. Not so much a problem in bathing suits, but my wife didn't find it very enjoyable dressed in heels for dinner. The carpets in Las Olas were worn and dirty. The walls had the marks from suitcases on them. In our walk-in closet area there was a bare metal bar with rusty screws left in the wall where a picture or mirror had once hung but was never replaced. There was a metal strip coming off the entrance door which was never repaired even though it was quite apparent. Some nights we had turn-down service, some nights we didn't. None of the things are a big deal, but you don't find them in a true 5-star hotel. "Tired" best describes the entire Las Olas area. The thing that annoyed me the most was the food prices. I realize that whether you pay less for your room and more for the food, or the other way around the total cost is the same, but it was annoying to pay $10 for a hot dog or $14 for a cheeseburger. On the island, a mediocre lunch for 3, served in plastic dishes, cost $75. At dinner (which was very good at Sting Ray), there wasn't a single bottle of wine under $45 dollars (even in the lower priced pizza restaurant it was $42).. I know these wines and the mark-up was not double, but triple. Perhaps if we stayed at the upper level, our impression would have been different. The area leading to the Golden Door Spa area was beautifully landscaped but that only served to show the contrast that existed there and at the Las Olas area where we were given a room. The staff was very friendly, the golf course a lot of fun (the best part of the trip - unfortunately) but now I know what my friend was talking about. Not even close to a 5-star hotel and I wouldn't go back.

Reviews.Title: “Not bad, but not even close to a five-star resort”
Reviews.Author: planktonrules
Reviews.Content: This is supposedly a five-star resort and if it was not billed as one, I probably would have enjoyed my stay much more. For a true five-star, the following problems would NOT have existed: 1. Standing in a short line for half an hour to check in to the hotel. While there weren't many people in line, it took way too long. One of the clerks was talking with a friend instead of helping customers. Then, when it was my turn, they told me they didn't have a room with two queen beds--even though I reserved this specifically. Eventually, they located one and acted like they were doing me a favor for giving me what I'd paid for in the first place. 2. The room looked clean and was rather large but also quite spartan. Everything was white and drab. Perhaps other rooms were nicer--mine wasn't extraordinary in any way. 3. My final day, I found mites (little red bugs) in the bed. I told staff and they didn't seem all that apologetic. I would have been horrified if I were in their shoes. 4. I tried to book a fishing charter through the resort. The office closed early (just after I checked in) and they never called me back even though I left a message. There was plenty to do in nearby San Juan so I didn't press the issue--but not calling back or having any brochures on hand about the fishing trips seemed weak. Overall, an adequate hotel but they have a lot to learn about the total package--some things were excellent but others were far from what you'd expect. Despite the problems, the rate was decent and the location. grounds and amenities were nice. With a bit of work, effort on the part of staff and updating the drab room, it could be a 4 or possibly 5-star resort. Also, the cost to many of the activities seemed high--such as making guests pay $25 to use a rather ordinary gym.

Reviews.Title: “Tried to scam us after check out”
Reviews.Author: BeachLovers67
Reviews.Content: We had a decent trip -- a beautiful location with a mediocre hotel -- but as others have noted: watch your bill. In our case at checkout the front desk added $750 to our bill (for breakfasts and transportation included in our package deal). After a monumental struggle, they removed these charges. We paid the bill ($2000+) and left. After we got home, the nice people at the hotel changed our bill to add charges back in! We've had to file a claim of fraudulent charges with our bank, and cancel our credit cards because they kept trying to charge us after we left. No vacation is worth that. Avoid this place, unless you don't care about getting ripped off! Oh yeah, and there was CONSTANT construction the whole time we were there -- on Palomino Island, and at the hotel. Imagine trying to read your novel on the beach while listening to an electric saw and hammers!

Reviews.Title: “Unforgettable”
Reviews.Author: jazzylostoz
Reviews.Content: Although its been almost 2 years since my stay at El Conquistador, I still consider it one of my favourite places to stay. We stayed for 10 nights and were given a room down by the marina. The entire hotel, pools, casino and grounds were amazing. We took the free boat over to Palomino Island about 5 times, where we went horse riding on the island, rented a kayak and paddled out to a tiny deserted island and , when we felt like doing nothing, we pulled our sun chairs half way into the water read books and relaxed. The breakfast buffet, although a little pricey, was absolutely worth it. They also have a small gym with breath-taking views of the beach. We generally like to spend only a small amount of time in our hotels when we travel, prefering to go out and explore instead, however, at this beautiful hotel, we only left the grounds 2 times in 10 days. That really says something. A few of our friends had hotels in San Juan, and from what we saw, there was absolutly no comparison

Reviews.Title: “ABSOLUTE PERFECT BEACH VACATION SPOT”
Reviews.Author: chgotrvlr71
Reviews.Content: This hotel is simply one of the best! The grounds and facilities are amazing, the staff is top notch, the activities and amenities are perfect

Reviews.Title: “Watch Your Charges!”
Reviews.Author: Chehan
Reviews.Content: We were at the resort for six days, when we got there they tried to book us (my two daughers and myself) into a room with a view of the driveway, when we were supposed to have a double room with an ocean view. We were able to get a somewhat better room but had to walk 15 minutes to get to anywhere. We booked treatments at the Golden Door spa, the service was average with a huge price. Then when I got home they had run a charge thru my card ($160) for two no show appointments on a different day, and I still cannot resolve, they never call back when they say they will, etc. Also there were about $500 charges on my bill that I had to resolve and have removed on the day we checked out. Check every charge carefully! Other than this, the place was beautful, we enjoyed the island, the staff is friendly and helpful. I got sick with sun reaction and they got a doctor on the phone with me immediately and the medicine was delivered within an hour. Also had left my camera in the spa and realized after hours and security got there right away and got it for me.

Reviews.Title: “The most complete resort in Puerto Rico”
Reviews.Author: wakho
Reviews.Content: The El Conquistador Resort is the nicest most complete resort we have stayed in Puerto Rico. Some reports we read made us a bit hesitant about the resort and it's size and age, and our experience to the contrary is why we decided to write this report. The resort was very large beacause of the option of Villas, independent 3 bedroom living areas, and a couple of hotel options. It was easy to get around the complex with the support of the staff and golf carts that would pick us up at the villas and bring us to the hotel lobby. The villas were more isolated and quiet as we had hoped. There was a nice small pool and a couple of hot tubs available for the villas. The resort offered many options including golf, tennis, cool state of the art water park, multiple pools, good restaurants, shopping, access to the bioluminescent bay, beach on an island, a cable car, marina and a very polite supportive staff all around. We plan on staying at El Conquistador during our next annual trip to Puerto Rico.

Reviews.Title: “Great place if you have a lot of extra money to burn......”
Reviews.Author: Fun1Mn
Reviews.Content: We booked our room in the Olas with 2 double beds and had a great view. We found out later the the Las Casitas Village would have been cheaper and would have had all the same things but would have also included Free internet, full kitchen and private pool for the village with a full bar with food. This would have cut down our expenses alot. The food is very pricey but good. The Olas is like the "forgotten village". There isn't anything but a pool and hot tub with towels. If you want a drink or food you need to get on the tram and go up or down to find a place to eat. I would not recommend this village for a family who needs a kitchen. I would go to the Las Casitas Village and get the same thing with a kitchen and for less cost. The island is fantastic!!!! The water park is also great! Would I go back. If I stayed in a place with a kitchen.

Reviews.Title: “El Conquistador Resort and Spa is Fabulously Overpriced”
Reviews.Author: TravelBugsMaryland
Reviews.Content: The El Conquistador Resort and Spa is a magnificent hotel with breathtaking views located in Farjado, Puerto Rico. I just spent 2 nights there and need to take out a 2nd mortgage just to pay my bill. This place has everything and you are going to pay for it. An example of what I'm talking about is - they want to charge you $7.00 for bottled water in your room, one word for that - "ridiculous". We spent $58.00 for lunch and all we had were fish and chips and a grilled chicken sandwich. We ordered 2 pina coladas with extra rum and were charged $29.00. The resort has 15 restaurants and not one of them serves the local cuisine; unexceptable. The on site water park is great, but don't bother with that because its not complimentary. Instead go to their private island - Palomino Island and enjoy the free swimming. I strongly suggest you bring your own snorkel gear, you will end up paying for the cost of 2 sets of snorkel gear for the price it costs to rent one. If money means nothing to you I strongly suggest you stay here. If your a working class person like me stay somewhere else. This place is gorgeous but its gonna cost you.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful views expensive food.”
Reviews.Author: Swimmer09
Reviews.Content: when we first checked in our reservation was for a partial ocean view. Our room faced the golf course. The manager said he would give us an UPGRADE a partial ocean view. The sheets had stains on them and so did the towels. It looked like rust stains.The food was awful in the Blossoms Restautrant. We were ill after dinner.It was vey greasey. We told the waited but he did not care. The best place to eat was at the Balyhoo at the Marina. We also like the Cafe by the pool. Be aware that they add the gratuitey on your bill. Do not tip. We had the water park package which included the buffett breakfast. The Breakfast was 25 each and after tax tip and gratuitey for three it came to 91.00. It should have inculded mimossa for that price. One night we went to a restaurant called Blue Bahia. It was walking distance from the Marina down a dark walk way. Were were assured by security it was safe. We were seated and waited for a waiter waited for the food and waited for the bill. The food was awful and we had to spray our selves wtih OFF which they did provide. The mosquitoes were bad. The Bill was 63.00 for gumbo, pasta and a shrimp and three cokes. Were went on a shopping and Bacardi Rum factory tour through the hotel. They packed 11 people into a van for a 1hr ride into San Juan. For $50 each it should have been a nice motor coach. When we got to San Juan we were told we were on our own for the rum factory tour. We were not changed for the tour to the factory but we went on our own. Skip the rum factory tour. You can by Rum at the airport on your way home and it is cheaper than the factory. When you buy it at the airport you can then bring it on the plane with you. If you buy it at the factory you have to put in your luggage. We just felt so ripped off every time we went to dinner. If they are going to charge alot for food make it the best and not mediocre. I felt like a prisoner everytime we chose a restaurant. It you decide to take a taxi and each out side the complex you will pay 15.00 each one way The view were beautiful and the island was nice. It did have wasps and bees. We bought water there 5;00 for Dissani. I am glad I am home. This place would be better off being an all inclusive and having better restaurants.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful property with many amenities and first class service”
Reviews.Author: BrynBoston
Reviews.Content: Stayed in a 3 bedroom casita. Clean, very spacious, great service. Wonderful new water park, kids enjoyed jet skiing and fishing. Many restaurant choices - great dinner at steak house, Japanese and Italian restaurants. Friendly, helpful staff. Excellent service. Spa treatments were lovely. Cannot think of a bad thing to say. A fantastic resort for family or couples.

Reviews.Title: “Golden Door Spa”
Reviews.Author: skies8
Reviews.Content: The world economic crisis has caused many organizations to cut back on their services, however a world class spa should maintain its reputaion and its expert fitness and treatment services at all costs. The current fitness classes at the Golden Door Spa have been reduced dramaticaly. Worldwide master trainers, Lawrence Biscontini and Manuel Velazquez positions as fitness instructors have been terminated. They not only offered excellent and various classes in many fitness forms but also allowed for cross training for al hotel and spa guests each day.

Reviews.Title: “What a rip-off! Don't go there--bad service, indifferent management,poor value for money”
Reviews.Author: ljrkrispes
Reviews.Content: Beautiful and very pricey. Breakfast was over $100 for 2 adults and 2 kids. Ate dinner in 2 different hotel restaurants. Both times it took over an hour for our meal. It was so bad that another patron came over to us and apologized for getting his meal first--and then talked to the manager on our behalf. When the bill came for our cold and poorly cooked Chinese dinner, the service charge was still included. My husband talked to the manager who told us that there were Chinese cooks and he was Puerto Rican--all we heard were excuses, and no offer to make it right. I complained to the night manager, who expressed concern and then to the Head of Food and Beverage the next day who did not seem concerned. The response of the hotel was nothing but excuses and no real effort to make up for the terrible experiences. The whole week seemed like a very good hotel was cutting corners--the hot tubs were tepid at best (management did not seen concerned there either). The rooms were nice, the front desk was great and the concierge did a good job. Otherwise, it was hard to get employees' attention as they spent most of their time chatting in groups or text messaging. Since I had 5 Puerto Rican friends tell me that this was a super hotel, I can only assume that something has changed. I can only say that the overall service and leadership was terrible. We rode to the airport with several other couples who had similar experiences at other restaurants in the hotel. The hotel is about 55 miles from San Juan--a $78 shuttle ride arranged through the hotel. Nothing cheaper with other agencies. If you don't want to be a captive at the resort, car rental is $50 a day or so. No real place to eat in Fajardo, so taking a cab anywhere will add up in a hurry. The beach is a 10 min shuttle boat ride away (private island owned by hotel). Rental of an inner tube float was $11 day, jet ski was $110 an hour, a mojito was $9. Shuttle ran every half hour. Internet was $15 a day, computer rental in the business center was $8 for 15 min.

Reviews.Title: “Puerto Rico at the El Conquistidor Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Z06black
Reviews.Content: We just returned on 3/17/09 from Puerto Rico. Since it was a golf get away for 4 guys we chose the El Conquistidor Hotel. Came in from NJ at 10:00 am and were checked in and out on the course by 2:00 PM. We were there in 2007 while the renovation was going on and were glad to see that the project was completed and that the facility was in oustanding condition. Our rooms were in the lower level down at the Marina and they were wonderful. Great weather, great service but the resort was empty. No more that 250 quests could have been there. No waiting for anything, ever. The staff was extremly friendly and competent as always. The ride out to Palomino Island on the new Catamaran water shuttle is always fun. Golf course was in fantastic shape with lots of flowering plants, iguanas and even a mongoose to view each day. We walked off site to the fishing town for lunch twice to have a lower priced meal. We all liked it and found it to be very safe, but of course not as nice as the hotel grounds. With the prices of flights and rooms having come down I can't wait to go back. Highly recommended if you going to Puerto Rico and want a resort vacation with family or freinds.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort with great views but subpar food options that are overpriced”
Reviews.Author: GoCanes2006
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at the El Conquistador several days after joining the Hilton family as a W=A Collection Resort. Prior to our arrival, it was rather easy to add our HHonors number after the switch from LXR to Hilton. The reservation showed up on our HHonors reservation portfolio and the requests / information carried over flawlessly. We booked a Garden View room, but were happy to learn before arriving it had been upgraded first to a La Vista Ocean View and then to a Las Brisas Ocean View. We arrived at the hotel at approximately 1:30AM on Thursday nigh / Friday morning. We were greeted at the front desk by a young woman with a strong southern accent. She seemed kind of aloof. Nonetheless, after a rather long check-in given the time of night, we were off to our room. The Las Brisas Ocean View King room was very clean and looked exactly like the pictures on the El Conquistador website. Small couch, balcone, desk, large mirror, lcd television and a large bathroom that included a walk-in closet. The only problem with the room upon check-in was that the safe was locked shut and we had some things we wanted to get into it, but dealt with it in the morning. A couple hours after going to sleep, we were awoken at 5:00AM by an alarm. At first it was not clear what the alarm was for, but it sounded like a fire alarm. We tried calling the front desk but there was no answer. We went out the front door to only see other guests standing in the open air hallways looking as confused as we were. As we were about to follow the exit signs after the alarm had been going off for 5 minutes or so and no answer from the front desk, the alarm stopped. A final call to the front desk finally got someone and they were aware of the alarm but did not have any idea what caused it and it took them time to find the manual override to shut it off. It definitely seemed like the hotel staff did not know how to deal with this situation and thankfully it was not a real hazard. During our stay we found the property to be very well kept and enjoyable to go around. The pools are very nice, clean, easy access to lounge chairs and several bars with food options throughout the main pool area. Towels are provided at main location that also displays activity options for the day (none of which occurred even though they were listed). Casino The Casino is small and recently renovated. It no longer has Craps tables. There are two blackjack tables (usually only one operates), a roulette table and a 3 card poker table. Minimum bets during out stay at the blackjack was as high as $10 and usually $5. The roulette table has a minimum bet of $2. There are a lot of slot machines with a mix of bonus slots and traditional slots all varying in ranged from 1 cent to $1. Casino is open from Noon to 3:00AM daily. Food Food was probably the most disappointing part of the hotel. By far the best food was at the outside bar Bella Vista just off the lobby. It is italian, but the food was very good. It was while we dined here that we met three people from Hilton who were surveying the hotel. The fine dining options were disappointing. We ate at the Stingray Cafe at the marina twice which was good, but not great. Presentation of certain dishes was subpar and the restaurant that advertises itself as Med / Caribbean flavor could not hit either with greatness. We are there twice, but only because it was the better of the fine dining options. Blossoms, an Asian restaurant was no better than the Asian restaurants within blocks of my apartment. Food was just not flavorful and when the restaurant messed up our order, they did not offer to fix it but just asked that we eat around the problem - completely unacceptable for a nice restaurant at a resort. In addition, the appetizer pan fried pot stickers / dumplings might have been the worse I have ever eaten. Just disgusting. We were really excited about this restaurant and it was incredibly disappointing. Breakfast options are alright, with Las Brisas being the only main buffet option (the casitas area has a continental breakfast) was pretty good. Made to order omelettes, french toast, pastries, meats, cereals and fruits. $25 per person and not bad. Other options include a small cafe past the Casino which was alright (order the ala carte eggs and a side toast to save money). Starbucks was probably the most busy breakfast place and the little bodega-like places all had breakfast but rarely got in new product each morning - so the same muffin would be out for three days. We tried dining at the Spa Cafe three times, but it was closed every day we were there for no reason. Food on the small beach island, Palimon Island, was okay but expensive like all other options for lunch. It did the trick though for our visit to the beach. Other lunch options around the pools have similar fried / burger-like food and salads and are also very expensive. I almost wished they had a better fast food option on property for a lunch option. It was tough forking out $50 for lunch everyday. Drinks were expensive, served in small plastic cups, insufficient alchohol and hardly worth the $10 to $14 prices that are charged at the various bars. A big disappointment as the tropical environment makes you crave some great tropical and freshly made drinks. Instead, boxed mixes dominate all the drinks and just make for a plain and boring drink experience at the various bars around the property. Probably the only great drink on the property is down at the marina bar, the Ballyhoo - a mix of rums and juices which is the signature drink of the marina-area. Stores There are number of different small stores on the property selling clothes, small food options, drinks and even a sunglass hut. They were open most of the day and were not too bad. Different stores though had different prices for the same things, so that was kind of odd. One thing is that $4 water gets old quickly, especially when they do not offer complimentary water at the pool area during the hot days.
