We ate at La Brista for lunch almost every day- good sandwiches and pasta salad- my friend and I split a sandwich each day, and it was the perfect size. We did eat at the Bally Hoo bar one day for lunch- good food (the conch fritters were excellent!). We were discussing different appetizers, and the waitress said we could get a sampler (it wasn't listed on the menu). She told us it was good for 4 people- we didn't find it big enough for 4 as our only lunch, but the food was good. For breakfast, our package included the buffet at Las Brisas- it was the same food for 5 days! The omlet station was SLOW every day (and worse on the weekends). There was a bit of a knat problem on our first morning (kind of disgusting, actually), but they must have done something, because it wasn't a problem the rest of the time. It is outdoor seating, so the birds are very agressive- but really, it's not a reflection on the hotel. The breakfast was fine. One thing to be aware of- the dress in the evenings is very fancy. Men are expected to wear pants and women are expected to dress up. And they did! We were expecting Caribbean casual (shorts and a nice shirt), but it wasn't. My husband had only brought 2 pair of pants, and he needed them every night. Palomino Island was beautiful! We had no problems with the ferry- it was nice taking a boat ride! The island itself was fun. We couldn't find an umbrella (we got there around 11:30), so we rented one for $10.00. They brought it over and set it up for us. The activities seemed expensive, but it is a resort. We rented a wave runner for an hour- split it between the 2 couples, and it was the perfect amount of time. The Caribbean was crystal clear, as expected. It was shelly, though- tough to walk in. I would suggest wearing flipflops that can get wet or water shoes. If you are die-hard beach peole, this hotel isn't for you, as you do have to work to get to the island. The casino lived up to the "Caribbean Curse"- we lost, as we have at every Caribbean casino we've been to. There were $5.00 tables, and we had no problems getting a spot. It's small and smokey but never crowded. There wasn't much else to do at night, particulary during the week. We went to the Magic Show- it was wonderful! I think it runs 2x per week- we really enjoyed that. There was dancing in the nightclub Casablana, but we never went and really didn't see anyone else in there. On Friday and Saturday, there were piano players throughout the lobby and a band. We did go on a sunset cruise one night- it was NOT worth $63.00pp- it was a small sailboat with minimal food and drink- we were soaking wet by the time we were done. We never had a problem with the funiculars as some people mentioned. They were in constant motion and we never saw them broken down. Many of the guests were Spanish-speaking. We were told that in the summer, tourism is down, so they run specials for the locals to stay there. It wasn't a problem- just odd to not hear English! One person told us that this is one of the premier resorts on the island and that many families come for their vacations here. Apparantly Mariah Carrey and Michael Jordan (and other basketball players) own places in Las Casitas. Shopping was good- a lot of touristy stuff- t-shirts, towels, etc. We did buy some Lladro- the prices seemed good (and there is not tax). I came home and checked the prices on line- they actually were very good. My husband bought a watch band for a Breitling he has- also priced well. Rum, however, was much cheaper at the San Juan airport. I spent an afternoon at the spa- it was very nice- good facial and reflexology. I've been to a number of high-quality spas, and this was one of the best. Our friend golfed- said it was a GREAT course. He'll probably write a review also, but he went 2 days after 4:00- very cheap and not as hot! We would absolutley recommend this hotel (unless you are true beach people- it takes awhile to get to the beach or true snobs that can't be happy unless you're only at a 5-star hotel). Several of my friends, when I returned home, asked me if my husband, who is used to travelling in really NICE places, was happy with the resort. He was. The food was expensive, but we expected that at any resort. The staff was helpful and courteous- especially in the restaurants. The rooms were bigger than normal rooms. The pool area is gorgeous- so tropical! And the views- AMAZING! Being on a cliff really makes this an elegant, beautiful resort. When it was first opened, it must have been truly magnificent- now it is just really, really nice. Definitely go and enjoy!!

Reviews.Title: “definitely going back!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Well,we had a great time in this hotel,we stayed for 8 days from July 2-9,2004,this hotel was one of the best hotel I have ever seen! We booked an oceanview room but they upgraded us to La Marina site and we loved it. Having the hotel's private island which is the Palomino Island was the best !!!My family enjoyed snorkeling a lot , jet skiing and the horseback riding. If you're complaining about the prices of food in the hotel well, go out and eat like we did, we enjoyed food outside the hotel and learn more about Puerto Rican food, we even ordered pasteles to bring back home.I didn't go to another country to taste American food again.We even bought the water bottles, can sodas, milk, danish, orange juices for breakfast so that we can be in Palomino first thing in the morning and go out to eat at night,take out and bring it back to the room and eat in the balcony as family.Our family became more closer than ever. When we had a complain about something in the room,they usually fixed it fast and called you back for your comment.My suggestion is rent a car too. If you want to a nice quiet and not overcrowded pool ,take the marina pool or the las olas because that's far from the grand hotel. I never get bored this time because there were a lot of things to do. Can you believed that I haven't visited the casino or the shops. Thank goodness for that! Well,all I can say make the best of your stay because we did .You're there to to have a great time with your family. Being treated like royalties is once in a lifetime opportunity and memories with your loveones will never be forgotten.

Reviews.Title: “Breathtaking views, but expensive...”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My family stayed at the Wydham El Conquistador form July 5-8, 2004. We arrived to check in early, as I was dropping off my grandparents so they could use the casino. We were informed that check in was at 4pm, NOT 3 pm as I wrongly assumed. We checked anyway( at 2pm) and were told to check back periodically for the room availability. At 4 pm, 4:30 and 4:45 we were told that the room was not ready. The desk agent did not have a pleasant attitude. In frustration we all left to drive my grandparents home. When we arrived at 6:pm, I called the hotel to inquire about my room availability and was given a room finally. Parking is expensive. It you self park your car- it is $10 per day- if you Valet- it is $15/day. The parking lot is a short walk away so be prepared to walk in the heat. Our room was in the La Vista wing. It was a very nice room with a King size bed and a queen size pull out sofa bed. The ceilings were high and we had a large outdoor room (terrace). The room was ocean front. The views were breathtaking. The bathroom was stocked with plenty of towels and the mini bar was nicely stocked as well. The beach is located on tiny Palomino island which was a short ferry ride away. You must take the furnicular down the side of the cliff to reach the marina in order to board the ferry. This ride was convenient and quick. The beach itself was nothing to speak of. Lots of coral so the swimming is not so great. The sand is white but there is so much coral in it, it is not for lying or playing in. We ate lunch at Las Brisas restaurant. $66 for 2 adults and 1 child. The food was only ok.The virgin Pina Colada was to die for though! The grounds are gorgeous. The swimming pools are beautiful and clean. The hot-tubs need to be cleaned more often. Upon closer inspection, upper walls in the corridors were covered in mold! The resort definitly has its pros and cons and is not perfect. I do recommend going just for the experience. But go during the off season and get a low rate!

Reviews.Title: “A nice vacation, but was it worth the money?”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My family and I just returned from a one week stay at the El Conquistador (June 26-July 3, 2004). I read many of the reviews before we left, and, by and large, they were helpful. We stayed at the Atlantis last year and several 4/5 star hotels in Disney in prior years, so my comparisons are based on those experiences. Overall, the hotel does need a face lift. There is a lot of green mold on parts of the structure that should be sparkling white, which gives an overall shabby appearance. The staff was very nice and friendly, although their services, particularly housekeeping, were definitely not up to par. We are Wyndham By Request members, and we got the three rooms we asked for in the Las Vistas part of the hotel, which is reportedly the most recently renovated. It was quiet during the week, and very, very noisy on the weekends. Also, we found that if you do not keep the air conditioning on very high, the rooms smell musty. We were on the meal plan for four of the seven nites and dined at Stingrays, Otello (twice) and Isabela's. The first two were good (not great), the third (which is supposed to be the "signature" restaurant), was marginal, at best. My son had a dead fly on his salad plate. They took it away and bought us a round of drinks. The breakfast buffet at Las Brisas, although the same EVERY single day, was sufficient, although it costs $20 per head during the week and $21 on the weekend. The only difference is that they have someone carving ham on the weekend. She was totally disengaged and had to be asked several times if you wanted a bit more than the sliver of ham she offered. Also, the omelet line was so long on the weekend that you could easily spend twenty minutes waiting. Palomino Island was beautiful-- be sure to bring water shoes, your own snorkeling equipment and blow-up tubes. The rates for the banana boat and jet ski were exactly the same as I have seen at other resorts. The funicular and ferry service was fine. The casino is small, and it gets very crowded on the weekend. Nothing for the kids to do, except for an outdated game room which didn't have any games for a twelve year old (the games were geared toward younger children). The taxes and tariffs they add to the room rates are amazing....we wound up paying $320 a nite for rooms booked at $269 per nite. In short, although we had a very nice vacation,I wouldn't go back because I do not think we got anywhere near what we paid for, particularly given the fact that it is off-season.

Reviews.Title: “Not good”
Reviews.Author: shellyewton
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed here in Feb. of 2004. The staff was not very friendly. The hotel â€œnickel and dimedâ€� you to death. (They charge extra for everyday that they come into your room clean up.) You must take a ferry to a "private" island for a beach. You can not bring any drinks or food onto the island; you must buy their beverages which are very overpriced. The food was average with the only exception being Stingray Cafe. The casino was overcrowded. Our experience overall was not very satisfying

Reviews.Title: “Know what you're paying for”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My mother and I stayed in the Wyndham El Conquistador for the first leg of our two week vacation in Puerto Rico in June. I, like many, read numerous reviews of the hotel and was feeling very skeptical of my hotel choice. My only advice ... know what you are paying for! The rooms (at least in Las Brisas) were old, outdated and musty and the food was entirely too expensive. The funicular (similar to a cable car that transports guests to parts of the hotel at the bottom of the cliff) can be inconvenient and crowded. But ... the views are breathtaking. And Palimino Island is a MUST SEE! It is like having your own secluded beach. The water is crystal clear with varying shades of turquoise and blue that linger off into the distance. Be aware, there is a large reef/rock that surrounds much of the island (at least by the beach), therefore, there is not much room to do any swimming. But the hotel provides comfortable beach chairs, many of which are situated under grass roofed huts or swaying palm trees. If you are the kind of person that enjoys an emmaculate hotel room and feel you would dislike the inconvenince of traveling on the funicular or catching the ferry to Palimino Island, then this resort is not for you. But, if you are adventurous and enjoy beautiful grounds and are attracted by the idea of having your own secluded beach then you can't miss with the Wyndham El Conquistador. If you choose to stay at this hotel, I would recomend renting a car rather than taking the shuttle to the hotel. We were able to go out and pick up snacks and drinks to save on expenses. We also tried to take a travel size cooler to Palimino, but were told that coolers were not allowed. Quick fix - put all of your drinks in a bag or backpack and when you get to the island ask for a bucket of ice at the bar. They commonly hand these buckets out to guests that are buying bottles of beer. One last thing ... which left a bit of a bad taste in my mouth ... be aware that the resort tacks on additional tax and tariff charges. We ended up paying $40 extra per night in addition to our room rate. That sucked!! All this resort needs is a few extra dollars spent on remodeling the outdated hotel rooms and it would be close to perfect. I would defintely recomend this hotel to others.

Reviews.Title: “Four Thumbs Up!!!”
Reviews.Author: ANTIRED2
Reviews.Content: We vacationed at the Wydham El Conquistador Resort for four days. My biggest and only complaint is that we didn't book a longer stay. I almost cried when I left, which expresses how much I absolutely enjoyed everything. To start, we were greeted and bags were taken from us during check in. The woman who checked us in was very helpful, positive, and cheery. We felt very welcomed and appreciated. The room was neat and clean, not like some of the reviews stated as being old and could use upholstering. The only problem was that we received a room that wasn't to our likings. First off, the room was overlooking the marina, which could present a problem because of the noise from the boats, and secondly, the TV was not working properly. The repairman, who was already in our room trying to fix the problem made every attempt to accomodate us. He assured that he'd do everything possible to correct the problem at hand. Still all in all, we felt we needed to know what our options were. He referred us to specific rooms that not only were quieter but also more spacious with better views. When the front desk called our room to check on satisfaction, we told them of our dilemma at hand and they directed us to return to the front desk and all would be rectified. We asked for a room change, and the changes were made with no hassles or extra charges. The room that was referred to us by the repairman was situated at the far left end of the first marina area with huge terrace, view of pool, and oceanview directly to Palomino Island, and to our satisfaction no loud boats. Housekeeping changed our linens and supplies as requested everyday, unlike some of the reviews aforementioned. They also checked on us in the evening to see if we needed extra towels and supplies. Now if that isn't service, I don't know what is. We've both traveled to a few places together and separately as well, and we both agree that this was our best vacation. From the breathtaking views of the property, to the polite and knowlegeable staff, to the welcome basket of Merlot wine and platter of fruits and cheeses, we can say we were treated as royalty. If we both had time and money, we'd book another trip for next month. We need a minimum at best of six whole days to enjoy this place. We must admit, it does help to become a member of the Wyhndham by Request Preferred Member. After experiencing this majestic place for ourselves, we've concluded that some people just have to complain about everything or just in need of attention. Either they may be bored at home, or bitter about something because there is no need to have anything negative to utter about this resort. Its a 4-5 star hotel, you'd expect to pay a little more for food and the extras. Its a massive establishment, you'd expect to take elevators, funiculars, escalators, and long walks from your room to the lobby. Its location is in a country where the native tongue is Spanish, you'd expect for some to not understand everything you are saying. Speaking of service, we ate at Bella Casa. I had a chicken salad in which a fly landed on one of the leaves in my salad. Were there any problems in taking that off the bill? No problems no drama!!!! It was removed from the bill and our table with apologies. When our drinks were finished, there were always refills without even needing to signal the waiters/waitresses. Ultimately, we had to take the time to write this because if you are planning to make your vacation stay at this resort, you've made an excellent vacation choice and will enjoy yourselves as we did. We are confident of that.

Reviews.Title: “Bit of a disappointment”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: At the start of our vacation we stayed at the Wyndham Old San Juan Hotel and spent the final three days at the Wyndahm El Conquistador. The staff at the Old San Juan Hotel were much friendlier then the staff at the Conquistador. Our room was spactious and had a great view, but the room showed its age and was in need of refurbishing. The facilities were gorgeous. The restaurants were overpriced and the food was not particularly great. I don't think I would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Four thumbs down..You're better off staying at Motel 6, same Quality less $$$!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Wyndham El Conquistador Resort on May 21 â€“ 25. We decided that it would be worth our $$$ to stay at a Quality resort, boy was I totally wrong picking this place. Overall we were very dissatisfied with this place. First day there we arrived about 1:30pm to check in and they told us our room would not be ready till 4:00pm. I had also provided them with my membership card for â€œWyndham by Requestâ€� card, for early check in but it seem to do nothing for us. I would check every hour and our room was still not ready so we just hung around and explored the place. We used their main Jacuzzi and it was very dirty. I could feel sand at the bottom of the Jacuzzi floor and things were floating around the top, pretty gross! After being there three hours we finally went up again to the lobby to see if our room was ready and it finally was, but by this time it was way over 4pm. We headed for our room down in the Marina section. Itâ€™s about a 15-20 minute walk there and to get there you need to take a couple elevators and the funicular. It is a ways there. Once we got to our room it was like a mini suite, large high ceilings, a mini living room, a wet bar and a large master bathroom with a closet and a safe. There was also a nice balcony overlooking the marina with French doors (The window pane of the French door had a major crack in it). I loved the CD/stereo with large speakers. Overall a nice room. The bad thing was that Wyndham by Request had asked me for my favorite drinks and snacks before hand and I didnâ€™t see anything remotely close to what I had requested. It was as they totally ignored my request. Another bad thing about the rooms is that the walls are very thin and you could hear your neighbors next door. The resort is enormous and the only way to get to the main part of the hotel is by taking the funicular which can be a pain. Especially since one evening we were all dressed up to go to dinner and the funicular broke down on our way there. We were stuck in it for 30 minutes, which made us late for dinner. We had made reservations at Otelloâ€™s. Word of caution, DONâ€™T order the steaks there, we had to take ours back twice because the steak was full of bristles and fat and for such an expensive piece of meat ($34 a plate) you would think they would have a decent cut. The service was good but the food was terrible! We were so upset by the bad food we walked out and the waiter chased us down to the conciergeâ€™s desk. The waiter ended up comp-ing us for our food which was nice thing he did for us. Also if you go to Palomino Island and if you plan to take your own food or drinks hide it all or they will stop you from taking it with you. We were unfortunate to find that out. We knew the food and drinks would be way over priced ($7) for a drink, so we took our own little cooler with water sodas and snacks. As we were getting ready to go on the ferry they stopped us and told us no coolers allowed on the island. Our little cooler looked like a regular bag, but of course they want you to spend on their expensive food and drinks since you are held captive on that island. Also the coffee in the room is awful, so one morning we went to their little cafÃ© bakery place grab a regular cup of coffee on a Styrofoam cup which is only about 4 oz or coffee and they wanted $3.00 for that! We decided to rent a car for the most part another bad thing is that they charge you $10 to park your car in their parking lots even if you stay there you still have to pay for parking. Anyway, we would go to the local small marina town close to the hotel and we would have a wonderful full breakfast with coffee and all and even with orange juice and it would be under $6.00 for the both of us. That place was awesome, and you get to be with the real people of Puerto Rico. The place is called â€œMarina Bakeryâ€� they also serve lunch there and itâ€™s next to a liquor store. That liquor store has happy hour after the locals get off of work. Itâ€™s a blast. Very interesting for I have never seen a liquor store doing a happy hour. Only in Puerto Rico! The casino is okay, not very big and the tables really get packed on a weekend night. The tables are very expensive to play on. Most start at $10 and up. Only one night did I see $5 black jack tables and I believe that was on a Monday night. The shops are okay to look at but everything is so inflated. I seen a pair of flip flop sandals that I liked and they wanted $49 for them and I had seen the exact pair out here in the states for $19.99. Also their bikinis suits are insane. They wanted $40 for the bottom and $40 for the top. If you have that kind of money to blow then by all means. Overall the place is way overpriced and is sort of outdated. All the different building areas of the hotel were so different, nothing matched which led me to believe that at one time there were different hotels and the Wyndham bought them all out and just kept them the way they are. Itâ€™s such a shame that they have outdone themselves in the quantity of the place but lost out in the â€œQualityâ€� department. If you are expecting QUALITY at this place, you will sorely be disappointed. It just looks awesome when you first arrive but once your living there you realize that your were better off staying at a Motel 6, because you will get the same quality but for a lot less $$$$. Like they say never judge the book by its cover, read the book first!

Reviews.Title: “Good, but some problems”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I went to the Wyndham El Conquistador for our 10-year anniversary. We had a really wonderful time. I did so much research before hand, especially this website, which was so helpful. I hope my recap helps... So... Everything you've written about this resort is true (good and bad). - (bad) Unless you are situated in Las Vistas or Las Casitas, expect a musty outdated room. We joined Wyndham by Request before arriving, and thank goodness we were upgrated to a beautiful, fantastic room with an ocean view. No complaints from us, but you should have seen the facilities on the lower levels. - (good) The spa was FANTASTIC! We went twice and had great experiences (massage, facial). They even gave us 20% off for messing up our reservation (worth the inconvenience of rescheduling since everthing at the spa is expensive). - (bad) And speaking of lower levels, the funiculars (two) were often broken down. One night after raining (they break down more often in the rain), we turned around and decided not to chance it because one or both were often out of order. - (good) The beach on Palomino Island is incredible. You feel like Gilligan himself. It is definitely worth the ferry ride! Do NOT miss the horseback ride. The views are spectacular, and the guides are super friendly (and knowledgable). - (bad) The staff is a little confused. I asked the CONCIERGE if I could purchase wine to bring back to my room. I was told no, then walked about 100 yards and found wine being sold in the lobby store! - (good) The shops were great. Don't miss the jewelery store on the way to the funicular. It just looks expensive. They have very reasonable items that make impressive gifts. Tell Robert Kelly from New York says hello! Great swimsuit stores, too, suits that you don't find in every department store. I wished I'd waited to swimsuit shop there (and comparably priced). - (bad) The food. Although the food at the fancy restaurants is great, and you feel it's worth the money ($25+up entrees), you just cannot get an inexpensive meal. The $13 salad from the Iguana Cafe was one of the blandest plates of lettuce I've ever eaten. After reading TripAdvisor, I had the foresight to bring a box of granola bars and some snacks for midday, so we got off easier than if we had to eat 3 meals, but even a quick lunch was ridiculously expensive ($12 hamburgers poolside). I'm accustomed to paying a lot for food, living in NY, but I actually felt taken advantage of paying this kind of money. - (good) Other than the staff being confused, they were all very, very nice and attentive. Any requests for service were met quickly (don't forget to tip). - (bad/good) Happy Hour was the best value around. 1/2 price drinks poolside from 2-3! Great value. But I do have a complaint about the drinks. Okay, Pina Coladas were supposedly invented in Puerto Rico. Yet, the drinks were made from prepackaged mixes, made here in the states! I felt sort of gyped, like it wasn't really an authentic Pina Colada. - (good) Great casino! The people could not be nicer, and they had plenty of $5 Blackjack tables. - (good) The airport transports were a breeze, but a little slow. Figure about an hour in transit from the airport, but the bus waits until it's full, so it might take up to 2 hours to finally arrive. Here's an extra tip: If you want an authentic Puerto Rican meal (you simply CANNOT find one at any of the restaurants at this resort!), here's what we did: On the day of our departure, we left early, checked into the airport about 4 hours before our flight, then took a 20 minute cabride to Old San Juan where we toured the forts and had a fantastic (authentic) lunch. We also had time to souvenior shop before jumping into a cab (lots available) back to the airport. Well, that's all I can think of for now. Hope this helps. Good luck and enjoy!

Reviews.Title: “Comprehensive Review”
Reviews.Author: RunnerJess9875
Reviews.Content: My wife (age 28) and I (age 31) recently stayed at the Wyndham from April 2 to April 6, 2004. Before going, we read numerous reviews of the property on this site and others. As you will note, the reviews are incredibly inconsistent; either people greatly disliked it or loved it. Although the reviews were helpful, we did not feel they provided enough detail or hints to make our stay better. Therefore, we have spent the time to assemble this comprehensive review of the hotel, its restaurants, etc. and to provide help hints & advice. To put this review in perspective, we have stayed at a number of the most common and highly rated resorts in the mainland US (e.g. Phoenician, Ritz Laguna Nigiel), Hawaii (e.g. Hyatt Kauai, Hilton Waikoloa, Ritz Kapalua) and the Caribbean (e.g. Peter Island, Hyatt Aruba, Westin Grand Cayman). So I think we are able to put the hotel in perspective; at least for couples without kids (but I will try to provide advice for families as well). Flight & Transfers We flew into PRU on NWA, non-stop from Detroit. Arrived at around 2:45pm, waited 1 hour for our bags, hailed a cab around 4:00pm. Typical beat up minivan cab. It was Friday and we hit rush hour, so it took a solid 1 hour 15 minutes to get to the hotel, if not longer. The road to the Wyndham is always crowded, since it is not a freeway, so plan for at least 1 hour. The one-way trip cost $82, without tip (I was surprised how expensive, hotel tells you it will cost $65 for a taxi (they were wrong)). Advice: You should definitely factor in the taxi cost, when deciding whether to rent a car. We have been to PR many times, so we did not want to leave resort. But if you think you will use the car, then rent it. Savings on taxi will almost pay for it. (Note: Hotel charges self-park fee of $10 per day; unless you rent from Hotel Avis desk). Spoke to one lady who took Wyndham bus, since it was part of her package. Said it was normally $60 per person, round-trip. She said bus was old and bumby ride; but the buses we saw looked nice. Package We stayed on the four for free deal; paid $359 per night for a regular room, got the fourth night free. Nothing else was included. As an alternative (especially for families), the fifth night free deal sounded good b/c it included breakfast and transfers. Note: All of the packages are for regular rooms only. Also, there is a 21% tax per night. They said at time of booking that they would charge you the tax even on the free night. They made a mistake and charged me for all four nights, told them on check-out and they quickly corrected it. I think I lucked out, b/c when they removed the fourth night charge, they also removed the fourth night tax. Wyndham By Request You absolutely should sign up for Wyndham by request. You can sign-up via Wyndham.com. There is no cost. By signing up, you get a free upgrade and free food & drink amenity. When we arrived, we received an upgraded room (see below); 4 bottles of Dasani water; and four pieces of whole fruit. The website letâ€™s you choose from a variety of food and drink. Advice: Go for the water, you can always drink that warm the next day (beer will do you no good warm), and you will always want water. Go for the whole fruit, especially if you have kids or if breakfast is not included in your package. They originally brought us two bottles of water and two cokes. I called and had the coke substituted. Advice: We drank tab water at lunch and dinner. It was fine and tasted normal. Villages and Wings I could not believe the inconsistent reviews with respect to rooms. I dismissed it as different peopleâ€™s taste and prior hotel experiences. But I have found out the truth, it depends upon which wing and which room you have. Below are comments about each area of the hotel, and we attempted to explore and peek into at least one room in each village of the hotel. Las Olas (Bad): Half way down the funicular (see below for description of funicular), couple stories tall. The only way to reach this level is via the funicular. Not many rooms, area is isolated and quiet, but do not accept a room in this village. The whole area is old and rusty. Granted, we did not look into a room, but I donâ€™t care what the room looked like b/c the outside areas were similar to an old Holiday Inn. Las Brisas (Bad): This is on the upper level (main level). It is the East Wing of the hotel. I swear, this used to be a college dorm. It is old, paint outside exteriors is falling off in chunks. Had a dorm feel and smell. Donâ€™t accept a room in this wing/village. Granted, this is probably the best location in the hotel to have a room. Right near the funicular, in the middle of everything you want. It also has a very nice garden/courtyard area. But it is worth the walk to stay somewhere else. Marina (Good): This is the lower level, in the marina area. There is about a 20 slip, active marina; this is where the boat to palomino island leaves from. The only way to reach this village is via the funicular. This area was very nice, colored-updated buildings. Rooms seemed nicely appointed and second best to Las Casitas (similar quality to Las Vista). Advice: If you get this wing, try to get a room as far inward from the Marina as you can. The ferry boats to Palomino havee very loud diesel engines. Las Casitas: Private wing of the hotel; on the main level; to the far West of the Lobby. Can get multiple bed room villas, expensive. This is of course the quietest and nicest area of the resort. I would say the interiors did not look appreciably better than Marina and Las Vistas, but somewhat better. Advice: Unlike the other villages, you can book yourself into the Casitas and guarantee yourself that you get into this village. But it is pricey. To me, it is not worth it unless you have a family or multiple families, and need the space and want more of a small condo feel. But if money is not an issue, of course you should stay here. They say John Travolta and other stars have stayed here, wow, I doubt it. Very nice, but not five stars. La Vista: On the main level. This is the West Wing of the hotel, off the Lobby. We stayed in a deluxe ocean view room, #4226, on the pool side. Basically, this wing either overlooks the ocean/pool or golf course. The package gave us a golf course view, and the Wyndham By Request gave us an upgrade to a ocean view. Deluxe doesnâ€™t mean anything, it is a regular room. Advice: I emailed the By Request office at the hotel 3 days before arrival. I asked them to put me in an updated, quiet section of the hotel. They put me in La Vista. Based upon several peopleâ€™s comments, La Vista was the most recently renovated wing. Advice: The main pool is VERY LOUD; party because door wall has no sound insulation. I would not want one of the ocean/pool view rooms anywhere close to the main pool. We had an ocean/pool view room, but far to the West, near the entrance to Las Casitas. Even then, we could hear the kids at the pool. If they put you near the pool, ask for a downgrade to a golf course view, on other side of La Vista away from pool. Advice: This wing has a great garden/courtyard area. One of the best I have ever seen. But with the beauty comes coqui frogs. They make loud sounds all night long; hundreds of them. If you have problems sleeping with noise, do not get the La Vista wing (I think Las Brisas has the same issue). We slept fine, but wanted to note it, b/c it can get annoying. Rooms The room we had in the La Vista wing was a 3.5 to 4 star type room (using AAAâ€™s system as my baseline). The quality and cleanliness of the room was below all of the resorts I listed at the intro, but those are 4.5 to 5 star resorts and rooms. It was similar to a general room we had at Hilton Hawaiian village or other Hilton and older Marriott resorts. The good thing was the carpet and furnishings looked very new. But the bathroom was dated and somewhat dirty. Obviously what they did, and it is common in the hotel industry, is they redid the room without ripping anything out but the carpet. So they replaced carpet, furniture and paint, but did not change tub, tiles, sink, lighting fixtures, etc. The Marina rooms looked comparable but a better setting outside. The Las Casitas rooms looked the best, but still, I think they were a solid 4 star room, still not a Ritz, Four Seasons or a new Westin/Hyatt resort type room. Keep in mind that it is tough to keep the rooms looking sparkling clean in the Caribbean due to the humidity and high family use. All rooms had high speed internet access for $14.95 a day. It worked great. Also, all had coffee pots for morning coffee; never used it though. They also all have a VCR and radio system with tape deck (did not see CD player). TV has all major US channels and a movie rental systems with 50 plus movies; extensive choices for $12.95 per movie. Plenty of sitting room includes desk, two chairs and a love seat. Two chairs and table on balcony. All have balconies. Funiculars There is three levels to this hotel. Top, middle, bottom. Top includes (from West to East) Las Casitas, La Vista, Lobby (with most of the restaurants, shops and main pool), Las Brisas. Near Las Brisas, which is about a 7-10 minute walk from Las Casitas, you can board the funicular to take you down. Middle includes Las Olas, its pool and the Tex Mex Restaurant. Bottom includes Marina (Palomino island ferry), Marina Village rooms, some shops, Marina pool, Stingray restaurant and Ballyhoo bar. I never found the funiculars to be a problem. We waited, one time, 5 minutes. Most other times, you wait 1-2 minutes. There is no schedule, and there are two of them. One stops in the middle at Las Olas, the other is express between Top and Bottom. I will note that we were told that the hotel was only 65-70% full. Palomino Island and Ferry Catch ferry at Marina. Takes a solid 20 minutes to get to island; leaves every half hour. Pretty much everything is to the right, as you get off Ferry. There is Iguanaâ€™s (lunch pavilion). Then about 500 hundred plus lounge chairs. This was impressive, there is always a chair. Also, they all have fancy cushions (looked like they were new); so they are very comfortable. The problem is that only a few have thatched huts to go with the chairs. If you want a thatched hut, you have to go early, probably on the 10am or earlier ferry. If you donâ€™t get a thatched hut, you can sit in the sun or find shade under a tree. Overall, this is a very nice island. But donâ€™t be fooled, the main beach is almost not swimable. The beach is all coral formations. So cool for snorkeling, but not much for swimming. Also, beware of the snorkeling, because the water at times is only 1-2 foot deep. There are supposedly other beaches on the other side of the island, but you have to hike to them up a hill, we didnâ€™t. Advice: Definitely go to the Island at least once. It is a little bit of pain to worry about the ferry schedule, etc. But it is a very nice island. We kept walking till almost the end of the thatched huts. We thought it was a great spot, but almost all areas are 5-7 min. walk from restrooms (only ones are next to iguanaâ€™s). They have extensive water sports rentals on the island. Pools Notes: All pools have lounge chairs with nice, new cushions. All pools have towel huts. You do not have to give your name, just tell them how many towels you want. Every pool also has a bar nearby. All pools lack umbrellas. I donâ€™t know why, but they must think us Northerners can handle sitting in the sun all day. It was actually ridiculous the number of umbrellas they had. Maybe 1 umbrella for every 20-30 chairs. There is a collection of 3-4 pools at the Main pool. One was an activity pool, one a lap pool, one with swim up bar. Also a Jacuzzi. Always pretty crowded and lots of kids. There was a small slide, mainly for kids. Pool is not heated and was a decent temperature but little cold. Air temp. was mid-80s, but it takes a lot of sun to heat a big pool. There were individual pools at Marina, Las Olas and Las Casitas. Advice: At the entrance to Las Casitas, it says only Las Casitas guests can enter the area. We ignored the sign. The Las Casitas pool is heated, like bath water. They also have a Jacuzzi (wasnâ€™t very hot). The second day, they saw us coming from the La Vista wing and asked where we were staying, so we got booted. But they donâ€™t typically do that, we just made it obvious. If you want to sit or try Las Casitas pool, simply donâ€™t walk through the main entrance. Walk along the side a little, past the spa. Then turn into Las Casitas area and back-track to pool. Looks like you belong. They will not ask you at pool for room number or anything. Las Casitas pool does get a decent crowd of both adults and kids. Advice: The best day we had was at the Marina pool. There was only 8 people there, all day. It is right on the ocean (not swimable ocean). Also, it is right next to a lawn with plenty of palm trees. So although the Marina pool has little or no umbrellas, we just took our chairs out onto the lawn under the trees. Also, you will notice an individual cabana on the lawn. We used it one day, and no one ever said anything. The cabanas by the main pool are obviously rent only, this one had no signs and the pool attendant clearly saw us in it and did not say anything. Restaurants We were very happy with the food overall. Clearly, the quality of the food did not match the price, but it never does at fancy resorts!! So just convince yourself that the value proposition is never going to be good, just hope for good food. It was also very good service, at times outstanding. The staff is generally quite friendly and sometimes exceptional. For example, when you asked how to go somewhere or you looked lost, someone would walk with you and show you to your destination; even if it took 5 minutes. Tex Mex (Las Olas): Inside and outside seating, bar inside. This would be a good place for happy hour (they serve free chips, cheese and salsa during happy hour); unlike US Mex restaurants, they do not give you free chips and salsa with your meal. We had a very good meal here. We ordered the nachos and 1 order of fajitas. When the nachos came out, we cancelled the main course order of fajitas. The nachos were huge, easily filling both my wife and I for the whole dinner. The nachos were excellent and only cost $10!! So we had a whole dinner for $10 plus drinks. Not gourmet, but it was nice to sit outside and each normal food. Isabellaâ€™s: Only inside seating, 4 star AAA rating. Fancy steakhouse, nice atmosphere. Didnâ€™t eat here this time, but did once before. We liked it, and it tends to get good reviews. Otelloâ€™s: Only inside seating. Fancy Italian. Again, very good meal, maybe the best we had. We split Tortellini; it was fantastic! I had soup of the day (very good) and wife started with Caesar salad (normal; lightly dressed which was good). Good atmosphere and excellent service. This is one way to save fat grams and to save $, split b/c the portions are ample at all restaurants. Blossoms: Only inside seating. This is two restaurants in one: Japanese tepenyaki (like BENIHAHA'S) and a Chinese restaurant. Also had sushi bar. We ate at Chinese restaurant and it was good and very similar to Americanized Chinese; one step up from your local Chinese restaurant, not as good as PF Changs. Good service. General Taoâ€™s chicken and spring rolls were both good. Japanese restaurant looked crowded and since they seat in order at the tables, make a reservation. Stingrayâ€™s (Marina): Inside and outside seating. Seafood mainly. Didnâ€™t eat here. Le Bistro (Las Casitas): Inside and outside seating. Upscale French, need reservation a couple days ahead, if for a weekend. Did not eat here. CafÃ© Caribe: Inside seating. You can tell, this was newly renovated. It has a great atmosphere and a perfect menu for kids: burgers, chicken fingers, pizzas, ice cream, etc. For adults, it is the best ice cream place. Not only the take out area, but go sit on a bar stool and order a sundae; they are great. Chocolate chip ice cream was my favorite. Service is excellent. Overall, I found the service to be quite good, as compared to other Caribbean destinations. Puerto Rico is laid back compared to mainland US, but not as laid back as rest of Caribbean. Day Excursions Did not take any, since we have been to PR before. But Old San Juan and the Fort tours are good; shopping is extensive downtown. If you have a car, drive through rain forest. Nice, but not as nice as Hawaii. If you want to drive somewhere for dinner, but donâ€™t want to eat locally or drive all the way back to San Juan, try the restaurants at the Westin Rio Mar. Large resort about 25-30 mins away. Note: Walgreens and Fast Foods are within 10 minutes of resort. Comparison to Hyatt and Westin The 3 main high-end beach resorts on PR are the Hyatt Dorado, Westin Rio Mar and Wyndham. I do not consider the Ritz a resort; small beach and next to airport. Hyatt used to be two hotels in one (Cerromar plus Dorado), but they are converting the Cerromar into timeshares. I would say they all have their pros and cons, and are all solid four star resorts. The Westin rooms are probably the nicest, then Hyatt, then Wyndham. There is no comparison with respect to size, design, etc.; Wyndham is larger and more grand. But the Hyatt, which gives you access to two resorts in one and the Westin which has a hotel and a timeshare, are both large properties with good size water areas and a large number of restaurants. Neither the Hyatt or Westin have an island like Palomino, but they donâ€™t need it b/c they are located on a swimable mainland beach. The Hyatt is probably the best for beach goers. They have two and three story structures about 30 yards for the beach. Full access right out your room. The Westin is more concentrated in one or two main structures, about 100 yards from the beach. Frankly, I have no clear favorite, but if I were going back to PR, I would probably choose the Westin. Nice rooms and relatively quiet; but my wife would choose the Hyatt b/c of the beach. In summary, I am glad I went to the Wyndham, we had a very good time. As long as you know what to expect, big resort, not great rooms but fantastic array of activities, unbelievably designed hotel, you will have a good time. Even if you donâ€™t stay at the Wyndham, try to visit it during the day. It must have been something very special when it was first built; what they need is not a $10 million renovation, they need to shutdown and do a $100 million face lift. But with that said, you can clearly tell they have spent money over the years; Las Casitas and Marina look very new, and certain restaurants are modern.

Reviews.Title: “Wondeful”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The hotel was wondeful. It had wonderful service. It was also clean and well organized. The Palomino island is a treasure for relaxing. I will definitley go back. The only thing I didn't like was the chinese restuart on the upper level, the food was too expensive and didn't taste good. I found some good buys at the gift shops at the hotel so their worth visiting. Really worth the trip:)

Reviews.Title: “Wyndham El Conquistidor”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The resort was beautiful, the staff was attentive, the weather was wonderful. The rooms were great, large and clean with a great view and wonderful maid service. We rented a car. The trip from the airport is $60.00 roundtrip per person. The trip to the rain forest is 49.00 per person, the trip into San Juan is $70.00 per person. The car rental thru dollar rental was 295.00 with unlimited mileage. There is a parking fee of $10.00 per day. The car allowed us to eat some of our meals away from the resort at a great savings. Most of our meals at the resort cost arround 10-15$/person. The more expensive rest. like Isabellas and othello was approx 20-30$/entree (but the food was very good. The beach was great, but beach shoes are a must, and pack your own float toys etc..there is a charge for use of these. There are so many pools and areas to explore, you will not be bored. The casino is so so, but we are not gamblers. The had a wonderful magic show while we were there. We would go back in a heartbeat!!! Join the Wyndham by request, you can do it at the Wyndham site at it does give you some perks!!

Reviews.Title: “Wow, Beautiful”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This was an absolutely beautiful hotel, and was filled with beautiful forest noises at night. The rooms were average, but clean and we had a great ocean view. Try the Wyndham Special drink--yum. We went in May and it was not crowded. My Wyndham by request snack was not exactly what I ordered, but the fruit was nice and appreciated. The biggest piece of advice I would have is to check any reservation at the Golden Door Spa three of four times to be sure they have it. Pretty much every woman that was there had their reservation messed up. Once you get past that, the experience at the spa is phenomenal. Ladies, ask for Javier for your massage. My girlfriend had him, and she said afterwards: "I'm not sure, but I think we are engaged now!" Nothing inappropriate, just a handsome guy who gives thorough massages! Service in the restaurants was slow, but you are in Puerto Rico on vacation--who cares when you have the most incredible view ever. The grounds of the El Conquistador are the most beautiful of any hotel I have seen. Staff were friendly; maid service was fine.

Reviews.Title: “Wyndham El Conquistador Resort”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: If you want to be away from the city life, this is the place to go. If you want to get to know Puerto Rico you need to RENT a car to get out of the resort and be willing to drive 45 mnts to San Juan or 2 hours to Ponce, the two nearest big cities. Both beautiful, worth visiting and not a difficult drive. Do some research.I think they should at least have a shuttle that gets you to and from town. (Fajardo or Luquillo beach) In case that you need to make purchases, such as pharmacy or the sort. Instead what they have is ferry trips to Palomillo and Culebra beach.The other problem is that they do not serve any food from the island, I found this was lacking in courtesy towards the culture and to the visitor.There is a nearby beach called Luquillo that offers traditional food in what they call "kioskos" (stands). The food is safe (we ate it and had no problem with it) .Also in Luquillo there is a small restaurant we found called Caribbean (----------------------, it only opens after 5 pm, but its very, very clean & the food (Mofongo w/Lobster) was superb. Call first.Do some research in the hotel's literature about the native food.Other than that the resort is excellent in other ways and if you want to be isolated the beauty and the weather are like paradise.Note about the people: Puerto Ricans are known to be very warm, nice and smooth, unless that you rub them the wrong way. So don't have an attitude & they will pretty much try to accomodate your needs.

Reviews.Title: “Filth and Disgust in Fajardo”
Reviews.Author: jatallah
Reviews.Content: My husband and I went to this resort in July 2002 and I have to say that we still talk about how horrible it was. Every time we hear people talking about going to Puerto Rico, we make it a point to tell them where NOT to go: The El Conquistador. The grounds are immense and if you happen to be located on the cliff side, below the main buildings, riding the funicular can become very taxing to a decent meal. The food is terribly overpriced - thought the steak house dinner was quite good quality. Although the main areas seem to have decent upkeep, a visit to any public restroom on the property will show you otherwise - a look behind the scenes. The worst part is having to wait in line and take a FERRY to the beach - which is overcrowded and not particularly clean, as the beach accepts day visits. We will never go back to this resort and recommend staying closer to San Juan where you enjoy the vibrant old town.

Reviews.Title: “The luxury Resort that couldn't deliver”
Reviews.Author: SeattleTravelor
Reviews.Content: Reading the reviews before our trip was very confusing, they were so opposite. After staying at the resort my husband and I have this conclusion. The hotel is very poorly managed. Most of the problems are procedural with improperly trained staff. It disguises itself as a high end resort (which it could be). But it really is a high priced mid range hotel. The driver of the shuttle was very welcoming but after a 1 hour drive you do not want to wait in a check in line that was about 45 minutes even with only 6-8 people in line and 4 people on staff behind the front desk. Then you have to go back to the shuttle get a bellman and then you get to go to your room. No high end Resort checks in this way . Someone should be waiting with your room assignment, they have all the flight and arrival information, you should not have to worry about you luggage again because it is brought directly to your room. The furniture on the balcony is shipped and with more paint flakes everyday. The bathroom had 12 inch holes cut in the ceiling. And the hallways smelled like glue. The maid service was excellent. The restaurant staff is not, and the food taste like your normal side of the highway rest stop. Even the 'nice' restaurants. Not once during our stay did staff answer phone calls not even at the Golden Door Spa. The funicular ride to the Marina is anything but fun. It is slow and one was constantly out of service. The staff would also hold elevators and the funicular so they could load carts and other maintenance equipment. These are not the signs of a high end hotel. Palomino Island is beautiful and we swam out to another small island just off shore. It was very relaxing. Tried to sit at the pool one day but only the upper pool was open and all the chairs were taken. The hot tubs were more like plunge pools. At check out our bill was overcharged by about 300.00 dollars and everyone else in line had the same problem. Heard mostly the same complaints from the other guests. Then had to argue for a good 15-20 minutes to get some of the charges corrected. Then the front desk agent would speak Spanish to agent next to them and you can imagine what was said. So no express check out here. If you are used to staying at luxury resorts this will not be the place for you. If you can swallow the high prices and with economy reults I guess this would be an okay place for you to go.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise Lost”
Reviews.Author: JamesDeloughy
Reviews.Content: DO YOUR HOMEWORK BEFORE STAYING AT THIS HOTEL I received what I felt was extremely poor service during my stay and the El Conquistador and felt I should write and inform those who are contemplating spending time and money at this Hotel. There are many other hotels to choose from in the Caribbean and I suggest you pass on the El Conquistador for the following reasons: 1. Antiquated Moldy Rooms and Dilapidated Common Areas Our room was not ready until after 6 p.m. and when we entered, the room was completed in bloom with mold and furniture, fabrics that had seen better days. The bed was tantamount to a park bench and after being subjected to constant mold spore blasts by the A/C system, my wife and I began feeling nauseous and sick. If you are hell-bent on staying at this hotel, my suggestion is trying the new La Casita Section which boasts a five star rating as opposed to the primary hotel which is four stars. This is information that I could have used prior to my depressing visit. Furthermore, the pictures of the hotel are breathtaking but in reality the hotel is in need of a great deal of maintenance, restoration and cleaning. We were very disappointed with what we were sold vis-Ã -vis the reality of the hotelâ€™s physical condition. 2. Exceedingly overpriced and unpalatable food The El Conquistador is home to the ten dollar hot dog and fourteen dollar cheeseburgerâ€”these are usually two low cost items that help demonstrate the overall prices at the hotel; almost like comparing the prices of the McDonaldâ€™s Big Mac to gauge inflation in countries around the world. Okay, you say the writer is being cheap however, having actually eaten real ten dollar hot dogs and real fourteen dollar cheeseburgers at finer hotels around the world, please make no mistake and do not be confused in any way, this low-grade dog food is not worth the money. In fact, I would price the overall food experience at one-quarter of its cost thatâ€™s if you did not experience the food poisoning as I did over a fish dish at the self-acclaimed French Restaurant--Le Bistro. The last morning of my stay while I sat eating breakfast, I could not help but becoming sickened with the birds flying above dropping excrement throughout the dinning room and upon my table (folksâ€”this was inside). Roaches were also widely present in and around the buffet line. The tables, chairs and floor were coated with bird excrement. Again, should you be hell-bent on staying at this hotel, walk off-property by the marina area and visit a local restaurant where you will find a good fish restaurant with superior food at a quarter of the price. If you do not have the opportunity to go off-site, I understand second hand that the Italian restaurant may be reasonably decent but could make not promise about the cleanliness of the kitchen. For two people, you should plan to spend an average of $50 on breakfast, $50-$60 for lunch and not less than $100.00 (without wine) for dinner unless you eat in the snack bar. I never mind spending money on good food, but unfortunately the food at the El Conquistador was overpriced commensurate with its overall poor quality. 3. Etcetera, Etcetera, Etcetera. The El Conquistador holds itself out as a four and five star resort but from my perspective, I would rate the El Conquistador 1 to 3.5 star depending on the service area notwithstanding Golf which I did not experience during my stay. In short, travelers beware before committing a stay at this hotel. Make sure you do your home work to ensure lackluster service, low-grade and overpriced food and second-rate accommodations does not mitigate your vacation enjoyment. Unfortunately for us, we bought into the embellished pictures and sleek marking material without reading the reviews. I should have known better than to stay at the El Conquistador when telephoned the night before to confirm our room and was disconnected a number of times before I was told in a curt way that rooms could not be reserved in advance. We wasted a great deal of time and money being uncomfortable and left dissatisfied with every meal or request we made of the hotel. We wish you better luck

Reviews.Title: “Almost perfect”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Almost perfect...I say this because the first night we were there we left our camera at the Cafe Caribe @ 9 o'clock at night (keep in mind that the restaurant closed at 10 and we were the last ones seated in section we were in) needless to say our camera did not show up! We even spoke with the manager on duty and he was a total jerk about it, but we got free dinner on the house since it was an inconvience for us. We were told by a couple (not just one) of the employees that we would be compensated the amout when we checked out. But the day we checked put the supervisor working on our report was not in, how convenient! Anyways, the weather was awesome and left the balcony doors open all night (never any problems with bugs)We stayed 5 nights and 6 days. The room was almost perfect...we had a full size bed instead of a King like we requested and they said if we moved we would lose our ocean view, so we decided to stay. We stayed in La Vista wing with a balcony and we had the 4 for free package, which included round trip airport transfers and full breakfast buffet. Going to the hotel was great we were the only ones on the bus and we had unlimited drinks, which we DID NOT pay for (like one of the previous reviewer had stated she had). Tuesday we took the ferry to Palamino Island and had soo much fun. The snorkeling there is awesome. This was our first time in PR so we were amazed at the beauty. We saw a baby sand shark and a jelly fish. My husband also rented the jet ski, which was $65 for a half hour but what the heck. The hotel was never crowded and the pools were awesome. Customer service was decent. Alexander from the front desk came to our room to give my husband's family directions from two towns over. He also sent us home with Pasteles (a puerto rican tamale, basically). El Yunke was awesome. We swam in the La Mina Falls and had a blast. It's about a 45 minute hike from Big Tree Trail. Old San Juan was nice. Definitely a whole day thing. We weren't too disappointed in the hotel cause we knew what we were going for. We only ate 3 out of 5 dinners there and they were at the Cafe Caribe and Cafe Bella Vista. Since we had the buffet we just wanted light dinners. The casion was decent never smokey but if you play black jack watch out cause the dealer doesn't play his second card until all the players are done and we watched the game for about a half hour and almost everytime, the dealer one. A lot of the slot machines were out but A LOT of the nickle slots were hitting all night. One guy won over $9,000 on one machine! We did pretty good too. Overall this is definitely a hotel that you need to stay at. If you're going to Puerto Rico to see the sites this is not the hotel for you. Because of the location and because you won't want to leave once you're there. We are definitely gonna go back. If anyone has any questions please feel free to e mail me.

Reviews.Title: “Absolute Paradise”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Went to El Conquisatdor to spend the day. What an incredible resort. Yes, it is about 1 1/2 hr drive from San Juan, but if your idea of a vacation is to hang by the pool, and relax.....YOU WON"T FIND A BETTER SPOT. The arrival alone is awe inspiring. Driving up the mountain, perfectly manicured greens all the way up, as you are driving past the golf course. Then the beautiful lobby, and the breath taking views by the pool. I love the beach, but I would make the exception to stay by the pool most of the week if I was there. You wouldn't even miss the sand. However...what a nice little adventure to travel to Palomino island if you do want the beach experience. This place is pure paradise. I look forward to staying for a week next year.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a 4 day/3 night stay at the Wyndham El Conquistador Resort & Country Club. Having read the numerous negative reviews of this resort, I was somewhat skeptical. However, having just returned, I can say that all the worries were definitely unfounded. The property is one of the most beautiful places I've ever seen. The rooms were well appointed and the maid service was very good. The food was a bit expensive, but no different than than the prices you would expect to find in NYC or Boston. Drinks were a little on the high side, but I figure you are on vacation in a resort setting, so that is to be expected. The service was very good, from the front desk to the restaurants. Of course there were exceptions, our waiter at Ballyhoo's was not all that attentive. But every resort of this size will have some help that isn't exactly top-notch. The pools were all very nice, my only complaint is that the jacuzzi's were not all that warm. I'm sure it is difficult to keep outdoor hot tubs at appropriate temperatures throughout the day though. Palamino Island (the private beach) was beautiful, but I'd recommend wearing sandals in the water (there is a corral reef just off shore and the broken off pieces of the corral are abundant in the sand). I would also recommend renting a car at the airport. It gives you much more freedom if you want to go out and explore the area. There are actually some great little restaurants within a mile or two of the property, and the prices are significantly lower than the property resorts. Plus, the hotel shuttle is $60/pp, so if you are traveling with a companion, it makes it just as cost effective. I haven't travelled extensively through the carribean, but having stayed at numerous upscale hotels included Fairmonts, W Hotels, and JW Marriott's...I'll say that the accommadations at the El Conquistador do measure up. Oh, and for a great Margarita, go see Richard at the Cantina Las Olas. Great margarita, and an entertaining bar keep.

Reviews.Title: “Perplexing”
Reviews.Author: Nicci
Reviews.Content: It's hard to write this, you just want El Conquistador to be so fabulous, but it's not. We were there for part of our honeymoon, and it was the most disappointing part of the trip. The hype you hear sets it up for the fall. Beautiful to behold, but there are problems in the belly of the beast. Staff attention is inusfficient, and it is outright unfriendly at times (except the bar staff). Our room was crawling with mosquitoes, there was a gap in all of the door frames; I'm allergic and the staff did nothing to help. The restaurants were good, pretty good, but I'd pay the same for the best Baltimore/Philly places and get 10 times the service and satisfaction. The beach is a nice concept, but the water and sand are lacking. If you go, do take a hike to the windward side of the island, though; it's beautiful and romantic. PS Pizza by the pool was awesome -- funny, but that's what we always tell people when they ask if El Conquistador was "Great"...

Reviews.Title: “Solid Place, Solid Service, Incredible views”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Based on all the prior reviews I read before I went and having went and returned, I have come to one conclusion. People are way to critical about the small stuff. Botttomline for a couple travelling to this resort without kids is; join wyhndam's by request program beofre you leave, when you get there talk your way into staying at La casitas village (by far the best place to stay at the resort), enjoy the coean views from your room, wake up walk 50 ft to get breakfast that you an bring back to your room. maid service was on point every day, butler service was prompt. resturants where great (prices to high? come on people, it s a resort and they have all types of casual places to eat as well). the loung with the pool table across from blossoms is a great place to chill, have a drink and smoke a cigar. Overall, place is incredible, didnt have one bad experience. I will say though that the beach sucked (reefs are way to close to shore so there is nowhere to just swin and hang out) and they are in desperate need of an adult pool. Also, the fitness center is a joke. the one at the golden door spa is perfect, give the girl a nice tip at the front desk on your first day and she wont charge you the $25 admission fee each day.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise no other way to desribe it.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: After reading all of the reviews of this resort, I expected a beautiful resort with little or no service. What I found was a amazing resort with great service and friendly staff. I think people whine too much about every little thing, the resort was manicured, views breathtaking and our room was clean and rather large. Each restaurant we tried was good with Le Bistro being the best, and service at all of the restaurants was great. I reccommend staying in the main hotel if you have young children and in las casitas or las marinas if you do not as they are much more private. Just relax and enjoy the entire resort.

Reviews.Title: “Best food found in the mini-bar!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Given our numerous travels throughout the world as reference, the food quality at this property was plain old poor. Not only that, but the pricing for the food offerings was unreasonable. If this property desires to remain as a group destination, it will have to complete some significant changes regarding food/beverage services. It is amazing how good that meal on Continental Airlines tasted on our way home! We will not return to this property as there are much better values elsewhere.....and certainly much better food.

Reviews.Title: “Great views and golf, average diving”
Reviews.Author: godawgsfah
Reviews.Content: I recently returned from the Wydham El Conquistador resort (3-20-27, 2004) for spring break with my wife and children (ages 7 and 13). Overall I liked the resort, it is beautiful, large and very well landscaped. The resort is on a cliff and is composed of at least 5 different hotels. We stayed at the Las brisas (sp?)hotel which has great ocean views and is about 3/4 up the hill from the marina. There are pools everywhere with 3 pools and 3 hot tubs at the main hotel, one pool and hot tub at the hotel near but not quite to the marina and another pool at the villas by the marina. The golf course and spa are near the main hotel. If you want action or people watching try to stay at the main hotel. The marina area seems to be the quietest ( except for the boats). Las brisas was somewhat in between, with easy access to both areas. The golf course was very pretty, in good shape and challenging enough but not absurdly difficult. Green fees were high($160) in the am but dropped to about $100 for early pm play and $70 for late pm play. I teed off at 2:30 and had time to finish before dark (~6:30). We rented a car at the desk in the hotel for 2 days and drove into Old San Juan and to the El Younque rain forest. Driving is easy, but there are almost no street signs to give you reference, so rely on landmarks. Both of these trips are easy to do on your own if you don't like tours. The rain forest is impressive and actually kind of cool temperature-wise. There were NO BUGS in the rainforest other than butterflies, I couldn't believe it. The diving was a dissapointment. Not so much for the quality of the dives, but for the inability to schedule trips. On three days when I wanted to go out, but there were not enough divers (6 is the minimum to take out the boats). The dive operation at Casa del Mar was well staffed and had two nice, new 42' dive boats. How they stay in business only going out once or twice a week is a mystery. They did have a daily snorkle/dive trip, but it is mainly for resort divers and was not a good experience when I tried it. The trip to Culebra island was good with good shallow(<50') reef dives, but it is all day for two one tank dives. The food at the resturants was good to very good and uniformly expensive with dinners for four (with minimal wine/alcoholic drinks) averaging $160-200. Our highest bill was $268 at Othello's. The breakfast buffet was a good deal and we usually ate well there and were too full for lunch. Palimino island was fun and there are hiking trails as well a fully staffed beach with food/drink and watersports rentals. The hotel staff was friendly and helpful as were people we met in San Juan and in the rainforest. My only complaints are the general prices of everything and that some areas are beginning to show a little wear and tear and need to be updated for a hotel of this caliber. In all, we enjoyed our stay and would recommend the Wyndham El Conquistador for a nice family vacation with a little something for everyone to do.

Reviews.Title: “Ignore the Complainers!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 4 day stay at the El Conquistador (over Easter Weekend), with my husband and 2 kids (ages 12 and 14). Had a wonderful time at this gorgeous resort...Resort is the key word here. I have gotten so tired of reading negative reviews, I decided I needed to balance the ratings. The people who complain always say the same things: beautiful place , but over-priced....WHAT do you expect?? This is a resort...have you ever stayed at a 4 star, beautifully appointed, pampering, friendly hotel on a georgeous Caribbean Island that was NOT an expensive place to eat?? If you have, PLEASE give me the name so I can book a trip!!! My suggestion to those people is go to an all-inclusive resort, where everything is included (then you'll get an appreciation of sub-standard food!!) Anyway, We rented a car which is the way to go (hotel bus is $60 roundtrip, we got a deal on a car on Hotwire for $115 for our stay). The key here is no one from the hotel forced us to take the bus. We arrived early, 12:30pm, check in time was 4pm. My husband did a "pre-check in", was given the hotel charge card, our bags were stored, and the very helpful desk clerk told him to come back to the head of the line to get our room about 3....Very easy!! Pool areas are clean and beautiful...never waited for a clean towel, despite the busy holiday weekend. Lounge chairs are hard to come by mid-day.....BUT WHOSE FAULT IS THAT??? It is the ugly Americans who go to the pool at 7am, put towels on twice as many chairs as they need, and then go off to a 2 hour breakfast. I am quite sure if a resort policed the lounge chairs, people would complain about that too!!! Our room was lovely: King bed with pull out sofa. Very large bathroom area, and big balcony with table and chairs. There was a refrigerator in the room, which was great, another way TO SAVE ON THE FOOD SPENDING. (at no extra charge) Now on to food... we do not travel to focus on food, and generally look for cheaper opportunities to eat....there were plenty of reasonable options. The main swim-up pool bar serves a quick lunch (big chicken nuggets, hamburgers w/ fries, etc. plenty of food under $10) Also, the bar had "happy hour" in the afternoon ....cheaper drinks!!! We loved the terrace restaurant: Bella Vista: Great brick oven pizza $12 for a pizza big enough for 2. I had a great tomato and mozzerella sandwich. By the way.,.a spectacular view for no extra charge!!! We also ate at the marina bar/grill: Bally hoo: yummy wraps. Las Brisas has breakfast brunch: $20 for a nice assortment (no more than what we would spend at home) We brought juice and donuts for the kids and had most mornings on our balcony (coffee maker in the room) We also left the property for dinner one night. We did not eat at any of the expensive restaurants, but heard the steakhouse was great. Now on to the other major complaint: the funicular down to the marina, and then the ferry to Palomino Island. What is the problem people??? Easter weekend... we never waited longer for the funicular than we would have for an elevator in some hotels!!! And what fun, a cable car down the mountain, with a spectacular view (no charge!!)There are 2 cars and each holds 20 people easily. Then at the bottom you hop the ferry for the island, it runs constantly, definitely more than on the 1/2 hour. Again what a great ride!!! at no charge!! Yes it is a 15 to 20 minute trip, but you are on vacation, what is the hurry??? RELAX and enjoy the gorgeous scenery!!! The island is lovely, with plenty of lounge chairs and lots to do. Definitely rent snorkeling gear, lots of coral just off the beach with lots to look at (not expensive). The watersports rentals are not any more than anywhere else: $65 1/2 for jet ski and $100 for an hour. Finally, a fun activity in the evening is the drive in movie. They set up a big Screen next to the main pool and show family movies like "Cat in the Hat" You can float in the pool and watch or sit in a lounge chair. The swim up bar even has popcorn!!! We had a late flight, checked out in the am and requested a room to shower in the afternoon. We got one for 1/2 hour at 2, and our bags were checked for us. We went over to Palomino for the day, and at 1:45 got our room, showered, and were very sad to have to end this lovely vacation. In closing, don't listen, go, and plan on having a wonderful time....No one at the El Conqustador will keep you from enjoying yourself!!!

Reviews.Title: “Loved the views”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 4 day 3 night vacation....the kids stayed home.. we stayed at the Marina Area since we wanted the most quiet place....nice room which overlooked the marina...we rented a car from the airport so that we would not be held "hostage". Food prices were reasonable for this type of resort...there are refrigerators in the room which lends itself to snacks...bring some with you if you don't rent a car...Las Brisas restaurant for Breakfast Buffet was worth every penny..we paid $20 per person and the view makes it worth it...make sure you make reservations for any restaurant...the spa was alright, we did a couples massage...Palomino Island was beautiful...we stayed the whole day there...went horseback riding and had lunch on the beach...if you are a beach and not a pool person, this is not the hotel for you since it takes twenty minutes each way... the grounds were ABSOLUTELY breathtaking...the golf course looked beautiful..we did not play...we found the staff to be courteous and friendly...we would definitely return

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful setting!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Very nice. Visited 3/24/2004. Beautiful views and the island beach was very nice! You are captive there for meals if you don't have a car, but if you do have a vehicle there is a parking charge. My only complaint was lack of local food in the resort; a little comida criollo please! The room was very nice. Lovely common areas and helpful staff.

Reviews.Title: “Convention Vacation - March 23 - 28th 2004”
Reviews.Author: Hotelcritique
Reviews.Content: Just back from a wonderful long weekend at the El Conquistador. My husband and I were invited to be guest by his company at this resort. The Wyndham transportation bus picked us up(along with a couple hundred more people attending this convention) at the airport and transported us to the resort within an hour and a half. Once at the resort, we were handed a cup of fruit punch and our room keys. We gave the porter our room numbers and our luggage was delivered promptly. Our room was located in the Las Bristas building between the main hotel and the Marina area. The building is perched on a hillside over looking the ocean. We were in a corner room on floor 3, closest to the hotel. Although the room was slightly dated, we had a spectacular view of the ocean, Palomino Island, the marina, the hotel, pools, Las Casitas and the mountains! In all of our travels, we have never had such a beautiful view. Our complaints about the room were that there were double beds and no king sized bed. Also, the room connected to the next room and we could hear EVERYTHING said as I am sure they could hear us. The ice machine and elevators were outside of our room and they created a great deal of noise. We had a stereo and TV in the room and I was always able to find something to listen to on the stereo. Very nice touch! The bathroom was nice and roomy with the exception of the shower/toilet area. These tubs were sunken and the ceiling very low. Would be very awkward to bath a child in that tub. The closet was also a bit narrow as was the safe. The deck was nice and breezy. There were two chairs and a round table. The table needed to be replaced, but made do. I had breakfast on the deck two mornings. One morning, I was bothered by many black birds trying to get a bite. Music from the hotel pool drifted down and was quite pleasant to listen to. The Palomino island ferries were a bit noisy, but we got used to hearing them. We took the funiculars down to the marina a few times and they were very efficient. A bit scary however as they are on a cable run track. We loved Palomino island! We had a beach party one night as part of the convention and the food and entertainment were exceptional!
